revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2013}} {{Infobox building | coordinates = {{Coord|-33.848343|151.209756|format=dms}} }} The '''Sydney Ghost Train fire''' was a fire on the night of 9 June 1979 at [[Luna Park Sydney]]. The fire killed six children and one adult, and destroyed the amusement park's [[ghost train (ride)|ghost train]]. Inadequate fire-fighting measures and low staffing caused the fire to completely destroy the ride, which was first constructed in 1931, and had been transported from [[Glenelg, South Australia]] to [[Milsons Point, New South Wales]] during 1934 and 1935.
Originally the fire was blamed on electrical faults, but arson by unknown figures has also been claimed. The exact cause of the fire could not be determined by a [[coronial inquiry]]. The coroner also ruled that, while the actions of Luna Park's management and staff before and during the fire (in particular their choosing not to follow advice on the installation of a sprinkler system in the ride) breached their [[duty of care]], charges of [[criminal negligence]] should not be laid. The case was reopened in 1987: no new findings were made, although the police investigation and coronial inquiry were criticised. The fire forced the closure of Luna Park until 1982, when it reopened under a new name and new owners.
A memorial garden was installed by Luna Park in 1995, but its fixtures were lost during the park's 2003 redevelopment. In replacement, a plaque listing those killed was placed on the location of the ride, but a promised mural to surround the plaque was never painted. A separate memorial park was created by [[North Sydney Council]] in 2007, including a sculpture by [[Michael Leunig]].
==Ride== {{Expand section|size, layout, capacity, and features of the ride|date=April 2010}} Luna Park's Ghost Train was a [[ghost train (ride)|ghost train]]-style amusement ride. Designed and constructed in 1931 at [[Luna Park Glenelg]], the ride was transported to [[Milsons Point, New South Wales|Milsons Point]] along with all the other rides and reassembled prior to Luna Park Sydney's first opening in October 1935.
==Fire== On the night of 9 June 1979, a fire broke out inside the ride at approximately 10:15 pm. Due to a combination of low water pressure, under-staffing within the park, and inadequate coverage of the Ghost Train by the park's fire hose system, the fire was able to completely consume the ride.<ref name=Marshall110>{{Cite book|last=Marshall |first=Sam |year=2005 |title=Luna Park - Just for fun |edition=2nd |publisher=Luna Park Sydney Pty Ltd |location=Sydney, Australia |isbn=0-646-44807-2 |page=110}}</ref><ref name="SMHmay-26-07-INSIGHT">{{Cite news|first=Kate |last=McClymont |title=Haunting questions won't go away |url=http://www.smh.com.au/news/national/the-haunting-questions-that-linger/2007/05/25/1179601669141.html |work=Sydney Morning Herald - Weekend Insight |page=13 |date=26 May 2007 |accessdate=7 June 2007}} - Note that the online version differs from print article; different title (''Haunting questions linger'') and first three paragraphs missing.</ref> It took an hour to bring the fire under control, but it was extinguished before any significant damage could be done to the adjacent River Caves and [[Big Dipper (Luna Park Sydney)|Big Dipper]].<ref name="SMHmay-26-07-INSIGHT"/><ref name="TheAge19790611Birnbauer01"/>
Around 35 people were believed to have been on the ride when thick smoke began to escape from the tunnel doors.<ref name="TheAge19790611Birnbauer01"/> Ride staff raised the alarm, and began to pull people from the ride as their cars exited the tunnel.<ref name="TheAge19790611Birnbauer01"/> It was initially thought that everybody had escaped the fire, but at around 11:30 pm, the bodies of seven people were found inside the ride: John Godson and his two children, Damien and Craig, and four [[Waverley College]] students; Jonathon Billings, Richard Carroll, Michael Johnson, and Seamus Rahilly.<ref name="SMHmay-26-07-INSIGHT"/><ref name="TheAge19790611Birnbauer01"/> At the time of the fire, investigating police speculated that the seven had climbed out of their cars and unsuccessfully tried to find their way out of the tunnel; had they stayed in the cars, they might have survived.<ref name="TheAge19790611Birnbauer01"/> Other evacuated passengers reported seeing empty cars exit the tunnel on fire.<ref name="TheAge19790611Birnbauer02">{{Cite news|title=Seven die at fun fair: Suddenly fire and smoke make the mock horror real |newspaper=The Age |date=11 June 1979 |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=ydoQAAAAIBAJ&sjid=x5IDAAAAIBAJ&pg=4980,4921257&dq=luna+park+fire&hl=en |accessdate=10 April 2010}}</ref>
==Investigation== The park was shut down immediately after the incident for a federal investigation.<ref name=Marshall110/><ref name="TheAge19790611Birnbauer01"/> A [[coroner|coronial]] inquiry into the incident did not determine the cause of the fire, although it was demonstrated that the ride's permanent wiring and attractions were not the source of ignition.<ref name=Marshall110/> Coroner Kevin Anderson found that Luna Park's management had failed to develop an adequate fire suppression program, despite recommendations by [[North Sydney Council]] and the Fire Department eighteen months earlier.<ref name=Marshall110/> Anderson's report stated that while the park's owners and management had failed in their [[duty of care]] towards patrons, the failure was not ''"that high degree of negligence necessary to support a charge of [[criminal negligence]]"''.<ref>{{Cite book|last=Marshall |first=Sam |year=2005 |title=Luna Park - Just for fun |edition=2nd |publisher=Luna Park Sydney Pty Ltd |location=Sydney, Australia |isbn=0-646-44807-2 |pages=110–111}}</ref> The [[NSW Government]] called for new tenders to operate the park on 31 July 1979.<ref name=Marshall111>{{Cite book|last=Marshall |first=Sam |year=2005 |title=Luna Park - Just for fun |edition=2nd |publisher=Luna Park Sydney Pty Ltd |location=Sydney, Australia |isbn=0-646-44807-2 |page=111}}</ref>
Before the fire, a Sydney design consultant stated that he had advised Luna Park management to install a sprinkler system in the Ghost Train in December 1977, following an inspection of the park for potential renovations.<ref name="TheAge19790611Birnbauer01">{{Cite news|title=Seven die at fun fair: Electrical fault suspected in ghost train fire |newspaper=The Age |first=Bill |last=Birnbauer |date=11 July 1979 |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=ydoQAAAAIBAJ&sjid=x5IDAAAAIBAJ&pg=4980,4921257&dq=luna+park+fire&hl=en |accessdate=10 April 2010}}</ref> The recommendation was not followed.<ref name=Marshall110/><ref name="TheAge19790611Birnbauer01"/>
In 1987, a Government inquiry into corruption by the [[National Crime Authority of Australia|National Crime Authority]] reopened the investigation of the fire.<ref name=Spirits42>{{cite video |people=[[Gregory J. Read]] (director) |date=1996 |title=''Spirits of the Carnival - The Quest for Fun'' |url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0305463/ |medium=Documentary, Videotape |publisher=Paper Bark Films (production), Total Film & Television (distribution) |location=Sydney}} Scene occurring 42:00 to 43:30</ref> No new evidence was presented, but it was found that the police investigation into the incident had been inadequate, and the coronial inquiry ineffective.<ref name=Spirits42/>
Despite claims ranging from faulty wiring to sabotage in an attempt to have the park closed down and demolished, the cause of the fire has never been established.<ref name=Spirits42/>
===Links to Abe Saffron=== {{See also|Abe Saffron}} In May 2007, Anne Buckingham, a niece of Sydney underworld figure [[Abe Saffron]], claimed in an interview with ''[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]'' that her uncle was responsible for the fire.<ref name="SMHmay-26-07"/> Saffron had been associated with seven other arson attacks in the two years following the Ghost Train fire, although he had repeatedly denied involvement with the Ghost Train fire.<ref name="SMHmay-26-07-INSIGHT"/><ref name="SMHmay-26-07"/> Buckingham claimed the attack was part of a plan for Saffron to gain control of Luna Park's lease, although she stated her belief that the seven deaths were not intended.<ref name="SMHmay-26-07"/>
Former Park Artist [[Martin Sharp]] claimed that Saffron had approached Luna Park's owner, Ted Hopkins, several years before the fire, offering to buy the park.<ref name="SMHmay-26-07-INSIGHT"/> In 1985, it was claimed by NSW [[Member of Parliament|MP]] [[Michael John Hatton]] that Saffron had [[beneficial ownership]] of the park, resulting in an inquiry which concluded that although people related to Saffron were involved in supplying pinball and arcade games to Luna Park, Abe Saffron himself was not linked to the ownership of the park.<ref name="SMHmay-26-07-INSIGHT"/>
Buckingham later denied she made the comments attributed to her and demanded the story not be published, although the ''Herald'' claims her original statements were recorded on tape during a face-to-face interview.<ref name="SMHmay-26-07">{{Cite news |first=Kate |last= McClymont |title=Niece links Abe Saffron to Luna Park deaths |url=http://www.smh.com.au/news/national/they-werent-meant-to-die/2007/05/25/1179601666851.html |work=Sydney Morning Herald |pages=1, 13 |date=26 May 2007 |accessdate=7 June 2007}}</ref> The NSW [[Attorney General#Australia|Attorney General]] has stated the coronial inquiry could be reopened, but would first require the submission of new evidence to the police.<ref>{{Cite news|author=[[Australian Associated Press]] |title=Fun park fire inquest could be reopened |url=http://www.news.com.au/story/0,23599,21825940-1242,00.html?from=public_rss |work=News.com.au |date=31 May 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080416195803/http://www.news.com.au/story/0%2C23599%2C21825940-1242%2C00.html?from=public_rss |archivedate=16 April 2008 |accessdate=7 December 2015 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
==Memorial== A memorial was dedicated in 1995 to the seven victims of the 1979 fire, with a tree planted next to an antique bench decorated with the names of the victims.<ref name="SMHjuly-14-03">{{Cite news|first=Sean |last=Nicholls |title=Ghost Train memorial tree haunts developers |url=http://www.smh.com.au/articles/2003/07/13/1058034877881.html |work=Sydney Morning Herald |date=13 July 2003 |accessdate=7 June 2007}}</ref> During the 2003 redevelopment, the tree was removed and the bench lost.<ref name="SMHjuly-14-03"/> Park director Warwick Doughty claimed that the memorial and events had little relevance, although North Sydney mayor Genia McCaffery, among others, disagreed and campaigned for the memorial's reinstatement.<ref name="SMHjuly-14-03"/> In 2004, a plaque listing the names of the victims was placed on an external wall of the [[Luna Park Sydney#Big Top|Big Top]], which was constructed on the site of the Ghost Train.<ref>{{Cite book|last=Marshall |first=Sam |year=2005 |title=Luna Park - Just for fun |edition=2nd |publisher=Luna Park Sydney Pty Ltd |location=Sydney, Australia |isbn=0-646-44807-2 |page=152}}</ref><ref name="SMH29mar04">{{Cite news|first=Sean |last=Nicholls |title=Tragic day at fun park recalled |url=http://www.smh.com.au/articles/2004/03/28/1080412238257.html |work=Sydney Morning Herald |date=29 March 2004 |accessdate=7 June 2007}}</ref> The plaque was to be the centrepiece of a mural painted by former Park Artist [[Martin Sharp]],<ref name="SMH29mar04"/> but this has never been painted. At least one person present at the unveiling of the plaque was unimpressed with the new memorial.<ref name="SMH29mar04"/>
A memorial park was opened at Lavender Bay by North Sydney Council on 25 August 2007.<ref name=mosman/> The ''Art Barton'' Park, named after former Park Artist Arthur Barton, includes a bronze sculpture designed by [[Michael Leunig]] dedicated to the victims.<ref name=mosman>{{Cite news|first=Andre |last=Khoury |title=Memorial honours for victims |url=http://www.mosmandaily.com.au/article/2007/08/29/1296_news.html |work=The Mosman Daily |publisher=Cumberland Newspapers |date=29 August 2007 |accessdate=9 September 2007}}</ref>
The Chapel at Waverley College features a memorial to four of the boys who perished in the fire. The memorial features a photo of each boy along with their names on a plaque.
==See also== {{Portalbar|1970s|Sydney|Fire|Disasters|Death}} *[[List of disasters in Australia by death toll]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Sydney Ghost Train Fire}} [[Category:Fires in Australia]] [[Category:1979 fires]] [[Category:1979 in Australia]] [[Category:Amusement park accidents]] [[Category:Disasters in Sydney]]

revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=October 2011}} {{Infobox music festival | name =60x60 | image = | caption = | location =Worldwide | years_active =2003-present | founders =[[Robert Voisey]] | dates = | genre = [[Electronic music]] | attendance = | capacity = | website =[http://www.60x60.com 60x60 Official Website ] }} '''60x60''' is a collection of 60 [[Electroacoustic music|electroacoustic]] or [[acousmatic]] works from 60 different composers/artists, each work 60 seconds or less in duration. 60x60 project showcases sixty new works, each sixty seconds or less, by sixty composers in a continuous sixty-minute concert, for a one-hour cross-section of contemporary music. The 60x60 project was conceived and developed by the new music consortium, [[Vox Novus]] and its founder, [[Robert Voisey]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.voxnovus.com/about/FounderStatement.htm |title=Founder of Vox Novus - Vox Novus - the new voice in contemporary music |publisher=Vox Novus |date= |accessdate=2016-03-30}}</ref><ref>[http://www.voxnovus.com/composer/Robert_Voisey.htm Robert Voisey – biography]. Voxnovus.com. Retrieved on October 18, 2011.</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fly.co.uk/fly/archives/uscanada_features/robert_voisey_time_and_motion.html |title=Cheap Flights Online - Search Flights on fly.co.uk |author=fly.co.uk |work=fly.co.uk |accessdate=March 30, 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927201334/http://www.fly.co.uk/fly/archives/uscanada_features/robert_voisey_time_and_motion.html |archivedate=September 27, 2007 }}</ref><ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20110714133921/http://www.musiccriticfresno.com/orpheus1.htm ''ORPHEUS DELIGHTS WITH MIXED MEDIA'']. Benjamin Boone, Music Critic Fresno, February 23, 2010</ref>
60x60 was designed to showcase the diversity of the contemporary music and has succeeded in presenting thousands of composers in hundreds of performances around the world since 2003.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://chambermusiciantoday.com/blog/posts/Think-fast/ |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130118223537/http://chambermusiciantoday.com/blog/posts/Think-fast/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2013-01-18 |title=Think fast! |publisher=Chamber Musician Today |date= |accessdate=2014-06-05 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Maven |first=Music |url=http://newmusicresource.blogspot.com/2012/10/happy-anniversary-vox-novus-60x60.html |title=Experimental Music and Video Resource: Happy Anniversary Vox Novus 60x60! |publisher=Newmusicresource.blogspot.com |date=2012-09-18 |accessdate=2014-06-05}}</ref> The 60x60 project puts out a call for submissions<ref>[http://www.voxnovus.com/60x60/Call.htm 60x60 – Call for Works] Voxnovus.com. Retrieved on October 18, 2011.</ref><ref>[http://www.rte.ie/radio/radioplayer/rteradioweb.html#!rii=16%3A3257131%3A2407%3A%3A Saturday April 4th, 2012] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120418035639/http://www.rte.ie/radio/radioplayer/rteradioweb.html |date=April 18, 2012 }} Day Break with Trish Taylor, RTÉ lyric FM 96-99fm Ireland</ref> for recorded media 60 seconds or less in length (also known as signature works.)<ref>[http://www.umfk.maine.edu/valleyvision/release/default.cfm?release=04239 UMFK professor has second composition released on CD to present around the world.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110719052332/http://www.umfk.maine.edu/valleyvision/release/default.cfm?release=04239 |date=July 19, 2011 }}</ref><ref>[http://www.newmusicbox.org/page.nmbx?id=61tp00 Got a Minute? A Few Words on Music in 60 Seconds or Less]. New Music Box (May 1, 2004). Retrieved on October 18, 2011.</ref><ref>Chris Pasles [http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/news/arts/la-ca-composers22jul22,1,7146085.story?amp;ctrack=1&coll=la-entnews-arts&cset=true&ctrack=5&cset=true WRITERS' BLOCK], "Los Angeles Times", July 22, 2007</ref> 60 one-minute works are selected from the submissions. The 60 works are then ordered to create a one-hour music mix. The 60x60 mix is then synchronized with and analogue clock where the beginning of each new minute brings the beginning of a new musical work by a different artist. the 60x60 mix is then presented in several venues throughout the world. Later in the performance season, 60x60 collaborates with artists of different disciplines to create multimedia performances with dance, video, and/or fine arts.
==Performance, participants and purpose== The performance of 60x60 consists of the 60 works played over loudspeakers in succession without pause for 1 hour.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.morrisdailyherald.com/articles/2007/11/08/neighbors/821lewis.txt|title=Local News for Grundy County|work=Morris Herald-News|accessdate=March 30, 2016}}</ref> It is played in conjunction with a synchronized analog clock. Works less than 60 seconds are artistically placed within a minute time frame; the rest of the minute is filled with silence until the next minute begins.<ref>[http://www.lewisu.edu/news/Newsarticle.htm?PArticleID=2155 Music Bytes at Lewis University] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716111806/http://www.lewisu.edu/news/Newsarticle.htm?PArticleID=2155 |date=July 16, 2011 }}. Lewisu.edu. Retrieved on October 18, 2011.</ref>
60x60's primary focus is to create an artistic representation of the electronic music being created in society today and to present that music to a large audience, "to represent diverse composers from all walks of life"<ref>[https://archive.is/20120710021442/http://columbiachronicle.com/microtonality-in-60-seconds/ ''Microtonality in 60 seconds''] Brianna Wellen, [[The Columbia Chronicle]] May 5, 2010</ref> Each 60x60 performance mix contains a wide variety of musical styles and aesthetics. "Founder Robert Voisey said the 60-centric format – inspired by other intermission-free performances in New York – is designed to retain audiences' attention. And through "60x60," he hopes to expose newcomers to electronic music."<ref>[https://archive.is/20120722214845/http://www.columbusdispatch.com/live/content/life/stories/2009/10/03/1A_60X60_DANCE.ART_ART_10-03-09_D1_M3F7CT9.html?sid=101 ''Minute hand to sweep performers on, offstage'']. Amy Saunders. ''[[The Columbus Dispatch]]'' published October 3, 2009</ref>
More than 2000 composers have been included in the project. A few notable composers in the 60x60 project include: [[Liana Alexandra]], [[Ernst Bacon]], [[Dennis Bathory-Kitsz]], [[Eve Beglarian]], [[Stephen Betts]], [[Colin Black]], [[James Brody]], [[George Brunner (composer)|George Brunner]], [[Warren Burt]], [[Monique Buzzarté]], [[Christian Calon]], [[David Campbell (composer)|David Campbell]], [[Robert Carl]], [[Gustav Ciamaga]], [[:fr:Paul Clouvel]], [[Noah Creshevsky]], [[Francis Dhomont]], [[Robert Dick]], [[Emma Lou Diemer]], [[Moritz Eggert]], [[Arne Eigenfeldt]], [[Karlheinz Essl]], [[Carlo Forlivesi]], [[David Gamper]], [[J. Ryan Garber]], [[Robert Gluck]], [[Daniel Goode]], [[David Gunn (composer)|David Gunn]], [[James Harley]], [[David Evan Jones (composer)|David Evan Jones]], [[Richard Kostelanetz]], [[Gintas K]], [[Joan La Barbara]], [[Le Tuan Hung]], [[Mary Jane Leach]], [[Elainie Lillios]], [[John Link (composer)|John Link]], [[Guy Livingston]], [[Annea Lockwood]], [[Chris Mann (composer)|Chris Mann]], [[If, Bwana|Al Margolis]], [[Mike McFerron]], [[Diana McIntosh]], [[Christian McLeer]], [[David Morneau]], [[John Oliver (composer)|John Oliver]], [[Pauline Oliveros]], [[Marco Oppedisano]], [[Cezary Ostrowski]], [[Frank J. Oteri]], [[Robert W. Parker]], [[Maggi Payne]], [[Sarah Peebles]], [[Anne van Schothorst]], [[Daria Semegen]], [[Alex Shapiro]], [[Judith Shatin]], [[Alice Shields]], [[Juan Maria Solare]], [[Laurie Spiegel]], [[Allen Strange]], [[Robert Scott Thompson]], [[Barry Truax]], [[Eldad Tsabary]], [[Robert Voisey]], [[Jane Wang]], [[Rodney Waschka II]], and [[Hildegard Westerkamp]]
60x60 is a project in which promotes both established and emerging composers and artists alike. 60x60 is a platform for the contemporary composer to promote his or her career and expose their style and aesthetic to audiences around the world. Some of the emerging composers include: [[John Akins]],<ref>[http://www.evangel.edu/News/PressReleases/2010/0409Atkins.asp Evangel News: Professor’s music selected for International Computer Music Conference] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110927151532/http://www.evangel.edu/News/PressReleases/2010/0409Atkins.asp |date=September 27, 2011 }}. Evangel.edu (April 9, 2010). Retrieved on October 18, 2011.</ref> [[Christopher Ariza]],<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20110714133921/http://www.musiccriticfresno.com/orpheus1.htm Music Critic Fresno]. Music Critic Fresno (February 23, 2010). Retrieved on October 18, 2011.</ref> [[Jason Bolte]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ucmo.edu/music/malone.cfm |title=College of Arts, Humanities, and Social Sciences :: Music : University of Central Missouri |publisher=Web.archive.org |date= |accessdate=2016-03-30 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090304014026/http://www.ucmo.edu/music/malone.cfm |archivedate=March 4, 2009 }}</ref><ref>[http://www.digitalartweeks.ethz.ch/web/DAW07/Soundscape Stereophonic Soundscape]. Digitalartweeks.ethz.ch (July 23, 2009). Retrieved on October 18, 2011.</ref><ref>[http://j.web.umkc.edu/jlbtfc/biography.html Jason Bolte – Biography]. J.web.umkc.edu. Retrieved on October 18, 2011.</ref> [[Scott Brickman]] <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.umfk.edu/valleyvision/release/default.cfm?release=05160 |title=UMFK professor's music to be featured at two New York premieres - University of Maine at Fort Kent |publisher=Umfk.edu |date=2005-10-14 |accessdate=2014-06-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140607000936/https://www.umfk.edu/valleyvision/release/default.cfm?release=05160 |archivedate=June 7, 2014 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.umfk.edu/valleyvision/release/default.cfm?release=04239 |title=UMFK professor has second composition released on CD - University of Maine at Fort Kent |publisher=Umfk.edu |date=2004-12-24 |accessdate=2014-06-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140606211443/https://www.umfk.edu/valleyvision/release/default.cfm?release=04239 |archivedate=June 6, 2014 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.umfk.edu/valleyvision/release/default.cfm?release=04214 |title=UMFK professor has compositions performed at concerts - University of Maine at Fort Kent |publisher=Umfk.edu |date=2004-11-05 |accessdate=2014-06-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140607002701/https://www.umfk.edu/valleyvision/release/default.cfm?release=04214 |archivedate=June 7, 2014 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.umfk.edu/valleyvision/release/default.cfm?release=03159 |title=UMFK professor will have composition premiered at VoxNovus concert in Manhattan, New York - University of Maine at Fort Kent |publisher=Umfk.edu |date=2003-10-24 |accessdate=2014-06-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140606235242/https://www.umfk.edu/valleyvision/release/default.cfm?release=03159 |archivedate=June 6, 2014 }}</ref> [[Mikel Butler]],<ref>[http://media.www.thepinelog.com/media/storage/paper954/news/2008/02/04/Entertainment/Sfa-Students.Composition.To.Be.Featured.In.60x60.Concert.Tuesday-3186230.shtml ''SFA student's composition to be featured in 60X60 concert Tuesday'']{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}. Julianna Backer Issue date: February 4, 2008</ref> [[Russel Cannon]],<ref name="ucsc">[http://music.ucsc.edu/grad/dma/composition/currentstudents.html ''Music professor rewards honor students with steak dinners''] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090306183004/http://music.ucsc.edu/grad/dma/composition/currentstudents.html |date=March 6, 2009 }} Tracy Lyall Issue date: November 10, 2008</ref> [[Maurilio Cacciatore]],<ref>{{fr icon}} [http://www.italieaparis.net/actualite/news/maurilio-cacciatore-royaumont-11500/ Electro-cloître, une installation sonore électronique de Maurilio Cacciatore]. Italieaparis.net. Retrieved on October 18, 2011.</ref> [[Dan Sedgwick]], [[Marji Gere]], [[Nicholas Chase]]<ref name="nytimes1">Sulcas, Roslyn. (2008-11-17) [https://www.nytimes.com/2008/11/18/arts/dance/18wint.html Dance Review – 60x60 Dance – At the World Financial Center, an Express With No Delays]. NYTimes.com. Retrieved on October 18, 2011.</ref> [[Brad Decker]], Kevin Lewis<ref name="iwu">[http://www.iwu.edu/CurrentNews/newsrelease07/evt_Electroacoustic_1107.shtml Illinois Wesleyan: News]. Iwu.edu (November 27, 2007). Retrieved on October 18, 2011.</ref> [[Noah Meites]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://music.ucsc.edu/grad/dma/composition/currentstudents.html |title=DMA Students: Doctorate of Musical Arts in Composition at UCSC |publisher=Web.archive.org |date= |accessdate=2016-03-30 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090306183004/http://music.ucsc.edu/grad/dma/composition/currentstudents.html |archivedate=March 6, 2009 }}</ref> [[Mason Leiberman]],<ref name="bullardnews1">[http://www.bullardnews.com/news/2011-05-18/News/Brook_Hill_alum_makes_noise_in_music_world.html Brook Hill alum makes noise in music world | www.bullardnews.com | The Bullard Banner News] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110911111440/http://www.bullardnews.com/news/2011-05-18/News/Brook_Hill_alum_makes_noise_in_music_world.html |date=September 11, 2011 }}. www.bullardnews.com (May 18, 2011). A complete list of composers who participated in the 60x60 project can be found on the [http://www.VoxNovus.com/60x60/Composers.htm 60x60 website]
The 60x60 project is more than just a single performance. It is a venue where a large community of composers and sound artists come together to present their music. Each year after the call for works a Radio Request Extravaganza is held. This is a radio show where any work submitted to the project may be requested for airplay. Afterwards, a selection panels finds 60 works for the 60x60 International mix for that year; when 60 composers of a particular region or style are found an alternate mix is created to represent them. When this happens the project presents the alternate mix as well as the international mix in its concert season. After the project has presented the audio mixes, usually presented with an analog clock, 60x60 collaborates with an artist in a different media. A second performance season is held promoting the multimedia collaboration. In conjunction to the performances of the project a CD is made each year to represent the submissions sent to the project.
60x60 has been presented in various types of venues throughout the world from concert halls to classrooms; from contemporary museums to art galleries; from projections on building walls to installations in storefront windows; from large public atriums to bars and nightclubs. 60x60 uses "[[guerrilla]]" production tactics to bring it to the broadest audience possible. ==Multimedia collaboration== "Robert Voisey collected and culled 60 musical arrangements from many more submissions, all to inspire the performers and stimulate the audience." -Minute to Win It, Alison Sieloff<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.riverfronttimes.com/events/60x60-dance-1463658/ |title=60x60 Dance - Sheldon Concert Hall - St. Louis - Events |publisher=Web.archive.org |date=2011-10-06 |accessdate=2016-03-30 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111006032756/http://www.riverfronttimes.com/events/60x60-dance-1463658/ |archivedate=October 6, 2011 }}</ref>
Embracing its vision to reach a diverse audience 60x60 has collaborated with artists outside the acoustic medium to create multimedia performances. 60x60 has collaborated with experimental film makers, photographers, improvisational videographers, sculptors, choreographers and dancers. Some of the artists the project has worked with include [[Viv Moore]],<ref>60x60 Dance Toronto in Enwave Theater for NextSteps in Toronto Canada [http://www.harbourfrontcentre.com/blog/2014/10/sixty-perspectives-on-contemporary-dance-with-60x60/ ''Sixty perspectives on contemporary dance with 60×60''] October 14, 2014 / Anupa Mistry / NextSteps</ref> [[Hettie Barnhill]], [[Stephanie Bernard]], [[Andy Haspenpflug]], [[Justine Linnehan]], [[Sabrina Pena Young]], [[Adriana Pegorer]], [[Erin Bomboy]], [[Amiti Perry]],<ref>[http://mobile.dispatch.com/topic/3374-Features/articles/193733147 "Minute hand to sweep performers on, offstage"]. Amy Saunders, ''[[The Columbus Dispatch]]'' October 3, 2009</ref> [[Patrick Liddell]], [[Zlatko Ćosić]],<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20070927092045/http://www.stlmag.com/media/St-Louis-Magazine/August-2007/The-Projectionist/ ''"The Projectionist" ''] Stefene Russell ''[[St Louis Magazine]]'', August 2007</ref><ref>[http://www.stltoday.com/stltoday/lifestyle/stories.nsf/cooking/story/6E476CF366501815862573E5006F8738?OpenDocument ''Bosnian native cooks food that reminds him of home''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080208212228/http://www.stltoday.com/stltoday/lifestyle/stories.nsf/cooking/story/6E476CF366501815862573E5006F8738?OpenDocument |date=February 8, 2008 }}, Pat Eby, STLtoday.com / St. Louis Post-Dispatch, February 6, 2008</ref><ref>[http://www.riverfronttimes.com/2008-04-02/calendar/polyphony-spree/ ''Polyphony Spree'']. Paul Friswold Published on April 2, 2008 ''[[Riverfront Times]]''</ref> [[Jeramy Zimmerman]], [[Gisela Gamper]], [[Shimpei Takeda]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.shimpeitakeda.com/2004.htm |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070503161542/http://www.shimpeitakeda.com/2004.htm |archivedate=2007-05-03 |title=Shimpei Takeda |website=Web.archive.org |date= |accessdate=2016-03-30}}</ref> and [[Nick Zedd]].
===60x60 Dance=== 60x60 Dance is a collaboration pairing the 60 audio works with 60 different dances.<ref>{{cite web|last=Michelle |first=Candice |url=http://www.idanzcritixcorner.com/2009/11/dance-review-60x60-new-family-reunion.html |title=Dance Review: 60X60, A New Family Reunion |publisher=iDANZ Critix Corner |date=2009-11-19 |accessdate=2016-03-30}}</ref> Exactly like the audio performances, the 60 dances are performed continuously back to back for an hour synchronized with an analog clock. While the music of 60x60 Dance can be from any of the 60x60 mixes, the dancers and choreographers are pooled from the local area where the performance is being held. This creates a "grassroots" touring show which is community based utilizing the dancers from the immediate region. 60x60 Dance has had performances at churches, performance art spaces, art galleries, dance clubs, theaters, [[The Sheldon]], and the World Financial Center [[Winter Garden Atrium]]<ref>[http://turbulence.org/networked_music_review/2008/11/08/live-stage-60x60-from-arts-world-financial-center-new-york/ Networked Music Review – Live Stage: 60x60 Dance]. Turbulence.org. Retrieved on October 18, 2011.</ref> where it was described by ''[[The New York Times]]'' as a "masterpiece of organization"<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2008/11/18/arts/dance/18wint.html ''An Express Without and Delays'']. Roslyn Sulcas, ''The New York Times'', Published: November 17, 2008</ref>
*The first 60x60 Dance collaboration started in 2007 with a performance in Jan Hus Church and was directed with the choreographer [[Jeramy Zimmerman]] of in collaboration with [[Robert Voisey]].<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20081225174340/http://www.arts-electric.org/stories/081211_voisey.html ''"Rob Voisey: 60x60 Dance"''] Suzanne Thorpe, [[Electronic Music Foundation]], December 21, 2008</ref> *In 2009, 60x60 Dance had its debuts in Ohio, Kansas City, St. Louis,<ref>[http://newmusiccircle.org/2009/11/08/robert-voisey-60x60-dance/ Robert Voisey 60×60 DANCE – New Music Circle]. Newmusiccircle.org (November 8, 2009). Retrieved on October 18, 2011.</ref> and Montreal.<ref>[http://finearts.concordia.ca/newsandevents/events/60x60-dance.php 60X60 Dance, Canadian debut – Faculty of Fine Arts – Concordia University – Montreal, Quebec, Canada]. Finearts.concordia.ca (December 4, 2009). Retrieved on October 18, 2011.</ref> *Choreographer Amiti Perry organized 60x60 Dance to Columbus, Ohio at the Wall Street dance club.<ref>[http://www.columbusalive.com/live/content/features/stories/2009/10/01/ca_ar_60x60-dance.html Alive] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110727143004/http://www.columbusalive.com/live/content/features/stories/2009/10/01/ca_ar_60x60-dance.html |date=July 27, 2011 }}. Columbusalive.com (September 30, 2009). Retrieved on October 18, 2011.</ref> This was the first time 60x60 Dance was performed outside of New York City. Some of the artists included Columbus Movement Movement, (cm2 – pronounced "cm squared")<ref>[https://archive.is/20120913164257/http://www.theotherpaper.com/articles/2009/10/02/arts/doc4ac4b76b6f314685115350.txt "Performance art for the sound-bite culture"] Lyndsey Teter [[The Other Paper]], Published: Thursday, October 1, 2009</ref> *In Kansas City, Kansas and St. Louis, Missouri, Amiti Perry and Erin Bomboy organized dancers and debuted 60x60 dance in those cities in conjunction with [[Robert Voisey]] at [[Vox Novus]]. 60x60 Dance embraces the same philosophy for its dance performances as it does with its music productions. It is specifically designed to promote and expose to audiences around the world to many different choreographers and dancers with the vast wealth of vary styles and aesthetics that present day dance has to offer. A few of the choreographers who have participated in 60x60 Dance include: [[Germaul Barnes]], [[Hettie Barnhill]], [[Rob Bettmann]],<ref name="ovationtv1">[http://community.ovationtv.com/_60x60-What-is-Dance/blog/229910/16878.html 60x60 – What is Dance? – Ovation Blog post] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111009120204/http://community.ovationtv.com/_60x60-What-is-Dance/blog/229910/16878.html |date=October 9, 2011 }}. ===60x60 Video=== 60x60 Video is an hour of video which is synchronized to the audio mixes of 60x60. 60x60 Video has collaborated with video artists, experimental filmmakers, and VJ's to pair the 60 different audio compositions with video. * In 2012 [[Zlatko Cosic]], [[Patrick Liddell]], and [[Sabrina Pena Young]] returned to collaborate with 60x60 to take 20 minutes each of the 60x60 (2012) presenters mix and create video in a joined effort. * [[Zlatko Cosic]] also curated a film with many film students from the Digital Studio at [[Washington University in St. Louis]] using the 60x60 EMM Mix (EMM standing for [[Electronic Music Midwest]])<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.samfoxschool.wustl.edu/events/films/8927 |title=Calendar | Sam Fox School |publisher=Samfoxschool.wustl.edu |date=2013-05-01 |accessdate=2014-06-05}}</ref> * [[Sabrina Pena Young]] created video to the first Athena mix that she herself was the audio coordinator for and debuted. * In 2010, [[PiSSOFFART]] presented for the [[Sanguine mix]], "[[DAiLY CUT's]]" created by [[Pedro Pinheiro]] using 60 days of his video captures from casual locations at Barcelona (Spain) and Marraquech (Marocco). The video promoter was [[Daniel Dominguez Teruel]] and the screening premiere was at B-Movie Hamburg (Germany). * [[Patrick Liddell]] returns to 60x60<ref>[http://www.ontologist.us/label/?label=vox%20novus : ontologist :] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120113104656/http://www.ontologist.us/label/?label=vox%20novus |date=January 13, 2012 }}. Ontologist.us. Retrieved on October 18, 2011.</ref> to create video for 7 different 2010 mixes of the 60x60 project: the UnTwelve mix, Burgundy Mix, Crimson Mix, Magenta Mix, Sanguine mix, Scarlet mix, and the Vermillion mix.<ref name="whatsup">[http://whatsup-magazine.com/2010/11/17/minifest-a-weekend-of-musical-miniatures/ Minifest: A weekend of musical miniatures | What's Up! Magazine] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110718035216/http://www.whatsup-magazine.com/2010/11/17/minifest-a-weekend-of-musical-miniatures/ |date=July 18, 2011 }}. Whatsup-magazine.com. Retrieved on October 18, 2011.</ref> Liddell's collaboration with 60x60 has been screened at Bellingham's Minifest,<ref name="Minifest"/><ref name="whatsup"/> and the 2010 Outsound New Music Summit<ref>[http://www.beyondchron.org/news/index.php?itemid=8305 San Francisco's Alternative Online Daily News » The 2010 Outsound New Music Summit]. BeyondChron. Retrieved on October 18, 2011.</ref><ref>[http://www.outsound.org/summit/10/schedule_details10.html The Outsound Music Summit 2010 Schedule]. Outsound.org. Nmnmne.org. === 60x60 Images === 60x60 Images is a 60x60 multimedia collaboration based on fine art works that are 60 centimeters in length and 60 centimeters in width and then paired with a 60-second audio work in an art installation or performance. the project first started in Teatro Nuovo Giovanni in Udine, Italy with an idea by [[Vittorio Vella]], and [[Francesca Agostinelli]]<ref>[http://www.connessomagazine.it/60x60-images-contemporanea-2010 60x60 Images @ Contemporanea 2010 – Eventi Udine]. Connessomagazine.it. Retrieved on October 18, 2011.</ref> and [[Taukay Edizioni Musicali]]<ref>[http://www.taukay.it/en/archive/cont2010/2010_12.html TEM – Taukay Edizioni Musicali] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120315161126/http://www.taukay.it/en/archive/cont2010/2010_12.html |date=March 15, 2012 }}. Taukay.it. Retrieved on October 18, 2011.</ref> The project has since be reproduced in Mexico and in Cincinnati, Ohio.<ref>[http://www.taukay.it/en/archive/60x60_images_cincinnati.html TEM – Taukay Edizioni Musicali] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120315161137/http://www.taukay.it/en/archive/60x60_images_cincinnati.html |date=March 15, 2012 }}. Taukay.it. Retrieved on October 18, 2011.</ref><ref>[http://www.upi.com/Top_News/Local/2011/02/15/60-X-60-Images-A-Unique-Presentation-of-Visual-and-Audio/25-d7f55e474c Local News]. UPI.com (October 14, 2011). Retrieved on October 18, 2011.</ref><ref>[http://www.undo.net/it/mostra/115029 60x60 Images Art academy of Cincinnati]. Undo.net. Retrieved on October 18, 2011.</ref>
==Radio Request Extravaganza== In the beginning of each 60x60 concert season, the project holds a Radio Request Extravaganza. This is an all request radio show where composers and their fans call into the hosting radio station request works that have been submitted to the 60x60 project that year. Different new music radio programs and radio stations host the Extravaganza. In the past the 60x60 Radio Request Extravaganza has been hosted on [[Relevant Tones]] hosted by [[Seth Boustead]] on [[WFMT]] in Chicago,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.wfmt.com/relevanttones/2012/10/06/60x60-electronic-music-midwest/ |title=60×60 Electronic Music Midwest | Relevant Tones | 98.7WFMT |publisher=Blogs.wfmt.com |date= |accessdate=2014-06-05}}</ref> [[Afternoon New Music]] on [[WKCR]] New York, New York; [[Martian Gardens]] Radio Show on [[WMUA]] Amherst, Massachusetts;<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.masslive.com/weblogs/martian/index.ssf?/mtlogs/mass_martian/archives/2005_06.html|title=Real-Time News, Sports, Entertainment, and Life in Western Massachusetts - MassLive.com|publisher=|accessdate=March 30, 2016}}</ref> [[Kalvos & Damian New Music Bazaar]] on [[WGDR]] Plainfield, Vermont;<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kalvos.org/paststuf.html |title=Kalvos & Damian's New Music Bazaar: Recent Past Notices |website=Kalvos.org |date= |accessdate=2016-04-01}}</ref> Foldover, on [[WOBC-FM]] Oberlin, Ohio; and Sculpted Word on WBAR in New York, New York.<ref>[http://www.voxnovus.com/60x60/Events.htm 60x60 Events and Performances]. Voxnovus.com. Retrieved on October 18, 2011.</ref>
For the 10th Annual 60x60, Jim Cross on ''What's Next?'' on [[WGDR]] hosted a 10-hour marathon of the 60x60 Radio Requset Extravaganza<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wgdr.org/60x60-radio-extravaganza-archive/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130109085829/http://www.wgdr.org/60x60-radio-extravaganza-archive/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2013-01-09 |title=60×60 Radio Extravaganza Archive | |publisher=Wgdr.org |date= |accessdate=2014-06-05 }}</ref>
==Alternate Mixes== The project uses [[grassroots]] ideology to grow and promote its mission to expose [[Electroacoustic music|electroacoustic]] music.<ref>[http://media.www.thepinelog.com/media/storage/paper954/news/2008/02/04/Entertainment/Sfa-Students.Composition.To.Be.Featured.In.60x60.Concert.Tuesday-3186230.shtml ''SFA student's composition to be featured in 60X60 concert Tuesday'']{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Julianna Backer, The Pine Log, February 4, 2008</ref> When the project receives more than 60 compositions of a particular theme or from a particular region, the project creates a themed mix to be represent that subsection of its submissions.<ref>[http://www.voxnovus.com/60x60/Mission.htm 60x60 Mission]. VoxNovus.com. Retrieved on October 18, 2011.</ref> The project has created many different mixes besides its main "International Mix" which is a representative selection of the entire submissions made to the project for that year. === 360 degrees of 60x60 === 360 degrees of 60x60 was a special project of 60x60 created specifically for the [[International Computer Music Conference]] at [[Stony Brook University]] in 2010.<ref>[http://vagueterrain.net/content/2010/05/2010-international-computer-music-conference-preview 2010 International Computer Music Conference Preview (NYC)] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100612054352/http://vagueterrain.net/content/2010/05/2010-international-computer-music-conference-preview |date=June 12, 2010 }}. Vague Terrain (April 12, 2010). Retrieved on October 18, 2011.</ref><ref>[http://www.mobius.org/events/360-degress-60x60-emf 360 degrees of 60x60 @EMF] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110727091624/http://www.mobius.org/events/360-degress-60x60-emf |date=July 27, 2011 }}. Mobius. Retrieved on October 18, 2011.</ref> ICMC 2010 was dubbed the "RED" edition as an acronym for research, education, and discovery and the 60x60 mixes were named shades of red to commemorate it.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.icmc2010.org/ |title=Home Improvement | |publisher=Icmc2010.org |date=2013-11-21 |accessdate=2014-06-05}}</ref> The "RED" Mixes are a special 60x60 project containing 6 different mixes with 360 different one-minute audio pieces by different composers. Each of the 6 different 1 hour 60x60 mixes are named a shade of red titling the mix: including the Burgundy Mix,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://ccrma.stanford.edu/events/60x60-burgundy-mix-concert |title=60x60 Burgundy Mix Concert | CCRMA |publisher=Ccrma.stanford.edu |date= |accessdate=2014-06-05}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=United Kingdom |url=http://www.city.ac.uk/events/2010/may/sound-studio-60x60-burgundy-mix |title=Sound Studio: 60x60 Burgundy Mix | City University London |publisher=City.ac.uk |date=2010-05-12 |accessdate=2014-06-05}}</ref> Crimson Mix, Magenta Mix, Sanguine Mix, Scarlet Mix, and the Vermilion Mix.<ref>[http://www.icmc2010.org/program.html ICMC Program] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100728093857/http://www.icmc2010.org/program.html |date=July 28, 2010 }}. Icmc2010.org. Retrieved on October 18, 2011.</ref> The 60x60 "RED" mixes have received close to 100 performances in around the world. [[Patrick Liddell]] created video for all 6 hours of 360 degrees of 60x60.
===Athena Mix=== The Athena mix was created in 2011 and it contains works only from women composers.<ref name="60x60.com"/> The mix was named after the [[Athena Festival]] and was "macro-composed" by [[Sabrina Peña Young]] The first all women 60x60 mix contained the notable composers: [[Eve Beglarian]], [[Joan Labarbara]], [[Annea Lockwood]], [[Pauline Oliveros]], [[Maggi Payne]], [[Alice Shields]], [[Daria Semegen]], and [[Laurie Spiegel]]. "The 60×60 Athena Mix accomplishes much in its showcase of talented women from a global perspective. The 60×60 Athena Mix is a creative way to celebrate International Women's Day, a day set aside to celebrate the accomplishments and achievement of women around the world."<ref>{{cite web|author=Sabrina Peña Young |url=http://www.easyeartraining.com/2013/03/06/open-your-ears-to-60x60/ |title=Open Your Ears to 60x60 |publisher=Easy Ear Training |date= |accessdate=2016-04-01}}</ref>
In 2012 [[Sabrina Peña Young]] coordinated another Athena Mix of all women composers to contribute to the 60x60 projects decade celebration. The concert performed on [[International Woman's Day]] on Friday 8 March 2013 at [[Harris Museum & Art Gallery]] in Lancashire, United Kingdom.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://thetwohats.co.uk/?p=3763 |title=60 x 60 Athena Mix – Sounding Out the Harris Museum & Art Gallery |publisher=The Two Hats |date=2013-03-26 |accessdate=2014-06-05}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Patricia |url=http://lanarts.org/the-60x60-athena-mix-2012/#more-2583 |title=The 60×60 Athena Mix (2012) | Lancashire Artists Network |publisher=Lanarts.org |date=2013-03-30 |accessdate=2014-06-05}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://soundnetwork.org.uk/?q=node/457 |title=Sounding Out The Harris Museum, Preston |publisher=SoundNetwork |date= |accessdate=2014-06-05}}</ref>
===Canada Mix=== The 60x60 Canada mix contains works from composers from and currently living in Canada. The 60x60 Canada mix started in 2008 with [[Eldad Tsabary]] as the macro-composer/music coordinator and co-producer. Two Canadian mixes were created in 2008: a concert version<ref name="CESSA">[http://cessa.music.concordia.ca/wiki/pmwiki.php?n=EuCue.C60x60iConcertMix CESSA – ÉuCuE – 60x60 – Concert Mix] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110706173641/http://cessa.music.concordia.ca/wiki/pmwiki.php?n=EuCue.C60x60iConcertMix |date=July 6, 2011 }}. Cessa.music.concordia.ca (September 11, 2001). Retrieved on October 18, 2011.</ref> which was premiered at [[Concordia University (Quebec)|Concordia University]] as part of the [[ÉuCuE]] performance series<ref name="CESSA"/> and a "SONUS Gallery" mix that was published in the CEC's ([[Canadian Electroacoustic Community]]) electronic journal of electroacoustics, ''eContact!''<ref>Eldad Tsabary, "[http://cec.sonus.ca/econtact/11_2/sonusgallery_tsabary.html [Sonus Gallery] 60x60 Canada 2008–09]," ''eContact! 11.2 — Figures canadiennes (2) / Canadian Figures (2)'' ([[Canadian Electroacoustic Community|CEC]], July 2009).</ref> The 60x60 (2011) Canada Mix was presented at the 5th Toronto Electroacoustic Symposium (TES) a co-presentation of the [[Canadian Electroacoustic Community]] (CEC) and [[New Adventures in Sound Art]] (NAISA).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://cec.sonus.ca/events/TES/2011/index.html |title=CEC - Toronto Electroacoustic Symposium 2011 |publisher=Cec.sonus.ca |date=2011-08-13 |accessdate=2014-06-05}}</ref>
===Environmental Mix=== The 60x60 (2012) Environmental mix is the first 60x60 mix to include work entirely with the theme of nature and the environment both rural and urban. Composers from over a dozen countries are represented, and pieces including everything from field recordings at unique locations to sounds from outer space, from insect and animal sounds (yes, birds and bees, and also various pets) to urban noises, to expressions of the feelings people have for the places they inhabit, to lots of water sounds, will be heard. This mix received its premiere in California March 2012 as part of the project's decade celebration.<ref name="ocice1"/><ref name="Soka.edu"/> Robert Voisey is the audio coordinator for the 60x60 (2012) Environmental Mix.<ref>{{cite web|author=Robert Voisey |url=http://www.60x60.com/2012_Environmental_Mix.htm |title=60x60 Environmental Mix |publisher=60x60.com |date= |accessdate=2014-06-05}}</ref>
===The UnTwelve Mix=== The 60x60 Untwelve Mix contains 60 second audio works with tonal systems that go beyond the traditional [[tonality]] in Western music and [[twelve tone]] music. Started in 2010 in collaboration with [http://www.untwelve.org UnTwelve], the UnTwelve mix captures the work of composers in the same format as the classic 60x60 concert, however, the emphasis is on pieces whose pitch content is of interest in that it goes beyond the bounds of the traditional 12-tone equal tempered system.<ref>[http://www.untwelve.org/60x60collaboration.html microtonal music concerts for Chicago and the midwest]. UnTwelve. Retrieved on October 18, 2011.</ref> [[Aaron Krister Johnson]] is the "macro-composer" or music coordinator of the 60x60 UnTwelve Mix and co-produced the mix with [[Robert Voisey]] at [[Vox Novus]].<ref>[http://www.voxnovus.com/60x60/2010_UnTwelve_Mix.htm 60x60 UnTwelve Mix]. Voxnovus.com. Retrieved on October 18, 2011.</ref> was The UnTwelve mix had a proto-premiere in Istanbul, Turkey, on April 14, and the official premiere was April 27, 2010, at the Museum of Contemporary Art in Chicago.<ref name="Columbia Chronicle"/> It has since had performances in Kansas City, Missouri (July 23, 2010), Charlestown, Massachusetts (June 9, 2010) and is slated to have a performance at [[Slippery Rock University]], Slippery Rock, PA, on October 7, 2010, and a Chicago repeat performance on October 20, 2010, with video art by [[Patrick Liddell]]. The 60x60 UnTwelve Mix also has had several performances in Boston at Mobius, "Signs of Our 60 Times 60 II"<ref>{{cite web|author=<!---->By Matt Parish |url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/arts/music/2013/06/06/beloved-studio-prepares-for-fourth-starlabfest-union-square/OpQYHq7JtjdSK0ijwWokTN/story.html |title=Beloved studio prepares for fourth Starlabfest in Union Square - Music |publisher=The Boston Globe |date=2013-06-06 |accessdate=2014-06-05}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/arts/2014/05/16/boston-area-list/nPuyLoAWucQDpl9ik2HUHM/story.html |title=Boston Globe |publisher=Boston Globe |date=2014-05-16 |accessdate=2014-06-05}}</ref>
===The 5.1 Surround Sound Mix=== 60x60 in collaboration with [[Harvestworks]], curator [[Hans Tammen]] created the first 60x60 mix utilizing [[5.1 Surround Sound]] premiered at the Harvestworks studios in New York City. Receiving 160 submissions the 60x60 Surround Sound Mix exemplifies the variety possible with the 5.1 speakerref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20100728093857/http://www.icmc2010.org/program.html ICMC Program]. Icmc2010.org. Retrieved on October 18, 2011. configuration, "this exhibit is about multichannel sound, we chose a few works that are exemplary in terms of [[Spatial music|spatialization]] of sounds, while most others employ these means in a more subtle way. Everything you can do beyond stereo with 5.1 channels is there: 5.1, 5.0, 4.1 and 4.0. There is even a 3.1 work, it does spatialization solely with the center and rear speakers." -Curator Hans Tammen<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.harvestworks.org/may-16-voxnovus-60x60-surround-sound-works/|title=[May 16] VoxNovus 60×60 Surround Sound Works|work=Harvestworks Digital Media Arts Center|accessdate=March 30, 2016}}</ref>
==Macro vs Micro==
===Micro=== 60x60 is a collection of miniatures or "signature" works from 60 different composers/sound artists. Each work is 60 seconds (or less) in length and are sequenced in order to fit neatly within each minute of the hour; each new minute is a different piece from a different artist.
<blockquote>60x60 ensures that no individual piece of music lasts too long--you'd be hard pressed to find someone who couldn't sit through one minute of music that didn't appeal to them.<ref>{{cite web|author=Paul W |url=http://fcm07.blogspot.com/2012/11/the-case-for-shorter-pieces.html |title=The case for shorter pieces |publisher=Fcm07.blogspot.com |date=2012-11-13 |accessdate=2014-06-05}}</ref></blockquote>
60x60 creates a unique challenge for the composer/sound artist to express themselves in the concise time frame of one minute. Besides that one restriction, artists are free and specifically encouraged to express themselves in any way that they wish.
<blockquote>Voisey states, "A minute can be plenty of time to express a whole gamut of imaginative sounds and movements, or it can be a challenge, forcing the artist to isolate what is most important in his/her work." <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chattanoogan.com/2013/1/23/242839/UTC-Music-Department-Presents-60x60.aspx |title=UTC Music Department Presents "60x60" Monday - 01/23/2013 |publisher=Chattanoogan.com |date= |accessdate=2014-06-05}}</ref></blockquote>
===Macro=== 60x60 is much more than a collection of short works played one after another. The entire hour of 60 on-minute works is specifically curated or composed as a one-hour-long "macro-composition" containing the 60 works. All 60x60 mixes are put together by artists to create an artistic hour for audiences to enjoy.
<blockquote>60×60 involves macro-composition, which Voisey describes as, "the act of creating a musical work incorporating several fully formed ideas or complete works." And just as "ballet, operas, and movies are all perfect examples of many artists contributing to a greater artistic whole orchestrated by the 'macro-artist'," <ref>[http://www.newmusicbox.org/articles/the-compositional-collective-crowdsourcing-and-collaboration-in-the-digital-age/ ''The Compositional Collective: Crowdsourcing and Collaboration in the Digital Age'' ] By [[Sabrina Peña Young]], [[New Music Box]], September 12, 2012</ref></blockquote>
As the creator and leader of 60x60, [[Robert Voisey]] has created and "macro-composed" the most mixes and is responsible for the "main" annual 60x60 International mix since 2003. He has put together several other 60x60 mixes including: Pacific Rim mixes, Midwest mixes, 2006 New York Minutes Mix, Munich Mix, Electronic Music Midwest Mix, Evolution Mixes, the UK Mix, the Burgundy Mix, the Magenta Mix, the Sanguine Mix and the Scarlet Mix.
Several other composers have put together different mixes. [[Eldad Tsabary]] has been responsible for putting together the Canadian Mixes as well as the Vermillion mix and the Order of Magnitude Mix. [[Aaron Krister Johnson]] was responsible for the UnTwelve Mix and the Crimson Mix. [[Sabina Pena Young]] was responsible for putting together the Athena mix. [[Robert Ratcliffe]] for the Presenters Mix. [[Melissa Grey]] for the 2012 New York Minutes Mix. [[James Finnerty]] for the 2012 Canadian Mix. [[Thomas Gerwin]] for the 2012 Voice Mix.
==Past, present and future== There is a history of electroacoustic "shorts." In 1982, [[Elliott Sharp]] created an album of shorts called "State of the Union" to accompany an issue of Zone Magazine.<ref name="newmusicbox">[http://www.newmusicbox.org/page.nmbx?id=61tp00 "Got a Minute? A Few Words on Music in 60 Seconds or Less"] -[[Robert Voisey]] with additional reporting, Frank J. Oteri, "[[NewMusicBox]]" May 1, 2004</ref> In the mid-1980s when the Association pour la création et recherches en électroacoustique de Québec (Acreq) launched an annual competition for "Electroclips", most pieces being between one and three minutes in duration. In the late 1980s, [[Jean-François Denis]] and [[Claude Schryer]] of Montreal, commissioned 25 three-minute pieces for the "25 instantanés électroacoustiques", Électro Clips, published by empreinted DIGITALes in 1990, IMED 9004. In 1998, [[Larry Polansky]] created "The Frog Peak Collaborations Project" a double album of shorts based on an audio sound file from [[Chris Mann (composer)|Chris Mann]].<ref name="newmusicbox"/>
In the tradition of projects before it 60x60 has inspired several electroacoustic miniature projects such as [[David Morneau]]'s 60x365, where he blogged a 60-second composition once every day for a year.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://60x365.com/labels/collage.html |title=daily new music |publisher=60x365 |date= |accessdate=2014-06-05}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://WWW.5of4.com/about.html |title=|| David Morneau || 5 of 4 Music || |publisher=Www.5of4.com |date= |accessdate=2014-06-05}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ovguide.com/david-morneau-9202a8c04000641f8000000008bdef96# |title=David Morneau Video | Interviews |publisher=Ovguide.com |date=1975-05-02 |accessdate=2014-06-05}}</ref>
And the miniature form continues in many other projects such as [[Jon Nelson (artist)|Jon Nelson]]'s 50/50 project.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.some-assembly-required.net/5050/ |title=About |publisher=Some Assembly Required |date= |accessdate=2014-06-05}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.blog.some-assembly-required.net/2009/01/5050-call-for-artists.html |title=Some Assembly Required: 50/50: Call For Artists |publisher=Blog.some-assembly-required.net |date=2009-01-25 |accessdate=2014-06-05}}</ref>

revision.text:
{{Infobox planet | minorplanet = yes | name = 65803 Didymos | background = #FFC2E0 | image = | image_size = | caption = | discovery_ref =   | discovered = 11 April 1996 | discoverer = [[Spacewatch]] | discovery_site = [[Kitt Peak National Observatory|Kitt Peak National Obs.]] | mpc_name = (65803) Didymos | alt_names = 1996 GT | pronounced = | named_after = Greek word for "[[Twin]]"  | mp_category = [[Near-Earth object|NEO]]{{·}}[[Potentially hazardous object|PHA]]
[[Apollo asteroid|Apollo]] {{·}}[[Amor asteroid|Amor]]  | orbit_ref =   | epoch = 4 September 2017 ([[Julian day|JD]] 2458000.5) | uncertainty = 0 | observation_arc = 21.04 yr (7,686 days) | aphelion = 2.2760 [[Astronomical unit|AU]] | perihelion = 1.0133 AU | semimajor = 1.6446 AU | eccentricity = 0.3839 | period = 2.11 [[Julian year (astronomy)|yr]] (770 days) | mean_anomaly = 204.19[[Degree (angle)|°]] | mean_motion = {{Deg2DMS|0.4673|sup=ms}} / day | inclination = 3.4083° | asc_node = 73.209° | arg_peri = 319.30° | moid = 0.0404 AU{{·}}15.7 [[Lunar distance (astronomy)|LD]] | satellites = 1  | dimensions = {{val|0.78|0.08}} km
0.800 km {{small|(taken)}} | rotation = {{val|2.2593|0.0002}} [[Hour|h]]
{{val|2.26|0.01}} h | albedo = 0.15 {{small|(derived)}} | spectral_type = [[SMASS classification|SMASS]] = Xk {{·}}[[X-type asteroid|X]]  | abs_magnitude = 18.0{{·}}18.16{{·}}{{val|18.16|0.03}} }} '''65803 Didymos''', provisional designation {{mp|1996 GT}}, is a sub-kilometer [[asteroid]] and synchronous [[Binary asteroid|binary system]], classified as [[potentially hazardous asteroid]] and [[near-Earth object]] of both the [[Apollo asteroid|Apollo]] and [[Amor asteroid|Amor group]]. It is the target of the proposed ''[[AIDA (mission)|AIDA]]'' asteroid-mission. The asteroid was discovered in 1996, by the [[Spacewatch]] survey at [[Kitt Peak National Observatory|Kitt Peak]], and its small 170-meter [[minor-planet moon]] was discovered in 2003. Due to its binary nature, it was then [[Asteroid#Naming|named]] "Didymos", the Greek word for [[twin]]. == Discovery == ''Didymos'' was discovered on 11 April 1996, by the University of Arizona [[Steward Observatory]]'s [[Spacewatch]] survey using its 0.9-meter telescope at [[Kitt Peak National Observatory]] in Arizona, United States. The binary nature of the asteroid was discovered by others; suspicions of binarity first arose in [[Goldstone Deep Space Communications Complex|Goldstone]] delay-[[Doppler radar|Doppler]] echoes, and these were confirmed with an optical [[lightcurve]] analysis, along with [[Arecibo Observatory|Arecibo]] radar imaging on 23 November 2003. == Orbital characteristics == ''Didymos'' orbits the Sun at a distance of 1.0–2.3 [[Astronomical unit|AU]] once every 2 years and 1 month (770 days). Its orbit has an [[orbital eccentricity|eccentricity]] of 0.38 and an [[orbital inclination|inclination]] of 3[[Degree (angle)|°]] with respect to the [[ecliptic]]. Its approach to Earth in November 2003, was especially close with a distance of 7.18 million km; it will not come that near until November 2123, with a distance of 5.9 million km. It also passes very close to Mars: 4.69 million km in 2144. == Physical characteristics == In the [[SMASS classification]], ''Didymos'' is an Xk-type asteroid, which transitions from the [[X-type asteroid|X-type]] to the rare [[K-type asteroid]]s. It [[rotation period|rotates]] rapidly, with a period of 2.26 hours and a brightness variation of 0.08 [[Magnitude (astronomy)|magnitude]] ({{small|[[LCDB quality code|U=3/3]]}}), which indicates that the body has a nearly spheroidal shape. === Satellite === ''Didymos'' is a [[binary asteroid]] with a satellite in its orbit. The [[minor-planet moon]], provisionally designated {{mp|S/2003 (65803) 1}}, has an [[orbital period]] of 11.9 hours.{{efn|name=lightcurve-plot-PDO}} It measures approximately {{val|0.17|0.03}} kilometers in diameter compared to {{val|0.75|0.1}} kilometers for its primary (a mean-diameter-ratio of 0.22). It has been informally named "Didymoon"."[http://phys.org/news/2015-06-telescopes-focus-esa-asteroid-mission.html Telescopes focus on target of ESA's asteroid mission]" at phys.org (30 June 2015) == Naming == This [[minor planet]] was named "Didymos", Greek for "twin", due to its binary nature. The name was suggested by the discoverer, University of Arizona Lunar and Planetary Lab astronomer Joseph L. "Joe" Montani, who made the naming proposal to the International Astronomical Union after the binary nature of the object was detected. The approved naming citation was published on 13 July 2004 ({{small|[[Minor Planet Circulars|M.P.C.]] 52326}}). The moon's nickname, "Didymoon", remains unofficial. == Proposed exploration == ''Didymos'' was the target of the proposed unmanned [[AIDA (mission)|Asteroid Impact & Deflection Assessment (AIDA) mission]], a cancelled collaboration between [[European Space Agency|ESA]] and [[NASA]]. After the cancellation, NASA announced it would proceed with the impactor portion of the mission, called [[Double Asteroid Redirection Test|''DART'']]. The NASA mission is intended to test whether a spacecraft impact could successfully deflect an asteroid on a collision course with Earth. ''DART'' will be the first spacecraft to intentionally target an asteroid known to have a [[minor-planet moon]] ([[243 Ida]] was visited by the [[Galileo spacecraft]] but its moon was a surprise). ''Didymos'' is the most easily reachable asteroid of its size from Earth, requiring a [[delta-v|delta-''v'']] of only 5.1 km/s for a spacecraft to rendezvous, compared to 6.0 km/s to reach the [[Moon]].{{cite web | year = 2010 | url = http://echo.jpl.nasa.gov/~lance/delta_v/delta_v.rendezvous.html | title = Delta-v for spacecraft rendezvous with all known near-Earth asteroids | accessdate = 2010-10-07}} ''DART'' will be launched in December of 2020 for an impact in October 2022.{{cite web | year = 2018 | url = https://www.nasa.gov/planetarydefense/dart | title = Double Asteroid Redirection Test (DART) Mission | accessdate = 2018-06-29}} == See also == * [[List of asteroids visited by spacecraft]] == Notes == {{notelist|refs= {{efn|name=lightcurve-plot-PDO|1=[http://www.minorplanetobserver.com/pdolc/A65803_2003.HTM Lightcurve plots] of 65803 Didymos, Palmer Divide Observatory, [[Brian D. Warner|B. D. Warner]]}} }} == References == {{reflist|30em|refs= {{cite web |type = 2017-04-27 last obs. |title = JPL Small-Body Database Browser: 65803 Didymos (1996 GT) |url = revision.text:
{{unreferenced|date=November 2014}} [[Image:ANTI logo.png|thumb|ANTI - Contemporary Art Festival -logo.]] '''ANTI – Contemporary Art Festival''' presents site-specific [[contemporary art]] covering all artistic forms from [[sculpture]] and [[environmental art]] to dance, [[live art]] and [[performance]]. The yearly festival is held in [[Kuopio]], [[Finland]]. The first ANTI Festival was organised in 2002 by The Arts Council of [[Northern Savonia]]. The ANTI – Contemporary Art Festival Association was established in 2005 to coordinate the festival.
With an emphasis on performance, ANTI has established itself as Finland’s foremost presenter of live art while also showcasing new developments in [[Sonic art|sonic]] and [[visual art]]s. Site-specific and time based works take place in public spaces, on streets, in office buildings, parks, shopping-centres and other privately owned sites, depending on the festival’s theme and the nature of the works. The festival programme consists of artworks created by invited artists and artists selected by an open proposal process.
ANTI means ”gift” in Finnish. Therefore, it is very appropriate that the artworks which are presented are free of charge. There is a small fee only for the seminars, artists’ talks and workshops. The ANTI Festival wants to make art more accessible for everybody. People who usually don’t gravitate towards art may become participant viewers of artworks by chance.
24.9.2013 ANTI – Contemporary Art Festival launched a new international art award ANTI Festival International Prize for Live Art which was awarded for the first time in 2014.
==Themes==
'''2003'''
In year 2002 works were presented for example in a [[hair salon]], a [[gas station]] and in a [[nursing home]]. Main artists of the festival were butch artist Saga Kobayashi from Japan and Live Art artists Eve Dent and [[Kira O'Reilly]] from [[England]].
'''2004'''
International programme included artists from many countries such as [[Great Britain]], Canada, [[United States of America]], Germany, Japan and [[Netherlands]]. During four days there were 17 performances. One of them was Will Kwan's (CA) performative lecture in [[University of Kuopio]] which was mentioned in media as well as [[Jennifer Nelson (artist)|Jennifer Nelson]]'s (US) and Glen Redpath's (CA) work The Race. The Race was held in local super market where it brought running competition and consuming hysteria of Friday afternoon together.
'''2005'''
Theme of the year was time. The theme was crystallized by [[Charles Landry]] who said: ”It is important that a city does not wipe out its memory”.
'''2006'''
Some place might make you laugh. Some place will make you think. Somewhere you will not find art at all. You will walk through the city with a headset on. You will breath the same air with the artist. Somewhere you perhaps will feel strange pleasure. You will not even dare to enter somewhere. Somewhere you might get shocked. You may discover a slight disorder.
There were 17 artists from all over the world giving their performances in Kuopio City Hall, Väinölänniemi Tennis Court, Youth Center 44, Hotel Puijonsarvi, Huuhanmäki Observatory, Cinema Maxim, an empty property on Tasavallankatu, balcony of the Carlson department store, [[Kuopio Airport|Kuopio airport]], [[Savonia University of Applied Sciences]], Health Professions Kuopio, an apartment mediated by the real estate agency Huoneistokeskus and the office of Reijo Kela.
'''2007'''
For the 2007 edition of the festival a community college, a [[skateboarding]] park, the pages of a city newspaper, a late-night grill, a children’s playground and an entire island were negotiated by an international program of artists. One of the most attractive works of the year was the vacuum cleaner’s One Hundred Thousand Pieces of Possibility where the artist gave away 1000 euros in 1 cent pieces. Claire Blundell Jones’s work Introducing Tumbleweed to the Finnish Landscape was also well noticed in media.
'''2008'''
For ANTI 2008 Kuopio's residents opened their homes to audiences and host works made for domestic space. Other projects took place in a sports stadium, on a public stage, across the network of city streets and on, and under, the [[Rönö]] bridge.
'''2009'''
In year 2009 the theme of ANTI was walking. For example, Vincent Chevalier (CA) traveled from one place to another walking along a 2-metre length of red carpet by which he gave himself The Red Carpet Treatment. Tim Knowles (UK) in term set off walking and were guided solely by the wind. For this piece he had created a wind vane mounted to a helmet.
'''2010'''
This edition of ANTI concentrated on how artists working with writing and language navigate, read and inhabit the city.
'''2011'''
2011 was year of celebration since it was 10th ANTI Festival. There were pieces presented by artists from [[Great Britain]], United States, Canada, Belgium and France. In the programme there was for example Blast Theory’s Rider Spoke which was a work for cyclists who explored the city by bike, looked for places to hide recorded messages and found digital treasures others have hidden, the choir conducted by Heidi Fast and a balloon piece by Gaëtan Rusquet. The festival culminated with Mammalian Diving Reflex’s The Children’s Choice Awards where the only opinions that mattered were those of the kids.
'''2012'''
This year the ANTI – Contemporary Art Festival programme worked on the themes of man's relationship with nature and the connection between sexuality and the body as well as the natural state of the human body. The festival took over public spaces in Kuopio for the 11th time. And not just in the town — the Luonnon ANTI programme set up camp on the island of Karhunsaari as well. A weekend-long artwork and workshop programme were planned especially with children in mind.
'''2013'''
As usual, the ANTI Festival offered unexpected encounters in Kuopio and [[Northern Savonia]]. In this, its twelfth year, the international festival of contemporary art spread to other locations too, such as [[Lapinlahti]], Hietasalo island and the [[smoke sauna]] in Rauhalahti. In Cruising for Art about 20 Finnish and international artists made over 800 1-to-1 performances around Kuopio. Also the first PechaKucha night in Kuopio was organized during the festival.
'''2014'''
Children and teenagers were in the focus of this year's ANTI – Contemporary Art Festival. The international festival programme consisted of work where the youngest family members or youngsters nearing adulthood were either the theme or an active part of the production. This year the first ever ANTI Festival International Prize for Live Art was awarded. Winner of the first prize was Canadian artist [[Heather Cassils]].
==Recent events== Artistic Directors Mrs. Johanna Tuukkanen and Mr. Erkki Soininen of the ANTI -festival received a Finnish State Prize for the Arts on November 16, 2006.
Erkki Soininen was replaced by a Briton, Mr. [[Gregg Whelan]], who was appointed as Co-Artistic Director of ANTI in February 2007. Whelan has participated in ANTI as an artist since 2003. Whelan also works as a performance-maker, writer and co-artistic director of Lone Twin and Lone Twin Theatre.
ANTI – Contemporary Art Festival has participated in EU projects [https://web.archive.org/web/20141015124848/http://www.aspaceforliveart.org/ A Space for Live Art] and Up to Nature.
==External links== *[http://www.antifestival.com ANTI - Contemporary Art Festival -site] *[http://www.kipinafestivaali.fi/download.cfm?DownloadFile=91C7939D-20ED-B6D6-FE845B555A65ABC0 "New Co-Artistic Director selected for the ANTI Festival". February 5th, 2007.]{{dead link|date=October 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} (pdf)
{{coord|62|53|34.05|N|27|40|45.10|E|display=title}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:ANTI - Contemporary Art Festival}} [[Category:Festivals in Finland]] [[Category:Kuopio]] [[Category:Recurring events established in 2002]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Northern Savonia]] [[Category:2002 establishments in Finland]] [[Category:Street art festivals]]
