revision.text:
{{Primarysources|date=August 2008}} {{Coord|-37.904807|145.21062|display=t|type:landmark}} The protection, preservation, conservation and restoration of [[industrial heritage]] and related machinery is often overlooked in social histories. As the importance of the industrial heritage of [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]] and [[Australia]] has become more prominent, the '''Melbourne Steam Traction Engine Club''' (MSTEC) was established by volunteers to enable like-minded volunteers to preserve this part of our history. The '''Melbourne Steam Traction Engine Club''' was established in [[Melbourne]] over 45 years ago and is located at 1200 Ferntree Gully Rd [[Scoresby, Victoria]], [[Australia]]. On site there is an extensive collection of Mobile Steam, Stationary [[Steam Engine]]s, Stationary IC Engines, [[Diesel engines]], Diesel [[Engine-generator|Generator]] sets, [[Tractors]] and other mobile machinery.<ref>Members Handbook, 3rd edition - Aug 2008</ref>
{{Infobox Organization |name = Melbourne Steam Traction Engine Club |image = |image_border = |size = 160+ |caption = |map = |msize = (map size, optional, default 200px) |mcaption = (optional) |abbreviation = MSTEC |motto = |formation = 1963 |extinction = |type = Not for Profit |status = Incorporated |purpose = Steam and industrial heritage preservation |headquarters = 1200 Ferntree Gully Road |location = [[Scoresby, Victoria]] |region_served = |membership = |language = |leader_title = President |leader_name = Neil Meyers |main_organ = committee |num_staff = 0 |num_volunteers = 160+ |budget = |website = http://www.melbournesteam.com.au |remarks = }}
==History== Formed in 1963 the MSTEC has been at its present 6½ hectare site in [[Scoresby, Victoria]] since 1986 when the land was leased from the Beamish Heavy Haulage at Wantirna. The site was originally a depot used for the tunnelling of the main [[trunk sewer]] and was a desolate waste land when the club took it over. Since occupation, the site as been developed with landscaping, tree planting, installation of the rail track, construction of the 9 sheds and toilet block and a man made lake.<ref>Members Handbook, p.5</ref>
==National Steam Centre display== The engines on display at the National Steam Centre represent many years of collection and restoration efforts by the members. In addition to the engines owned by the club, a number of members' privately owned engines are kept at the centre. A particular effort has gone in to ensure Australian steam and industrial heritage is preserved for Australians, in Australia, rather than allowing local heritage to be shipped overseas.
==Run days== Many of the engines on display are operated on the last Sunday of each month. This unique opportunity allows visitors to see many of the steam and diesel stationary engines running, including several steam [[Traction engine]]s, [[steam roller]]s and tractors operating in the central arena. Rides aboard the miniature steam railway are a highlight!
==Annual rally== The club's annual rally, known as the '''Scoresby Steamfest''' is held on the long week end in March each year when many of the beautifully restored MSTEC engines are exhibited and operated. Particular emphasis is placed on exhibiting engines as they were intended to be used, driving industrial or agricultural implements for example. Exhibits from many other associated clubs and historic machinery associations are also displayed and operated, as well as that from private collectors and enthusiasts. More recently, exhibits at the '''Scoresby Steamfest''' have grown to encompass many other hobbies and collections, including model and experimantal engineering and crafting, collections of antique engineering artifacts and tools, oil lamps, mechanical music, and other items from bygone eras.
==Railway== The miniature railway operates every Sunday, weather permitting, from 11 am to 4 pm, except for the Christmas - New Year period. The track runs for about 1 km around the perimeter of the site. On the trip you pass the lake complete with numerous ducks and other water birds, you see the cattle grazing on the nearby farmland and you view some of the museum machinery around the track.
The line is only set up to run a single train at any one time. On the last Sunday of the month the train is pulled by a 4-4-2 steam locomotive. On other Sundays the diesel outline engine is used.
The grounds have shady trees, picnic tables and wood-fired barbecues for a picnic outing. There is no charge for admission to the grounds except for some special events like the annual rally.
==See also== * [[List of steam fairs]]
==External links== * http://www.melbournesteam.com.au
==References== <references/>{{Museums and galleries in Victoria (Australia) }} [[Category:Organisations based in Melbourne]] [[Category:Museums in Victoria (Australia)]] [[Category:Steam festivals]] [[Category:Miniature railways in Australia]] [[Category:Railway museums in Victoria (Australia)]] [[Category:Steam museums]] [[Category:Technology museums in Australia]]

{{coord|44|58|52|N|93|10|5|W|display=title}} {{Infobox recurring event |name= Minnesota State Fair |logo=[[File:Minnesota State Fair Logo.png|frameless]] |image= Fairchild.JPG |imagesize=frameless |caption= The State Fair Gopher 'Fairchild' greets fairgoers. |location= [[Falcon Heights, Minnesota]] |years_active= 1859–Present
(excluding 1861, 1862, 1893, 1945, 1946) |dates= 12 days before and including [[Labor Day]] |genre= [[State fair]] |attendance= 2,046,533 (2018){{cite news | url =http://www.startribune.com/minnesota-state-fair-breaks-attendance-record-surpasses-2-million-for-first-time/492418151/ | website = [[Star Tribune]] | date = September 4, 2018 | title = Minnesota State Fair breaks attendance record, surpasses 2 million for first time | last = Smith | first = Mary Lynn }} |website= [http://www.mnstatefair.org/ www.mnstatefair.org] }} The '''Minnesota State Fair''' is the [[state fair]] of the [[U.S. state]] of [[Minnesota]]. Its slogan is "'''The Great Minnesota Get-Together.'''" It is the largest state fair in the [[United States]] by average daily attendance.{{cite web| title=Detailed Daily Attendance| publisher =Minnesota State Fair| url =http://www.mnstatefair.org/general_info/attendance.html| accessdate = 2014-09-02}} It is also the second-largest state fair in the [[United States]]http://www.carnivalwarehouse.com/lists/2010list.pdf by total attendance, trailing only the [[State Fair of Texas]], which generally runs twice as long as the Minnesota State Fair.{{cite web| title =Fiscal Notes, September 2003| publisher =Texas Comptroller of Public Accounts|date=September 2003| url =http://www.window.state.tx.us/comptrol/fnotes/fn0309/big.html| accessdate = 2007-07-17}} The state fairgrounds, adjoining the Saint Paul campus of the [[University of Minnesota]], are in [[Falcon Heights, Minnesota]], midway between the state's [[capital (political)|capital]] city of [[Saint Paul, Minnesota|St. Paul]] and its largest city, [[Minneapolis]], near the [[Como Park, Zoo, and Conservatory|Como Park]] and [[Saint Anthony Park, Saint Paul|Saint Anthony Park]] neighborhoods of Saint Paul. Residents of the state and region come to the fair to be entertained, exhibit their best [[livestock]], show off their abilities in a variety of fields including [[art]] and [[cooking]], learn about new products and services, and eat many different types of [[food]]—often on a stick. The fair runs for twelve days from late August into early September, ending on [[Labor Day]]. The Minnesota State Fair was named the best state fair in the United States in 2015 by readers of [[USA Today]].http://www.10best.com/awards/travel/best-state-fair/ The Minnesota State Fair is one of the most popular tourist attractions in the area. Around two million people attend the Fair annually{{cite web|url=https://rove.me/to/midwest/minnesota-state-fair|title=Minnesota State Fair}}. Attendance in 2018 was a record 2,046,533 people. The highest daily attendance in the history of the fair was 270,426 visitors on Saturday, September 1, 2018.{{cite web|title=Minnesota State Fair Sets 1-Day Attendance Record Saturday|url=https://www.mnstatefair.org/about-the-fair/attendance}} ==History== [[File:1910postcardStateFairMN.jpg|thumb|right|1910 Minnesota State Fair postcard]] [[Minnesota Territory]] first held a Territorial Fair in 1854, although the first Minnesota State Fair didn't occur until 1859, the year after statehood. Since then, the fair has run annually except for five different years. In 1861 and 1862, the fair was not held because of the [[American Civil War|Civil War]] and the [[Dakota War of 1862]]. Scheduling issues between the fair and the [[World's Columbian Exposition]] in [[Chicago]], [[Illinois]] caused the 1893 show to be canceled. The fair again closed because of war in 1945, as [[fuel]] was in short supply. It was again closed in 1946 because of an outbreak of [[polio]]. {{cite press release | title =Minnesota state fair 2006 press kit | publisher = Minnesota state fair | year = 2006 | url = http://www.mnstatefair.org/2006_pdf/PressKit_MSF2006.pdf | accessdate = 2007-08-06 |format=PDF}} In its early years during the 19th century, the fair was held in many different locations. Some were not far from the current site, but others were held in Greater Minnesota, including years where it was held in [[Rochester, Minnesota|Rochester]], [[Owatonna, Minnesota|Owatonna]], and [[Winona, Minnesota|Winona]]. For a time in the 1870s, the [[Minneapolis-St. Paul|Twin Cities]] of [[Minneapolis, Minnesota|Minneapolis]] and St. Paul held competing fairs. Minneapolis, the younger city of the pair, eventually outdid its neighbor by staging the larger fair with the help of [[William S. King]]. {{cite book | last = Marling | first = Karal Ann | title = Blue Ribbon: A Social and Pictorial History of the Minnesota State Fair | publisher = [[Minnesota Historical Society]] Press | year = 1990 | isbn = 978-0-87351-252-7 }} In 1884, a [[committee]] was put together by the [[Minnesota State Agricultural Society]] to select a permanent site. One site that was considered was an area around [[Minnehaha Falls]], but the final site chosen was the [[Ramsey County, Minnesota|Ramsey County]] [[Poor farm|Poor Farm]], the fair's current site. It was a politically neutral site, being about halfway between Minneapolis and St. Paul. The fair first opened its doors there on September 7, 1885. The site was then 210 [[acre]]s (0.8 km²), but now stands at 322 acres (1.3 km²){{cite web |title=About the Fair |url=https://www.mnstatefair.org/about-the-fair/ |website=Minnesota State Fair |date=8 May 2018}}. [[File:PrincessKay.jpg|thumb|left|[[Linda Christensen]] sculpting Princess Kay in 2010]] One of the first annual events to occur is the creation of a [[butter sculpture]]. Each year, a new [[Princess Kay of the Milky Way]] is selected to promote Minnesota's [[dairy]] industry. Part of the job involves posing for several hours in a walk-in, glass-walled refrigerator as a 90-pound (41 kg) block of butter is carved into a head with her likeness. Butter makers started sculpting their products at the fair as far back as 1898, although the head-sculpting tradition didn't begin until 1964. The main entrance to the fair from Snelling Avenue heads onto a road named [[Dan Patch]] Avenue for a [[harness racing|pacer]] [[horse]] who won every race he ran in from 1900 to 1909 when he was retired. One of the most significant dates in the fair's history was September 2, 1901, when then-[[Vice President of the United States|Vice President]] [[Theodore Roosevelt]] was visiting and first uttered the famous phrase, "Speak softly and carry a [[Big stick diplomacy|big stick]]." Roosevelt became [[President of the United States|president]] just 12 days later after [[William McKinley]] was assassinated. In 1925, the Minnesota State Fair was the site of the Norse-American Centennial celebration. During his appearance at the [[Norse-American Centennial]], President [[Calvin Coolidge]] gave recognition to the contributions of [[Scandinavian-Americans]] and noted [[Leif Erikson]] as the discoverer of America.[http://www.naha.stolaf.edu/pubs/nas/volume33/vol33_10.htm ''The 1925 Norse-American Immigration Centennial and Ethnic Identity'' (April Schultz. Norwegian-American Historical Association. Volume 33: Page 267) ] In 1967, attendance was well over a million people and the record day that year was about 197,000 visitors. By 2016, attendance neared 2 million and the record day was about a quarter-million people.{{cite news | url = http://www.startribune.com/minnesota-state-fair-on-track-to-set-attendance-record/442706653/ | newspaper = [[Minneapolis Star Tribune]] | title = Minnesota State Fair on track to set attendance record | last = Roper | first = Eric | date = September 5, 2017 | accessdate = September 5, 2017 }} {{Clear}} 2018 was another record year for the Fair. The overall attendance record of 2,046,533 was set along with an all-time single-day attendance record of 270,426 on the second Saturday. https://www.mnstatefair.org/about-the-fair/attendance/ ==Attractions== ===Livestock=== A large portion of the Fairgrounds are occupied by livestock barns, where various farm animals are displayed. The animals and their owners take part in livestock shows to compete for awards. Most of the shows take place in the coliseum, a large indoor arena on the fairgrounds. The Coliseum was constructed to replace the Hippodrome, which was rendered structurally unsound during its use as a Propeller Plant by the A.O. Smith Corporation during WWII and razed in 1946, and was completed for use in the 1951 fair.{{cite book|last=Speer|first=Ray P.|title=Minnesota State Fair: The History and Heritage of 100 Years|year=1964|publisher=Argus Publishing Company|pages=237, 271}} Open class livestock competitions are held in horses, beef cattle, dairy cattle, swine, sheep, dairy goats, [[llama]]s, poultry (chickens, ducks, geese, turkeys, pigeons) rabbits, and stock [[dog]]s.{{cite web| title =Open Class Livestock| publisher = Minnesota State Fair| year =2007| url=http://www.mnstatefair.org/pages/livestock.html| accessdate = 2007-07-17}} On August 31, 2007, a bull escaped from its handler charging several fairgoers before fatally injuring itself charging a fire hydrant. No people were seriously injured in the mishap.{{cite web| title =Bull Escapes At Minnesota State Fair| publisher =WCCO| date =2007-08-31| url =http://wcco.com/local/local_story_243124851.html| accessdate =2007-08-31 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070929100000/http://wcco.com/local/local_story_243124851.html |archivedate = 2007-09-29}} ===Food=== [[File:Cheese Curd Stand at MN State Fair.jpg|thumb|A stand selling cheese curds]] One of the primary attractions at the State Fair is the wide variety of foods to be had.{{or-inline|date=December 2017}} Classic fair foods such as [[Cotton Candy|cotton candy]] and [[Hot Dogs|hot dogs]] are available. Some foods reflect Minnesota's agriculture, including [[Cheese Curds|cheese curds]], milk shakes, and [[Corn Dog|corn dogs]]. Many foods at the fair are deep fried or come on a stick; from the classic corn dog to alligator-on-a-stick, lobster-on-a-stick, and deep fried candy bar on a stick. New to the fair in 2006 was [[hotdish]] on a stick, a variant of a classic staple of Minnesotan cuisine. In 2007, one new food was [[spaghetti]] on a stick. 2008's new foods included two types of [[bacon]], one called "Pig Lickers", which is chocolate covered, and the other, called the "Big Fat Bacon", a quarter pound of maple glazed bacon. Another staple of the state fair is “Sweet Martha’s Cookies” a stand that serves fresh and warm chocolate chip cookies in buckets.{{cite news| title = new tastes, their takes| work = twincities.com| pages = 10E| publisher = St. Paul Pioneer Press| date = 2008-08-28}} In 2018, 27 new foods were introduced to the Minnesota State Fair including Firecracker Shrimp Stuffed Avocado, Honey Cream Soda Float, Mangonada Shaved Ice, Messy Giuseppe, Nordic Waffles, Smoked Soft Serve Ice Cream, and the UpNorth Puff Pastry.https://assets.mnstatefair.org/pdf/18-new-food.pdf ===Machinery Hill=== Machinery Hill is a large area of the fairgrounds. For several decades, it held the largest annual display of [[farm equipment]] in the world, with many companies showing off [[tractor]]s, [[combine harvester|combines]], and various attachments. However, modern displays generally focus on [[automobile|car]]s, trucks, [[lawn mower]]s, hot tubs and recreational machines like [[motorbike]]s. Farm implement dealers tend to direct their efforts to more targeted "farm shows," abandoning the State Fair to more urban or suburban types of exhibitors. Machinery Hill also contains an interactive exhibit for kids called Little Farm Hands. In this exhibit, children get to experience life on the farm from planting seeds to selling goods at the farmers market. {{Cite web|url=http://www.mnstatefair.org/entertainment/ag_exhibits/lfh.html|title=Minnesota State Fair {{!}} Little Farm Hands|website=www.mnstatefair.org|language=en|access-date=2018-02-02}} ===Shows=== [[File:PHCstage2008StateFair.JPG|thumb|left|''A Prairie Home Companion'' live at the grandstand]] The State Fair is host to numerous shows, including concerts, comedy shows, [[product demonstration]]s, and the State Fair Talent Contest. The Grandstand is a large outdoor concert hall that also features 3 floors of interior exhibition space. It hosts the largest of the fairs concerts and until 2002 was also the site of [[stock car]] races run on a small oval track. In 2003 the facility completed the first phase of a $35 million remodeling project that removed large sections of bleachers and increased [[seating capacity]] to 17,000.{{cite news | first = Greta |last = Cunningham |title = State Fair Grandstand to get a facelift |url = http://news.minnesota.publicradio.org/features/2003/08/18_cunninghamg_grandstand/ |publisher = Minnesota Public Radio |date = 2003-08-18 | accessdate = 2006-09-30}} Most local television and radio stations set up temporary studios at the State Fair in their permanent buildings or booths, including for example a live broadcast of [[Garrison Keillor]]'s ''[[A Prairie Home Companion]]''. As of 2013, the Grandstand hosts the Walker Art Center's Internet Cat Video Festival, in which fairgoers watch the year's most popular cat videos and memes and award the best videos with cat trophies, the most prized being the Golden Kitty.{{fact|date=December 2017}} Guest appearances have included Grumpy Cat and Lil Bub, two internet stars, as well as the creator of Nyan Cat, Christopher Torres. The festival began in 2012. ===Art=== The fair displays an annual art exhibition that is the result of a [[Juried (competition)|juried competition]] of works of [[fine art]]. Media include watercolor, oil, and acrylic paintings, photographs, sculptures, pastels, ceramics, glass, and textiles. Entrants must be living residents of the state. In 2010, a total of 2,330 pieces were submitted, and 413 works were accepted. Jeffery Gauss won the coveted People's Choice award with his "MicroDoodle Topiary", and "Dog Park" by Arden Harrison Bushnell won the Kid's Choice award.{{cite web| title =Fine Arts| publisher =Minnesota State Fair| year =2007| url =http://www.mnstatefair.org/pages/fine_arts.html| accessdate = 2007-07-17}} One unusual display at the fair consists of the entrants in the [[Crop art]] competition. The artwork must be made of plant matter (seeds, stems, flowers, fruit, etc.) suitable for growing in Minnesota.{{cite web| title =Ag-Hort-Bee Rules and Premiums| publisher =Minnesota State Fair| year =2007| url =http://www.mnstatefair.org/2007_pdf/AG07-pbWeb.pdf| format =PDF| accessdate =2007-07-17 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070928083538/http://www.mnstatefair.org/2007_pdf/AG07-pbWeb.pdf |archivedate = 2007-09-28}} For decades the display was dominated by [[Owatonna, Minnesota|Owatonna]] native [[Lillian Colton]] (1912–2007), who created [[Crop art|seed]] portraits, professionally,{{cite web| title =A remembrance of the Seed Lady| publisher =MPR| date =2007-03-22| url =http://minnesota.publicradio.org/display/web/2007/03/22/seedladyobit/| accessdate = 2007-07-17}} having effectively captured scores of celebrities such as [[Ernest Hemingway]], [[Barbra Streisand]], [[Franklin D. Roosevelt]], [[Prince (musician)|Prince]], [[Princess Diana]], and [[Willie Nelson]] in her crop art. After winning nine purple ribbons, she stopped competing, but continued displaying her work at the fair.{{cite web| title =Crop Art| publisher =David Steinlicht| url =http://www.cropart.com/index.htm| accessdate = 2007-07-17}} Competitions galore cover dozens of categories in [[Needlework|needlecraft]], garment-making, [[wood-working]], [[Physical model|models]], painting, [[doll]]-making, [[taxidermy]], [[stamp-collecting]], [[scrapbooking]], baking, [[canning|food preservation]], etc.{{cite web| title =Creative Activities - Rules and Premiums| publisher =Minnesota State Fair| year =2007| url =http://www.mnstatefair.org/2007_pdf/CA07-pbWeb.pdf| format =PDF| accessdate = 2007-07-17 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070928083546/http://www.mnstatefair.org/2007_pdf/CA07-pbWeb.pdf |archivedate = 2007-09-28}} ===Milk run=== The annual 5 km run begins on the fairgrounds, winds its way through the [[Saint Paul, Minnesota|Saint Paul]] campus of the [[University of Minnesota]] and the [[Saint Anthony Park]] neighborhood, and ends back at the fairgrounds.{{cite web| title =Milk Run| publisher =Minnesota State Fair| year =2007| url =http://www.mnstatefair.org/pages/milk_run.html| accessdate =2007-07-17}} ===4-H=== [[4-H]]{{cite web| title =Minnesota State 4-H| publisher =Minnesota State 4-H| year =2007| url =http://www.fourh.umn.edu| accessdate =2007-08-28}} has a significant presence at the fair, both in the 4-H Building and in the animal barns and arenas. Contests include herdsmanship, [[horse showmanship|showmanship]], judging teams, public presentations and county club exhibits. Livestock displays include [[beef cattle|beef]] and [[dairy cattle]], dairy and market [[goat]]s, [[poultry]] ([[chicken]]s, [[duck]]s, [[goose|geese]], [[turkey (bird)|turkeys]], and [[Columbidae|pigeons]]), [[rabbit]]s, [[Domestic sheep|sheep]], and [[pig|swine]].{{cite web| title =4-H Livestock| publisher =Minnesota State Fair| year =2007| url =http://www.mnstatefair.org/pages/4_H.html| accessdate = 2007-07-17}} About half of all 4-H projects entered are animal science projects. The 4-H building was opened and dedicated in 1939{{cite book|last=Speer|first=Ray P.|title=Minnesota State Fair: A History and Heritage of 100 Years|year=1964|publisher=Argus Publishing Company|page=203}} [http://www1.extension.umn.edu/youth/mn4-h/state-fair/ about 320,000 state fairgoers visit it every year]. The non-livestock projects include photography, performing arts, crafts, food & nutrition, clothing & textiles, and many more. ===Science=== In recent years the Progress Center has been housing the Eco Experience exhibit, which features activities and exhibits including the design and construction of an eco-friendly house, a [[rain garden]], exhibits addressing [[climate change]], [[energy conservation]], [[renewable energy]], [[biodiesel]] fuel and vehicles, and [[organic farming]]. The exhibit has received awards from the Western Fair Association, the International Associate of Fairs and Expositions, and the Minnesota Environmental Initiative.{{cite web| title =The Eco Experience at the Minnesota State Fair| publisher =Minnesota Pollution Control Agency| year =2007| url =http://www.pca.state.mn.us/ecoexperience/| accessdate = 2007-07-17}} ==Entertainment== ===Music=== Every year there are many musical venues. The most notable venue being the Grandstand which has a capacity of up to 17,000, and has featured headliners such as [[Alabama (band)|Alabama]], [[Christina Aguilera]], [[Backstreet Boys]], [[Bob Dylan]], [[Boston (band)|Boston]], [[Sheryl Crow]], [[Foreigner (band)|Foreigner]], [[Aretha Franklin]], [[Def Leppard]], [[Kiss (band)|KISS]], [[Lynyrd Skynyrd]], [[Demi Lovato]], [[Tim McGraw]], [[Mötley Crüe]], [[REO Speedwagon]], [[Rush (band)|Rush]], [[Santana (band)|Santana]], [[Blake Shelton]], [[Styx (band)|Styx]], [[James Taylor]], [[Carrie Underwood]], [["Weird Al" Yankovic]], [[John Mellencamp]], and [[Usher (musician)|Usher, featuring Lil'John (2017)]]. There are also many free entertainment venues featuring local bands and a selection of national acts. Entertainment stages include the Leinie Lodge Bandshell, the Schell's Stage at Schilling Amphitheater and the International Bazaar Stage, In 2010, [[Boyz II Men]] performed 2 nights at one of the free venues. Performers for the Leinie Lodge scheduled for 2015 include Lou Gramm "The Voice Of Foreigner", and several other national acts. The Cobras, a blues quartet, were slated to appear twice in 2016 at the French Creperie on Carnes Avenue.{{update-inline|date=December 2017}} ===Permanent rides=== There are several rides that are permanent fixtures at the fair, including the Giant Slide, on which fairgoers ride down a large fiberglass slide on burlap sacks. The Skyride is an aerial lift ride that carried fairgoers across the grounds in a gondola. The Space Tower is a [[gyro tower]] that rotates as it lifts people over 300 feet in the air, giving views of the Minneapolis/St. Paul area. There is also a [[haunted house]], located on Judson Ave, a water raft ride, and log chute. The fair's oldest ride, Ye Old Mill (opened in 1915), is located near the food building. It is a tunnel of love style ride that caters to all ages.{{tone-inline|date=December 2017}} ===Temporary rides=== [[File:Midway-Minnesota State Fair-2006.jpg|thumb|left|The Midway]] The [[Midway (fair)|Midway]] is a carnival-like setting that contains most of the rides at the State Fair. The attractions include several funhouses, roller coasters and other thrill rides as well as numerous games of skill. Adventure Park is where the more extreme thrill rides are located.{{fact|date=December 2017}} This includes the Ejection Seat and other rides like it. It is located across the street from the Midway, but is not a part of it. Adventure park also shares this block with a [[french fry]] stand.{{fact|date=December 2017}} Kidway is the carnival area on the fairgrounds geared toward children. Kidway is located between Dan Patch and Wright Avenues on the north end of the fairgrounds. {{Clear}} ==Management== The Minnesota State Fair is considered a quasi-state agency, under the direction of the Minnesota State Agricultural Society. The management of the fair is handled by the Board of managers. The state fair has not accepted any governmental funds since 1949. Revenue from the fair is reinvested into maintenance and the next year's fair. The Minnesota State Fair Foundation is an organization that works to improve and preserves historic state fair buildings. The foundation is a [[501(c)3]] organization, and also supports State Fair agricultural, scientific and educational programs. The foundation provided funding for the new Miracle of Birth center. The Fair employs about 80 full-time staff members for the entire year; in the summer, some 400 seasonal staff are hired. During the fair-time, around 3,000 people are additionally hired{{cite web|url=https://www.mnstatefair.org/about-the-fair/|title=About the Fair|publisher=Minnesota State Fair}}. ==J.V. Bailey House== [[File:BaileyHouse.JPG|thumb|right|The restored J.V. Bailey House]] The J.V. Bailey House, at 1263 Cosgrove Street, is one of the oldest buildings on the fairgrounds. It was built in 1911 and restoration was completed in 2006. It is connected to the greenhouses and was occupied year-round by the greenhouse superintendent until 2004. The State Fair Foundation operates out of the residence. The historic residence is open to Foundation donors and their family and friends during the fair.{{cite web| title =J.V. Bailey House| publisher =Placeography.com| url =http://www.placeography.org/index.php?title=J.V._Bailey_House%2C_1263_Cosgrove_Street%2C_Saint_Paul%2C_Minnesota| accessdate = 2008-08-29}} ==Mascots== The fair's mascots are two anthropomorphized [[Gopher (animal)|gophers]]. The choice of gopher as mascots was an homage to the [[University of Minnesota]] [[Goldy Gopher|mascot]] which is also a gopher and was a historical reference to the expansion of railroads in Minnesota, towns popping up across the state like gophers.{{cite web|title=Minnesota State Fair History|url=http://www.mnstatefair.org/pdf/media/MSF-History.pdf|website=Minnesota State Fair|publisher=Minnesota State Agricultural Society|accessdate=14 May 2018}} For these reasons, Minnesota is sometimes referred to as the gopher state.{{cite news|title=Minnesota Moment: Why we're called the Gopher State|url=http://www.startribune.com/minnesota-moment-why-we-re-called-the-gopher-state/474225163/|accessdate=14 May 2018|agency=Star Tribune Media Company, LLC|publisher=Star Tribune|date=February 16, 2018}} Fairchild, the original mascot, was suggested in a statewide contest by Gladys Anderson Brown in 1966 in honor of Henry S. Fairchild who advocated using the former Ramsey County Poor Farm as the permanent site of the fair.{{cite news|last1=Berdan|first1=Kathy|title=Q&A: Usually mute Fairchild is funnier – and punnier – than we thought|url=https://www.twincities.com/2016/08/25/pioneer-press-fairchild-mn-state-fair-mascot-50/|accessdate=14 May 2018|agency=Digital First Media|publisher=Twin Cities Pioneer Press|date=August 25, 2016}} Dressed like an early [[Barker (occupation)|barker]] on the midway with a straw hat and striped jacket, Fairchild has represented the fair since 1966. In 1986, he was joined on promotional materials by his nephew, Fairborn. {{cite book | last = Marling | first = Karal Ann | title = Blue Ribbon: A Social and Pictorial History of the Minnesota State Fair | publisher = Minnesota Historical Society Press | place = St. Paul, Minnesota | year = 1990 | isbn = 978-0-87351-252-7 | page = 234 }} ==Attendance records== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" |- ! Day !! Attendance{{Cite web|url=https://www.mnstatefair.org/about-the-fair/attendance/|title=Attendance|publisher=Minnesota State Fair Attendance|website=www.mnstatefair.org|access-date=2018-09-04}} !! Year |- ! First Thursday | 122,965 || 2018 |- ! First Friday |141,023||2016 |- ! First Saturday | 222,194 || 2018 |- ! First Sunday | 209,969 || 1994 |- ! First Monday | 144,504 || 2017 |- ! First Tuesday | 133,595 || 2014 |- ! First Wednesday | 144,940 || 2018 |- ! Second Thursday | 156,764 || 2018 |- ! Second Friday | 187,066 || 2017 |- ! Second Saturday | 270,426 || 2018 |- ! Second Sunday | 242,759 || 2017 |- ! Second Monday (Labor Day) | 178,867 || 2015 |- ! Entire Fair | 2,046,533 || 2018 |} ==Off-season use== [[File:President addresses "Bean Feed". State Democratic Chairman George Farr, Minnesota Attorney General Walter F. Mondale... - NARA - 194249.jpg|thumb|right|[[Walter Mondale]] (center) and [[John F. Kennedy]] (right) at the Fairground's Coliseum, 1962]] The fairgrounds is heavily used for events beyond the Fair. These include many horse shows in the Coliseum & Horse Barn, the Minnesota Horse Expo and the Minnesota Beef Expo, dog shows, antique & hot-rod car shows, motorcycle shows, model railroad shows, clothing & jewellery shows, gun & weapon collectors shows, comic book conventions, flea markets & swap meets, and more. Buildings on the grounds are frequently rented for commercial events such as appliance sales, computer & electronics sales, and boat & car sales. Earlier in the summer, some of the fairground's roads are used to host an annual series of bike races during the week, called the State Fair Affair Criterium Series. In addition, many of the buildings are rented for winter storage of boats, camping trailers, and similar equipment. Rental fees for such off-season use of the fairgrounds is a major source of revenue for the State Fair, often surpassing the profits from the Fair itself. The Coliseum was the home rink for many college and high school hockey teams. After 40 years and a few thousand games the facility saw its final game played in February, 2014. ==Gallery== Image:Princess Kay of the Milky Way-2006.jpg|Audrey Mohr of [[New Ulm, Minnesota]] (right), [[Princess Kay of the Milky Way]] 2006–2007 Image:Showing Holstein cow-Minnesota.jpg|Showing a [[Holstein (cattle)|Holstein]] [[cattle|cow]] Image:Draft horses-Minnesota.-2006.jpg|[[Draft horse]]s Image:Machinery Hill-Minnesota.jpg|Skyglider, Machinery Hill Image:Agriculture Building-Minnesota.jpg|The Fine Arts and 4-H buildings Image:Jams, Jellies, Honeys-Minnesota State Fair.jpg|[[fruit preserves|Jams, jellies]] and [[honey]]s Image:Giant Slide-Minnesota State Fair.jpg|The Giant Slide Image:2010 MN State Fair crowd.JPG|August 2010 crowd Image:MinnesotaStateFairBreads2007-08-25.JPG|Breads and baked goods Image:Minnesotastatefairpeople.jpg|August 25, 2007 Image:MN State Fair cheerleaders 2003.JPG|[[Minnesota Golden Gophers Spirit Squads|Golden Gopher Spirit Squads]] during the Maroon and Gold Day Parade in 2003 Image:Minn-State-Fair.jpg|Daytime crowd at the Fair Image:KARE-TV-MN State Fair 20060826.jpg|Television interview during the 2006 Fair ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{portal|Minnesota}} {{commons}} *[http://www.mnopedia.org/event/minnesota-state-fair-origins-and-traditions Minnesota State Fair: Origins and Traditions in MNopedia, the Minnesota Encyclopedia] *[http://www.mnstatefair.org/ Minnesota State Fair] *[http://www.msffoundation.org/ Minnesota State Fair Foundation] {{Minnesota}} {{Falcon Heights, Minnesota}} {{Music venues of Minnesota}} [[Category:Minnesota State Fair|*]] [[Category:History of Minnesota]] [[Category:State fairs]] [[Category:Festivals in Minnesota]] [[Category:August events]] [[Category:September events]] [[Category:Recurring events established in 1859]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Ramsey County, Minnesota]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Ramsey County, Minnesota]]

{{Multiple issues|{{underlinked|date=December 2012}} {{external links|date=December 2012}}}} {| class="infobox" style="width: 25em; font-size: 90%; margin: 0 0 1em 1em; clear: right; text-align:left" |- | colspan="2" style="text-align: center; background:#AFD6FF;" | '''Moskau Messe Exhibition Company (Moscow Fair)''' |- style="vertical-align: top;" |colspan="2" style="text-align: center; background:#eee;" |[[File:1 ECC Socolniki pavilion4 exhibition.jpg|300px]] |- style="vertical-align: top;" |style="text-align: right; background:#eee;" |'''Activity''' |style="padding-right: 1em;" | Exhibition business |- style="vertical-align: top;" |style="text-align: right; background:#eee;" |'''Foundation''' |style="padding-right: 1em;" | 1989 |- style="vertical-align: top;" |style="text-align: right; background:#eee;" |'''Location''' |style="padding-right: 1em;" | Moscow, Russia |- style="vertical-align: top;" |style="text-align: right; background:#eee;" |'''Director General''' |style="padding-right: 1em;" | Alexey Kharyutkin |- style="vertical-align: top;" | style="text-align: right; background:#eee;" |'''Website''' | style="padding-right: 1em;" | http://www.moskaumesse.com/eng/ |}
'''Moskau Messe Exhibition Company '''organises exhibitions, conferences and fairs in [[Moscow|Moscow, Russia]] and abroad. In 2011 Moskau Messe Exhibition Company became a full member of the Russian Union of Exhibitions and Fairs.
== History ==
Moskau Messe Company (Moscow Fair) was founded in 1989 as a [[History of Germans in Russia, Ukraine and the Soviet Union|Soviet-German]] joint venture. The company’s exhibitions were hosted in the Sokolniki Cultural and Exhibition Center, (the current [[Sokolniki Exhibition and Convention Centre]]) which had been underused since the 1960s, when it was one of the county’s main exhibition centers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.informexpo.ru/new/view_content.php?id=1484 |title=From Moskau Messe to MVK Holding |publisher=Informexpo.ru |date= |accessdate=2014-04-12}}</ref>
In the 1990s, Moskau Messe launched a series of projects that remain viable to this day. Polygraphinter was the first large-scale event to be held in Sokolniki in 1992. Other projects included EuroExpoMebel, International Construction Week, Woodex (woodworking industries) in 1993, Rosupak in 1996 and the Russian Education Forum in 1997.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://kommersant.ru/doc/265646/print |title=Exhibitions, fairs and salons: the first half of 1991 The Kommersant newspaper, no.5 (55), 01/28/1991 |publisher=Kommersant.ru |date=1991-01-28 |accessdate=2014-04-12}}</ref>
In 2002, Moskau Messe founded the MVK International Exhibition Company, <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kommersant.ru/doc/266000/print |title=New Sokolniki: shunting revirescence? The Kommersant newspaper: Government, no. 12 (23), 03/26/1990 |publisher=Kommersant.ru |date=1990-03-26 |accessdate=2014-04-12}}</ref> (which later became the British company ITE in 2010). In 2003, offices opened in [[Germany]] and [[Canada]] and in 2004, another one was opened in [[Israel]]. In 2007 and 2008, offices were opened in [[Turkey]] and [[China]].
From 2006 to 2010, Moskau Messe Exhibition Company, with the Sokolniki Exhibition and Convention Centre, launched a number of socio-educational projects including Still higher, and higher, and higher (the first exhibition in the stratosphere),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mvkstars.ru/eng/default.aspx |title=MVK Exhibition Company - Still higher, and higher, and higher! |publisher=Mvkstars.ru |date= |accessdate=2014-04-12}}</ref> TWO PARISes (in [[France]] and [[Russia]]), the first exhibition at the [[Eiffel Tower]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://paris.sokolniki.com/eng/default.aspx |title=Выставки Возможности Рынки |publisher=Paris.sokolniki.com |date= |accessdate=2014-04-12}}</ref> Our Victory Project,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://victory.sokolniki.com/eng/default.aspx |title=Our victory |publisher=Victory.sokolniki.com |date= |accessdate=2014-04-12}}</ref> and From Earth to the Universe.
== Current operations ==
In 2011, the Moskau Messe Exhibition Company became a full member of the Russian Union of Exhibitions and Fairs.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.uefexpo.ru/?id=257&org_id=69130 |title=RUEF Members / Moskau Messe |publisher=Uefexpo.ru |date= |accessdate=2014-04-12}}</ref>
At present, Moskau Messe manages the following social projects: the [[International Exhibition of Calligraphy]], the Russian Education Forum, WANExpo, the Festival of Prospective Mothers and the Newborn, EXTREMEX, the International Exhibition and Show of Extreme Sports, Tourism and Leisure, etc.
The main venue for the company’s exhibitions is the Chinese Exhibition and Convention Centres.
== Photos == <center> <gallery perrow="4" widths="200px" heights="130px"> File:1_Equiros_1.jpg File:4_Equiros_2.JPG File:5_Equiros_3.jpg File:2_Betonex_1.jpg File:3_Betonex_2.jpg File:6_Caravanex_1.jpg File:7_Caravanex_2.jpg File:8_Caravanex_3.jpg File:9_WanEXPO_1.jpg File:10_WanEXPO_2.jpg File:11_WanEXPO_3.jpg File:12_WanEXPO_4.jpg File:13_Calligraphy_1.jpg File:14_Calligraphy_2.jpg File:15_Calligraphy_3.jpg File:17_Russian Education.jpg </gallery> </center> {{-}}
== References == {{Reflist}}
== External links == * [http://www.moskaumesse.com/eng/default.aspx Moskau Messe Exhibition Company] * [http://www.sokolniki.com/eng/default.aspx Sokolniki Exhibition and Convention Centre]

revision.text:
{{Infobox | above = Murder of Desirée Mariottini | abovestyle = | image = | caption = | headerstyle = background-color: #99BADD | label1 = Born | data1 = | label2 = Died | data2 = 18 October 2018, Via Dei Lucani 22 [[Rome]], [[Lazio]], Italy | label3 = Cause of death | data3 = Respiratory crisis due to drug mix overdose and repeated torture and sexual abuse. | label4 = Burial | data4 = | label5 = Prosecutors | data5 = | label6 = Arrested | data6 = Mamadou Gara
Brian Minteh
Alinno Chima
Yusif Salia | label7 = Convicted of robbery, kidnapping, drug dealing, sexual assault, torture and murder | data7 = | label8 = | data8 = }} '''Desirée Mariottini''' was an 16-year-old Italian girl who was last seen on 18 October 2018 and was murdered soon after in [[Rome]], Italy.{{cite news |title="Fu stuprata da non cosciente" L'orrore sul corpo di Desirée |url=http://www.ilgiornale.it/news/roma/fu-stuprata-non-cosciente-lorrore-sul-corpo-desir-e-1592494.html |accessdate=25 October 2018}} ==Background== Mariottini was born and lived in [[Cisterna di Latina]] (Latina) in the region of [[Lazio]].{{Cn|date=October 2018}} The San Lorenzo district is a traditionally [[Left-wing politics|left-wing]] neighborhood still scarred by [[World War II]] bombings.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/10/27/world/europe/italy-salvini-immigration.html|title=Salvini Seizes on 2nd Italian Teenager’s Death to Push Immigration Issue|last=|first=|date=|work=[[The New York Times]]|access-date=2018-10-28|language=en}} ==Murder and investigation== On 17 October 2018, Mariottini missed the last bus and did not return to her home.{{Cite news|url=http://www.ansa.it/english/news/2018/10/29/gang-lied-to-teen-on-fatal-drug-mix-to-rape-her-gip_7f8670d6-6f31-4b95-bda4-a5b519217203.html|title=Gang lied to teen on fatal drug mix to rape her - GIP - English|date=2018-10-29|work=ANSA.it|access-date=2018-11-04|language=en}} Desirée Mariottini was drugged unconscious and sexually abused in a [[Drug house|drug den]] in the San Lorenzo district in Rome. While Desirèe was unconscious she was abused several times by different people. As reconstructed, she had taken drugs as early as the afternoon of October 18th, and died later on the night of 19 October. She was being abused while she was dying. This was shown by the investigations conducted by the police in Rome and by the San Lorenzo police station.{{cite news |title=Desirée: fermate due persone, caccia ai complici. Salvini: "I vermi pagheranno" |url=http://www.ansa.it/lazio/notizie/2018/10/25/desiree-polizia-ferma-due-persone_759d633b-c7ef-40a4-ace1-55af4e23bf4b.html |accessdate=25 October 2018}}{{cite news |title=San Lorenzo, l'ex enclave rossa senza più anima |url=http://www.ansa.it/sito/notizie/cronaca/2018/10/25/san-lorenzo-lex-enclave-rossa-senza-piu-anima-_c0bb745a-631a-4461-8460-b678fce9d99f.html |accessdate=25 October 2018}} On 25 October two people were arrested for the murder: Mamadou Gara 26 and Brian Minteh 43 , both [[Senegal]] and living illegally in Italy.{{fact|date=October 2018}} Both are accused, along other suspects, of group sexual violence, drug possession and voluntary homicide. The police are looking for at least two other men involved in the murder. The criminals were identified after a series of testimonies and findings made in the building where the body was found.{{cite news |title=Desirée: fermate due persone, caccia ai complici. Salvini: "I vermi pagheranno" |url=http://www.ansa.it/lazio/notizie/2018/10/25/desiree-polizia-ferma-due-persone_759d633b-c7ef-40a4-ace1-55af4e23bf4b.html |accessdate=25 October 2018}} Later, Alinno Chima, aged 40 from [[Nigeria]] was arrested.{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-45976450|title=Migrants held as girl's killing shocks Italy|date=2018-10-25|work=BBC News|access-date=2018-10-26|language=en-GB}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.maltatoday.com.mt/news/europe/90435/migrants_held_in_italy_over_girls_death|title=Migrants held in Italy over girl's death|work=MaltaToday.com.mt|access-date=2018-10-26|language=en}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.ghanaiantimes.com.gh/migrants-held-as-girls-killing-shocks-italy/|title=Migrants held as girl’s killing shocks Italy - Ghanaian Times|website=www.ghanaiantimes.com.gh|language=en-US|access-date=2018-10-26}} On 26 October 2018 a fourth arrest was made, Yusif Salia from [[Gambia]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.msn.com/en-us/news/world/italian-police-arrest-4th-suspect-in-teens-murder-in-rome/ar-BBOWmJT|title=Italian police arrest 4th suspect in teen's murder in Rome|website=www.msn.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-10-27}} None of the arrested [[Illegal immigration|had legal documents]] to reside in Italy.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/aponline/2018/10/26/world/europe/ap-eu-italy-teen-slain-.html|title=Italian Police Arrest 4th Suspect in Teen's Murder in Rome|access-date=2018-11-04|language=en}} ==Aftermath== Mariottini was buried on Sunday 30 october in Cisterna di Latina in a ceremony attended by hundreds and mayor Raggi declared a day of mourning.{{Cite news|url=http://www.ansa.it/english/news/general_news/2018/10/30/crowds-flock-to-desiree-funeral_98bbee0e-24d7-45d9-81b4-77f199b148fd.html|title=Crowds flock to Desirée funeral - English|date=2018-10-30|work=ANSA.it|access-date=2018-11-04|language=en}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.romatoday.it/cronaca/desiree-mariottini-funerali-30-ottobre-2018.html|title=Desirée Mariottini morta a San Lorenzo: oggi i funerali, Roma è in lutto|work=RomaToday|access-date=2018-11-04}} ===Visit by Minister Matteo Salvini at the scene of the crime=== On October 24th 2018 [[Italian Minister of the Interior|interior minister]] [[Matteo Salvini]], the leader of the anti-migration [[Lega Nord|Northern League party]], went to the abandoned building where the girl's body was found.{{cite news |title=Desirée, Salvini a San Lorenzo |url=http://www.ansa.it/lazio/notizie/2018/10/24/desiree-salvini-a-san-lorenzo_edb33358-4b98-46e3-bf66-48be9d9f0c7a.html |accessdate=25 October 2018}} Activists in the traditionally left-wing San Lorenzo district prevented Salvini from placing a rose outside the drug den where the victim was found and accused Salvini of exploiting her death. He returned later in the day unannounced and placed the flowers in front of the gate. ===Pronouncements by the [[President of the European Parliament]] [[Antonio Tajani]]=== The tragedy of Desirée "must be the last that happens in Italy and in Rome, an abandoned city, the degradation is evident, moral and social, more checks are needed in the city, more men and women of the police are needed, especially at night".{{Citation|last=alaNEWS|title=Desirée, Tajani: "Degrado a Roma, si diano una mossa"|date=2018-10-25|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=r32fk9XeXvM|access-date=2018-10-28}} ===The decision of the mayor of Rome=== The Rome Mayor [[Virginia Raggi]] decided to proclaim a day of mourning for the city in conjunction with the funeral of Desirée Mariottini.{{cite news |title=Desirée: fermate tre persone. Un testimone all'ANSA: "Stava male, intorno 7-8 persone" |url=http://www.ansa.it/lazio/notizie/2018/10/25/desiree-polizia-ferma-due-persone_759d633b-c7ef-40a4-ace1-55af4e23bf4b.html |accessdate=25 October 2018}} She also declared the intention of city authorities to have the building demolished. In a social media post, she stated that as a mayor, as a woman and the mayor of the city she could not tolerate the thought of this crime and called it an "atrocious crime".{{Cite news|url=https://www.euronews.com/2018/10/26/african-migrants-arrested-in-connection-with-italian-teenager-s-death-the-cube|title=African migrants arrested in connection with Italian teenager's death {{!}} The Cube|date=2018-10-26|work=euronews|access-date=2018-10-28|language=en}} On the evening of 25 October 2018, a spontaneous torch-light procession by the people of Rome San Lorenzo was organized to ask for "justice for Desirée".{{cite news |title=San Lorenzo scende in strada. Tensione alla fiaccolata per Desirée |url=https://www.iltempo.it/multimedia/2018/10/25/gallery/roma-san-lorenzo-desiree-fiaccolata-tensione-stupro-omicidio-droga-senegalesi-nigeriano-1094149/ |accessdate=25 October 2018}}{{cite web |title=Desirée: tre fermi per l'omicidio, caccia al quarto uomo |url=http://www.ansa.it/lazio/notizie/2018/10/25/desiree-polizia-ferma-due-persone_759d633b-c7ef-40a4-ace1-55af4e23bf4b.html |accessdate=25 October 2018}} ====Protests against the mayor of Rome==== On 27 October 2018, the citizens of [[Rome]] protest against the deterioration of the city, in which some areas such as Via Dei Lucani 22 are crumbling and abandoned to carelessness, and, above all, to criminals as drug dealers.{{cite news |title=Roma, cittadini in piazza contro la Raggi |url=http://www.ilgiornale.it/news/roma/roma-cittadini-piazza-contro-raggi-1593430.html |accessdate=27 October 2018}} == See also == *[[Murder of Meredith Kercher]] *[[Murder of Ashley Ann Olsen]] *[[Murder of Pamela Mastropietro]] *[[Murder of Amalia Voican]] *[[Murder of Maria Ladenburger]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{DEFAULTSORT:Mariottini, Murder of Desirée}} [[Category:2018 crimes in Italy]] [[Category:2018 murders in Europe|Mariottini, Desirée]] [[Category:2010s in Rome]] [[Category:Crime in Rome]] [[Category:Incidents of violence against women]] [[Category:Murder in Italy|Mariottini, Desirée]] [[Category:October 2018 crimes in Europe]] [[Category:October 2018 events in Italy]] [[Category:Trials in Italy|Mariottini, Desirée]] [[Category:Urban decay in Europe]] [[Category:Violence against women in Italy]]

revision.comment: Removing links to deleted file [[:File:Location of Naderabad in Aghanistan.png]]
revision.text:
<!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Location of Naderabad in Aghanistan.png|thumb|250px|right|Location of Naderabad in Afghanistan]] --> '''Naderabad''' was a city created in 1738 by [[Nader Shah]], the [[King of Persia]] from 1736 to 1747. Nader built the city in the aftermath of his army's destruction of [[Old Kandahar]] and named the city after himself. The city was near the Šorāb river, and {{convert|4|km|spell=in}} from the remnants of Old Kandahar. When Nader Shah died in 1747 the city was abandoned.,<ref name=encyclopaedia-iranica>{{cite web|last1=de Planhol|first1=Xavier|title=Kandahar: Historical Geography to 1979|url=http://www.iranicaonline.org/articles/kandahar-historical-geography-to-1979|website=IranicaOnline.org|publisher=[[Encyclopaedia Iranica]]|accessdate=24 July 2015}}</ref> though it continued to appear on 19th century European maps.<ref>Encyclopedia Iranica: Kandahar</ref>
==See also== *[[Kandahar]] *[[Old Kandahar]]
==References== {{Reflist}}

revision.comment: Added to the Parentage Controversy
revision.text:
{{pp-pc1|small=yes}} {{short description|Eleventh President of South Korea}} {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2018}} {{Infobox officeholder | name = Park Geun-hye | office = [[President of South Korea]] | native_name = {{nobold|박근혜}} | native_name_lang = ko | image = File:Korea President Park UN 20130506 01 cropped.jpg | predecessor = [[Lee Myung-bak]] | primeminister = [[Chung Hong-won]]
[[Lee Wan-koo]]
[[Choi Kyoung-hwan]] {{small|(Acting)}}
[[Hwang Kyo-ahn]] | successor = [[Moon Jae-in]] | signature = Park Geun-hye signature.svg | predecessor2 = Choe Byeong-ryeol | party = [[Liberty Korea Party|Saenuri Party]] (1997–2017)
[[Independent politician|Independent]] (2017–present){{cite news |url=http://www.yonhapnews.co.kr/politics/2017/11/03/0502000000AKR20171103139800001.HTML?template=2085 |title=한국당, '1호 당원' 박근혜 출당조치…'20년 관계' 청산 |newspaper=Yonhap News |date=3 November 2017 |access-date=3 November 2017}} | office1 = Leader of the [[Liberty Korea Party|Saenuri Party]] | predecessor1 = [[Hwang Woo-yea]] {{small|(Acting)}} | successor1 = [[Hwang Woo-yea]] | successor2 = Kim Yeong-seon {{small|(Acting)}} | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1952|02|02|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Daegu]], [[First Republic of Korea|South Korea]] | death_date = | death_place = | parents = [[Park Chung-hee]]
[[Yuk Young-soo]] | alma_mater = [[Sogang University]]
[[Joseph Fourier University]] | term_start = 25 February 2013 | term_end = 10 March 2017{{efn|name=note|Powers and duties suspended since 9 December 2016 by the [[National Assembly (South Korea)|National Assembly]] until final impeachment verdict on 10 March 2017}} | term_start1 = 19 December 2011 | term_end1 = 15 May 2012 | term_start2 = 23 March 2004 | term_end2 = 15 June 2006 | office3 = Member of the [[National Assembly (South Korea)|National Assembly]] | term_start3 = 30 May 2012 | term_end3 = 10 December 2012 | constituency3 = {{nowrap|[[List of members of the National Assembly (South Korea), 2012–2016|Proportional representation]]}} | term_start4 = 3 April 1998 | term_end4 = 29 May 2012 | constituency4 = [[Dalseong County|Dalseong]] ([[Daegu]]) | predecessor4 = Kim Suk-won | successor4 = Lee Jong-jin | office5 = [[First Lady of South Korea]]
{{small|Acting}} | president5 = [[Park Chung-hee]] | residence = [[Seoul Detention Center]] | term_label5 = In role | term_start5 = 16 August 1974 | term_end5 = 26 October 1979 | predecessor5 = [[Yuk Young-soo]] | successor5 = [[Hong Gi]] | module = {{Infobox Korean name |child = yes |hangul = {{linktext|박|근|혜}} |hanja = {{lang|ko|{{linktext|朴|槿|惠}}}} |rr = Bak Geun(-)hye |mr = Pak Kŭnhye}} }} {{Korean name|Park}} '''Park Geun-hye''' ({{Korean|박근혜|hanja=朴槿惠|rr=Bak Geun(-)hye}}; {{IPA-ko|pak‿k͈ɯn.hje|IPA}}; born 2 February 1952) is a former South Korean [[politician]] who served as the 18th [[President of South Korea]] from 2013 to 2017. Park was the first woman to be [[List of Presidents of South Korea|President of South Korea]]{{Cite news |url= http://articles.latimes.com/2012/dec/19/world/la-fg-south-korea-park-20121220 |title=South Korea elects first female president |last=Demick |first=Barbara |date=19 December 2012 |last2=Choi |first2=Jung-yoon|newspaper=Los Angeles Times |language=en-US |issn=0458-3035 |access-date=18 November 2016}} and also the first female president [[List of elected and appointed female heads of state and government|popularly elected as head of state]] in [[East Asia]]. She was also the first South Korean president to be born after the country's founding; her predecessors were either born during [[Korea under Japanese rule|Japanese rule]] or during the [[United States Army Military Government in Korea|post-World War II transitional period]]. Prior to her presidency, Park was chairwoman of the conservative Grand National Party (GNP) (which changed its name to [[Saenuri Party (2017)|Saenuri Party]] in February 2012) from 2004 to 2006 and 2011 to 2012. She was also a member of the [[National Assembly (South Korea)|National Assembly]], serving four consecutive parliamentary terms between 1998 and 2012. She started her fifth term as a representative elected by [[Party-list proportional representation|national list]] in June 2012. Her father, [[Park Chung-hee]], was the [[President of South Korea]] from 1963 to 1979, serving five consecutive terms after he [[May 16 coup|seized power in 1961]]. In 2013 and 2014, Park was ranked 11th on the [[Forbes list of The World's 100 Most Powerful Women|''Forbes'' list of the world's 100 most powerful women]] and the most powerful woman in East Asia.{{cite news |url=https://www.forbes.com/pictures/lmh45lfdj/geun-hye-park/ |title=The 25 Most Powerful Women in the World |accessdate=16 June 2014 |work=[[Forbes]]}} In 2014, she was ranked 46th on the [[Forbes list of The World's Most Powerful People|''Forbes'' list of the world's most powerful people]], the third-highest [[South Korea]]n on the list, after [[Lee Kun-hee]] and [[Lee Jae-yong (businessman)|Lee Jae-yong]]. On 9 December 2016, Park [[Impeachment of Park Geun-hye|was impeached by the National Assembly]] on charges related to [[influence peddling]] by her top aide, [[Choi Soon-sil]].{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/12/09/world/asia/south-korea-president-park-geun-hye-impeached.html |title=South Korea Parliament Votes to Impeach President Park Geun-hye|date=9 December 2016| work=[[The New York Times]] |author=Choe Sang-hun |accessdate=9 December 2016}} Her presidential powers and duties were suspended with the ratification of the impeachment. Then–[[Prime Minister of South Korea|Prime Minister]] [[Hwang Kyo-ahn]] thus assumed those powers and duties as Acting President.{{Cite web |url= http://english.yonhapnews.co.kr/national/2015/05/21/0301000000AEN20150521002600315.html |title=Park names Justice Minister Hwang Kyo-ahn as new PM |date=21 May 2015 |publisher=[[Yonhap]] |accessdate=21 May 2015}} The impeachment was upheld by the [[Constitutional Court of Korea|Constitutional Court]] via a unanimous 8–0 ruling on 10 March 2017, thereby removing Park from office.{{cite news|last1=Sang-hun|first1=Choe|title=South Korea Removes President Park Geun-hye|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/03/09/world/asia/park-geun-hye-impeached-south-korea.html|accessdate=10 March 2017|work=The New York Times|date=9 March 2017}} On 6 April 2018, Park was sentenced to 24 years in prison.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-43666134|title=Park Geun-hye: South Korea's ex-leader jailed for 24 years for corruption|publisher=BBC News|date=6 April 2018|accessdate= |language=}} Park is currently held under arrest at [[Seoul Detention Center]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/03/31/world/asia/park-geun-hye-arrest-jail-south-korea.html|title=Park Geun-hye’s Life in Jail: Cheap Meals and a Mattress on the Floor|last=Sang-hun|first=Choe|date=31 March 2017|work=The New York Times|access-date=13 May 2017|issn=0362-4331}} {{TOC limit}} == Early life and education == Park was born on 2 February 1952, in Samdeok-dong of [[Jung District, Daegu]], as the first child of [[Park Chung-hee]], the 3rd president of South Korea who served between 1963 and 1979, and [[Yuk Young-soo]]. She has a younger brother, Park Ji-man, and a younger sister, [[Park Geun-ryeong]].{{cite web |title=Candidacy of ruling party leader's sister gets cold shoulder |date=18 March 2012 |publisher=The Korea Herald |url=http://www.koreaherald.com/view.php?ud=20120318000328}} She is unmarried with no children. [[Pew Research Center]] described her as an atheist with a Buddhist and Roman Catholic upbringing.{{cite web|url=http://www.pewresearch.org/fact-tank/2014/08/12/6-facts-about-christianity-in-south-korea/|title=6 facts about South Korea's growing Christian population|date=12 August 2014|publisher=}} In addition to her native Korean, Park also speaks English, French, Spanish, and Mandarin with varying degrees of fluency.{{Citation needed|date=April 2018}} In 1953, Park's family moved to Seoul and she graduated from Seoul's Jangchung Elementary School and Sungshim (literal: Sacred Heart) Girls' Middle and High School in 1970, going on to receive a [[bachelor's degree]] in [[electronic engineering]] from [[Sogang University]] in 1974.{{citation needed|date=April 2018}} She briefly studied at [[Joseph Fourier University]], but left France following the murder of her mother.{{cite news |last=Harlan |first=Chico |date=25 January 2013 |title=South Korea's new leader, Park Geun-hye, was pushed onto political stage by tragedy |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/asia_pacific/for-s-koreas-park-after-tragedy-a-first-taste-of-power/2013/01/25/0dc9382e-5e30-11e2-90a0-73c8343c6d61_story.html |work=The Washington Post |accessdate=8 April 2018}} Park's mother was killed on 15 August 1974 in the [[National Theater of Korea]]; [[Mun Se-gwang]], a [[Koreans in Japan|Japanese-born ethnic Korean]] sympathizer of [[North Korea]] and member of the [[Chongryon]], was attempting to assassinate President Park Chung-hee.{{cite news |url=http://100.naver.com/100.nhn?docid=180730|script-title=ko:8·15대통령저격사건 (八一五大統領狙擊事件) |trans-title=15 August President assassination-attempt incident|publisher= Doopedia (두산백과)|accessdate=13 May 2012|language=Korean}} Park was regarded as [[First Lady]] until the [[assassination of Park Chung-hee|assassination of her father]] by his own intelligence chief, [[Kim Jae-gyu]], on 26 October 1979.{{cite news|title=Profile: South Korean President Park Geun-hye|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-20787271|accessdate=3 January 2018|work=[[BBC News]]|date=10 March 2017|quote=Some said the association with her father - and her experience as first lady - helped cement her win by overcoming prejudices among male voters.}}{{cite news |url=http://belfercenter.hks.harvard.edu/files/kogan-apsa-aug-2013.pdf|title=Weiner, Tim: ''Legacy of Ashes. The History of CIA''. New York, June 2007.}}{{cite book |url=https://www.amazon.com/Legacy-Ashes-The-History-CIA/dp/0307389006|title=Weiner, Tim: ''Legacy of Ashes. The History of CIA''. New York, June 2007.}} During this time, activists who were political opponents of her father claimed to be subject to arbitrary detention. Further, [[human rights in South Korea|human rights]] were considered subordinate to [[economy of South Korea|economic development]].{{cite journal |author=C. I. Eugene Kim|title=Emergency, Development, and Human Rights: South Korea| journal=Asian Survey| date=April 1978 |volume= 18|issue= 4|pages=363–78|publisher=University of California Press|url=https://www.jstor.org/discover/10.2307/2643400?uid=3739536&uid=2129&uid=2134&uid=2&uid=70&uid=4&uid=3739256&sid=21100798234751|doi=10.1525/as.1978.18.4.01p0404m}} In 2007, Park expressed regret at the treatment of activists during this period.{{cite news|url=http://english.kbs.co.kr/news/newsview_sub.php?menu=2&key=2007071913|title=Park Calls 1961 Coup 'Revolution' to Save Nation|date=19 July 2009|accessdate=13 May 2012|work=[[Korean Broadcasting System|KBS]] news|quote=She apologized for the sufferings and sacrifices of pro-democracy activists under the constitutional system, which was effective between 1972 and 1979.|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071225182651/http://english.kbs.co.kr/news/newsview_sub.php?menu=2&key=2007071913|archivedate=25 December 2007|df=dmy-all}} Park received honorary doctoral degrees from the [[Chinese Culture University]] in [[Taiwan]] in 1987, [[Pukyong National University]] and [[KAIST]] in 2008, [[Sogang University]] in 2010, and [[TU Dresden]] in 2014.{{Cite web|url=https://tu-dresden.de/tu-dresden/newsportal/news/ep_park?set_language=en|title=TU Dresden awards President of the Republic of Korea, Park Geun-hye, honorary doctorate|last=|first=|date=31 March 2014|website=|publisher=|access-date=15 June 2016}} == Career == === Assembly woman === Park was elected a Grand National Party (GNP) assemblywoman for [[Dalseong County]], Daegu, in 1998 [[by-election]], and three more times in the same electoral district between 1998 and 2008, being the incumbent assemblywoman till April 2012. In 2012, she announced that she would not run for a constituency representative seat for the 19th election in Dalseong or anywhere else, but for a proportional representative position for the Saenuri Party instead, in order to lead the party's election campaign. She was elected as a proportional representative in the [[South Korean legislative election, 2012|April 2012 election]].{{cite news |author=Chung Min-uck |date=20 March 2013 |title=Saenuri names proportional representatives |url=http://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/nation/2012/03/116_107308.html |work=Korea Times |accessdate=7 April 2018}}{{cite news |last=Fackler |first=Martin |date=20 April 2012 |title=In a Rowdy Democracy, a Dictator's Daughter With an Unsoiled Aura |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/04/21/world/asia/park-geun-hye-an-unsoiled-leader-in-south-koreas-rowdy-democracy.html |work=The New York Times |accessdate=7 April 2018}} === GNP chairwoman and "Queen of Elections" === Due to the failed attempt to impeach President [[Roh Moo-hyun]] and the bribery scandal of its 2002 presidential candidate, [[Lee Hoi-chang]] (revealed in 2004), the GNP was facing a severe defeat in the 2004 general election. Park was appointed as the chairwoman of the party and led the election efforts. In the election, the GNP lost its majority position but managed to gain 121 seats, which is largely considered a great achievement under such inhospitable circumstances for the party.{{cite web |url= http://news.naver.com/main/read.nhn?mode=LSD&mid=sec&sid1=100&oid=001&aid=0005579513 |title=총선 D-1 승패기준..영남승부 관심 |accessdate=16 October 2015}}{{cite web |url= http://biz.chosun.com/site/data/html_dir/2012/04/08/2012040800451.html |title=[증시閑담] 총선 결과에 촉각 세우는 주식시장 |accessdate=16 October 2015}} As the chairwoman of the GNP, Park helped her party make significant gains in local elections and actually obtain a majority in 2006. During the campaign, on 20 May 2006, Ji Chung-ho, a 50-year-old man with eight criminal convictions, slashed Park's face with a utility knife, causing an 11-centimeter wound that required 60 stitches and several hours of surgery.{{cite news |url= http://english.chosun.com/site/data/html_dir/2006/05/22/2006052261007.html |title=Joint Probe into Attack on GNP Chairwoman |work=Arirang News |date=22 May 2006 |accessdate=16 May 2012}}{{cite news |url= http://news.naver.com/main/read.nhn?mode=LSD&mid=sec&sid1=100&oid=038&aid=0000330425 |script-title=ko:박근혜대표 유세장서 피습 중상 |trans-title=GNP leader Park Geun-hye attacked during campaign |date=21 May 2006 |accessdate=16 May 2012 |work=Hankook Ilbo |author1=Gim Yi-sak(김이삭) |author2=Chung Min-seung(정민승) |language=Korean}} A famous anecdote from this incident occurred when Park was hospitalized after the attack. The first word that she said to her secretary after her recovery from her wound was "How is [[Daejeon]]?" After this, the candidate from the Grand National Party won the election for mayor of the city of Daejeon despite having trailed by more than 20 percentage points in opinion polls up to the point of the attack. In addition, during her term as the GNP chairwoman between 2004 and 2006, the party won all 40 reelections and by-elections held, which was largely credited to her influence and efforts. This feat gave Park a nickname "Queen of Elections".{{cite web|url=http://news.naver.com/main/read.nhn?mode=LSD&mid=sec&sid1=100&oid=009&aid=0000506402|title=대전 "박근혜 생각하면 결심이 흔들려요"|publisher=}}{{cite news |url= http://news.naver.com/main/read.nhn?mode=LSD&mid=sec&sid1=100&oid=001&aid=0005298622 |script-title=ko:박근혜, 野시절 `40대 0 신화'.이번엔?|trans-title=Park Geun-hye scored 40 to 0 as the opposition. How about this time? |date=4 October 2011 |accessdate=16 May 2012 |work=[[Yonhap News]] |author=Kim Nam-kwon (김남권) |language=Korean}}{{cite news |url= http://news.naver.com/main/read.nhn?mode=LSD&mid=sec&sid1=100&oid=003&aid=0004415188 |script-title=ko:'선거의 여왕' 박근혜, 총선에서 뒷심 발휘할까? |trans-title='Queen of elections' Park Geun-hye, Could she wield her magic again in April? |date=29 March 2012 |accessdate=16 May 2012 | language=Korean |work=NewsIs |author=Kim Min-ja(김민자)}} On 12 February 2007, Park made a much-publicized visit to [[Harvard University]] in [[Cambridge, Massachusetts]], United States. Her visit culminated in an address to a packed audience at the [[John F. Kennedy School of Government]], where she said she wanted to save Korea and advocated a stronger relationship between [[South Korea–United States relations|South Korea and the United States]].{{cite news |url= http://www.thecrimson.com/article.aspx?ref=516993 |title=Politician Wants To 'Save' Korea: South Korean National Assembly member advocates alliance with United States |date= 13 February 2007 |accessdate=16 May 2012 |work=The Harvard Crimson}}{{cite web |url=http://www.icasinc.org/2007/2007l/2007lghp.html |title=The Republic of Korea and the United States:Our Future Together |date=21 February 2007 |accessdate=16 May 2012 |work=Institute for Corean-American Studies, Inc.|quote=An Address Delivered at the ARCO (John F. Kennedy Jr.) Forum, John F. Kennedy School of Government Harvard University}} === 2007 Presidential bid === Park hoped to emulate her father's success by becoming the presidential nominee of the Grand National Party. She eventually lost to [[Lee Myung-bak]] by a narrow margin. Lee had a commanding lead at the beginning of the primary season, but Park was able to narrow the gap through allegations of Lee's corruption. Park won the "party members' bid", but she lost the "national bid", which is a larger percentage of the total presidential bid.{{Citation needed|date=April 2018}} === 2008 general election === After the [[South Korean presidential election, 2007|2007 presidential election]], President Lee Myung-bak formed a government of mostly close supporters.{{cite news| url=http://topics.nytimes.com/top/reference/timestyuopics/people/l/lee_myung_bak/index.html | title= Lee Myung-bak | work= The New York Times| date= 25 July 2012 | accessdate=13 November 2012}} Park's supporters argued that this was a kind of political reprisal, and that they should secede from the Grand National Party.{{cite news | url= http://spearheadresearch.org/SR_CMS/index.php/internationalaffairssecuirty/south-korea-park-likely-to-be-first-female-president | archive-url= https://archive.is/20130416011926/http://spearheadresearch.org/SR_CMS/index.php/internationalaffairssecuirty/south-korea-park-likely-to-be-first-female-president | dead-url= yes | archive-date= 16 April 2013 | title= South Korea: Park Likely to be First Female President | work= Spearhead Research | date= 28 August 2012 | accessdate= 13 November 2012 }} Eventually, they formed parties named [[Pro-Park Coalition]] and Solidarity for Pro-Park Independents (친박 무소속 연대; ''Chin Park Musosok Yeondae''). Park herself did not join them, but indirectly supported them by announcing "I hope these people will come back alive." After the mass secession, the rebels announced that they would rejoin GNP after the general election, but the GNP prohibited it. In the following [[South Korean legislative election, 2008|2008 general election]], the rebels won 26 seats: 14 from the Pro-Park Coalition and 12 as independents. Together, they played a pivotal role in the GNP's narrow majority. Park continually insisted that GNP should allow the return of her supporters. As of 2011, most of these rebels had returned to the GNP, resulting in approximately 50 to 60 assembly members who support Park out of 171 in the GNP.{{Citation needed|date=April 2018}} === Head of Saenuri Party === As a response to the dwindling approval rating of the GNP, the party formed an emergency committee and changed the name of the political party from the Grand National Party to the ''Saenuri'' Party, meaning "New Frontier" Party. On 19 December 2011, Park was appointed as the chairwoman of GNP's Emergency Committee, the [[de facto]] leader of the party.{{Citation needed|date=April 2018}} === 2012 parliamentary election === The Saenuri Party achieved a surprise win against the opposing [[Democratic United Party]] in the 2012 General Election, winning 152 seats and retaining its majority position. Because of the corruption scandals of the Lee administration revealed before the election, the Saenuri Party was widely expected to win no more than 100 seats.{{cite news| url= http://www.hani.co.kr/arti/politics/politics_general/527972.html |script-title=ko:‘선거의 여왕’ 화려한 귀환...수도권·젊은층에선 한계 |trans-title=Return of Queen of election. Park also showed her limit among capital area voters and the youth |date=12 April 2012 |accessdate=16 May 2012 |work=[[The Hankyoreh]] |language=Korean |author=Sung Yeon-chul(성연철)}} During the 13-day campaign period, Park traveled about {{cvt| 7200|km|mi }} around South Korea, visiting more than 100 constituencies.{{cite news|url=http://article.joinsmsn.com/news/article/article.asp?total_id=7895558&ctg=1000 |script-title=ko:'청바지 유세' 고개 흔들던 박근혜, 30분 뒤 |trans-title=Park Geun-hye shook head for wearing jeans, but after 30 minutes changed her mind |date=14 April 2012 |accessdate=16 May 2012 |language=Korean |work=[[JoongAng Ilbo]] |author1=Kim Jeong-ha(김정하) |author2=Hur Jin(허진) |author3=Sohn Guk-hee(손국희) |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130523105824/http://article.joinsmsn.com/news/article/article.asp?total_id=7895558&ctg=1000 |archivedate=23 May 2013 |df= }} It is the consensus of Korean news media and political experts that the most important factor leading to Saenuri Party's victory was Park's leadership. For this reason, the 2012 election was often dubbed the "return of the Queen of Election".{{cite news|url=http://www.edaily.co.kr/news/NewsRead.edy?SCD=DA32&newsid=01787606596478848&DCD=A01503&OutLnkChk=Y|script-title=ko:'여왕의 화려한 귀환' 박근혜가 돌아왔다|trans-title=Return of Queen of election, Park Geun-hye returned as GNP leader|date=15 December 2011|accessdate=16 May 2012|language=Korean|author=Kim Sung-gon(김성곤)|work=Edaily News}} Saenuri's defeat in the populous Seoul metropolitan area in this election, however, revealed the limitation of Park's political influence. === 2012 presidential campaign === {{Main|South Korean presidential election, 2012}} Park had been the leading candidate for the [[South Korean presidential election, 2012|2012 presidential election]] in every national-level poll in South Korea between 2008, when the Lee Myung-bak administration began, and September 2011, with an approval rating of 25% to 45%, more than twice that of the second candidate. Park's approval rating was highest when the 2008 National Assembly election showed her strong influence and lowest in early 2010 as a result of her political stance against the Lee administration in [[Sejong City]] issue.{{cite news|url=http://news.naver.com/main/read.nhn?mode=LSD&mid=sec&sid1=100&oid=001&aid=0005258502| script-title=ko:박근혜 대세론 `휘청'..스타일 변화 모색|trans-title=Park Geun-hye's top candidate position is challenged. needs to change her style|date=8 September 2011|accessdate=16 May 2012|work=[[Yonhap News]]|author=Kim Hwa-young(김화영)|language=Korean|quote=Faced with rising [[Ahn Cheol-soo]]'s approval rate, Park Geun-hye's leadership is in question. Sending messages wouldn't be enough, and she must increase her appearance in public. Park will try to tackle the center. [安風에 대세론 제동 걸려..정치적 시험대 올라. `메시지 정치'서 `현장정치'로..중도층 공략 본격화 예상]}} In September 2011, [[Ahn Cheol-soo]], a former venture IT businessman and the Dean of Graduate School of Convergence Science and Technology at [[Seoul National University]], emerged as a strong independent candidate for the presidency. In national-level presidential polls in September 2011, Ahn and Park Geun Hye closely competed for the status of front-runner, with Park losing the top seat in some polls for the first time since 2008.{{cite news|url=http://news.naver.com/main/read.nhn?mode=LSD&mid=sec&sid1=100&oid=001&aid=0005260480|script-title=ko:박근혜-안철수, 여론조사 `엎치락뒤치락'|trans-title=Poll: Park Geun-hye and An Cheol-soo are in fierce competition|date=10 September 2011|accessdate=16 May 2012|language=Korean|work=[[Yonhap News]]|author=Kim Nam-kwon(김남권)|quote=All eyes on public opinion after [[Chuseok]] holiday. [추석 연휴 직후 `민심 향배'에 이목 집중]}} After her victory in the 2012 General Election, Park's approval rating increased significantly. In a national-level survey by Mono Research on 30 August[http://www.kmobile.co.kr/k_mnews/news/news_view.asp?tableid=IT&idx=405228 박근혜 컨벤션 효과...안철수 지지율도 동반상승] in 2012, {{ko icon}} Park was the top presidential candidate with an approval rating of 45.5% when competing with all potential candidates, and according to another recent national survey result, had a higher approval rating (50.6%) than Ahn (43.9%) in a two-way competition with him as of 11 September.{{cite web|url=http://joongang.joinsmsn.com/article/936/9313936.html?ctg=1000&joongang|title=home survey 2012 survey by Realmeter|publisher=joongang.joinsmsn.com|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130126211012/http://joongang.joinsmsn.com/article/936/9313936.html?ctg=1000&joongang|archivedate=26 January 2013|df=dmy-all}} On 10 July, Park formally announced her 2012 presidential bid at the Time Square, [[Yeongdeungpo District]], Seoul. In this event she emphasized the right to pursue happiness, a democratic economy, and customized welfare services for the Korean people.{{cite web|url=http://news.donga.com/3/all/20120710/47651073/1|title=박근혜 대선 출마선언…대선레이스 본격 점화|publisher=news.donga.com}} The opposing Democratic Party elected [[Moon Jae-in]] as its presidential candidate on 17 September, while Ahn Cheol-soo announced his presidential bid on 19 September. Although still a leading candidate, Park had a lower approval rating than both Ahn and Moon when engaged in two-way competition, according to a 22 September national survey.{{cite web|url=http://joongang.joinsmsn.com/article/367/9398367.html?ctg=1000&joongang|title=home survey 2012 survey by Realmeter|publisher=joongang.joinsmsn.com|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130126235525/http://joongang.joinsmsn.com/article/367/9398367.html?ctg=1000&joongang|archivedate=26 January 2013|df=dmy-all}} She was elected as the President of the Republic of Korea on 19 December 2012 with the approval of 51.6% of Korean voters.{{cite news |last=Harlan |first=Chico |date=19 December 2012 |title=Park Geun-hye wins South Korea's presidential election |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/asia_pacific/park-geun-hye-leads-in-south-koreas-presidential-election/2012/12/19/783398d4-49e6-11e2-b6f0-e851e741d196_story.html |work=The Washington Post |accessdate=8 April 2018}} In 2017, the NSI has admitted it conducted an illicit campaign to influence the South Korea's 2012 presidential election, mobilising teams of experts in psychological warfare to ensure that the conservative candidate, Park Geun-hye, beat her liberal rival [[Moon Jae-in]].{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/aug/04/south-koreas-spy-agency-admits-trying-rig-election-national-intelligence-service-2012|title=South Korea spy agency admits trying to rig 2012 presidential election|first=Justin|last=McCurry|date=4 August 2017|website=the Guardian}} === Positions === [[File:KOCIS CheongWaDae Children Day 02 (8713947728).jpg|thumb|President Park Geun-hye (center) smiles and shows a portrait drawn by a girl in Cheong Wa Dae, Seoul, at [[Children's Day]] 5 May 2013]] In a 2012 survey by Korean Research assessing the political stance of 12 potential presidential candidates of South Korea, Park was considered the most conservative candidate.{{cite web|url=http://news.hankooki.com/lpage/politics/201206/h2012060802354721000.htm |title=한국아이닷컴! |publisher= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120608101501/http://news.hankooki.com/lpage/politics/201206/h2012060802354721000.htm |archivedate= 8 June 2012 |df= }} Her conservative, market-oriented political stance was well reflected in her campaign pledge for 2008 presidential bid to cut taxes, reduce regulation, and establish strong law and order.{{cite web|url=http://news.mk.co.kr/newsRead.php?year=2012&no=230947|title=2007년, 줄푸세·시장주의 → 2012년, 맞춤형 복지·경제민주화|publisher=}} Since 2009, however, Park started to focus more on welfare issues, advocating customized welfare services to the South Korean people. Park is well known for her strict, no-compromise adherence to political promises. In 2010, for example, she successfully stopped the Lee administration's attempt to cancel the plan to establish [[Sejong City]], a new national center of administration, arguing the plan was a promise made to people. This conflict between Park and Lee Administration cost her a considerable decrease in her approval rating at the time.{{cite web|url=http://nanumnews.com/sub_read.html?uid=17379§ion=sc201|title=[나눔뉴스] "세종시 피로감에 박근혜 지지율 하락세"|publisher=nanumnews.com}} In 2012, Park also vowed to construct a new airport in the southeastern region, a 2008 presidential campaign promise made by GNP but cancelled in 2011, despite claims of economic infeasibility of the plan.{{cite web|url=http://www.imaeil.com/sub_news/sub_news_view.php?news_id=9929&yy=2012|title=2012 Maeil Sinmoon article|publisher=imaeil.com}} The administrative vision of President Park Geun-hye's new government is "a new era of hope and happiness".
