The five Administrative Goals of the government are "a jobs-centered creative economy", "tailored employment and welfare", "creativity-oriented education and cultural enrichment", "a safe and united society" and "strong security measures for sustainable peace on the Korean Peninsula". The Park Geun-hye administration plans to create a trustworthy, clean, and capable government through carrying out these goals, related strategies, and tasks.{{cite web|url=http://www.korea.net/Government/Current-Affairs/National-Affairs?affairId=346|title=Korea.net : The official website of the Republic of Korea|first=Korean Culture and Information Service|last=(KOCIS)|publisher=korea.net}} Park chose not to vote in the [[South Korean presidential election, 2017|2017 South Korean presidential election]].{{cite news |url=http://www.koreaherald.com/view.php?ud=20170509000419 |publisher=''[[The Korea Herald]]'' |title=Did jailed ex-president Park Geun-hye use her vote? |date=9 May 2017 |access-date=13 May 2017 |first=Hyun-ju |last=Ock |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170514025809/http://www.koreaherald.com/view.php?ud=20170509000419 |archive-date=14 May 2017 |quote=According to local news reports, she gave up her right to vote as she did not ask for an absentee ballot, which is provided to inmates in detention facilities.}} == Presidency (2013–17) == === Inauguration === Park became the 18th president of South Korea on 25 February 2013. At midnight, she took over all presidential authorities including the prerogative of supreme command of South Korea's armed forces from her predecessor Lee Myung-bak. In her inauguration speech at the National Assembly building, Park spoke of her plan to open a new era of hope through "economic prosperity, people's happiness, and cultural enrichment". She particularly expressed her hope that North Korea would give up its nuclear arms and walk on the path of peace and mutual development, and declared that the foundation for a happy era of unification in which all Korean people will be able to enjoy prosperity and freedom and realize their dreams would be built through the Korean Peninsula Trust-building Process. In her inauguration speech, Park presented four guiding principles to realize her administrative vision: economic prosperity, people's happiness, cultural enrichment, and establishment of foundation for peaceful unification.[http://news1.kr/articles/1024223 News1 Korea: President's Inaugural Address] {{ko icon}} Park's inauguration ceremony was the largest one in South Korean history with 70,000 participants. Diplomatic representatives in Korea as well as high-level delegates specially sent from 24 countries around the world including Thai Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra, U.S. National Security Advisor Thomas Donilon, Taiwanese Legislative Speaker Wang Jin-pyng and former Japanese Prime Minister Yasuo Fukuda also participated in the event to congratulate Park.{{cite web|url= http://www.koreaherald.com/view.php?ud=20130224000257 |title=Park's swearing-in draws record 70,000 participants |author= |publisher=The Korea Herald |accessdate=16 October 2015}}{{cite web |url= http://www.chinapost.com.tw/taiwan/foreign-affairs/2013/02/26/371364/Legislative-Speaker.htm |title=Legislative Speaker Wang attends S. Korea president's inauguration |publisher=[[China Post]] |accessdate=29 October 2016}} === First year (February 2013 – February 2014) === ==== Administrative philosophy ==== The goal of the newly launched Park Geun-hye Administration for governing state affairs is to open "a new era of hope and happiness for all the people". Park avowed that South Korea will break away from its long-pursued development model that centers around the nation, and shift the focus of government administration from the state to individual citizens. Through this process the structure of co-prosperity, in which the citizens become happy and as a result the nation develops, will be created. Park's administrative vision and basic principles for governing the nation are concretely outlined in her policy plans for the economy, society, welfare, diplomacy, and unification. The administration's keywords in managing state affairs are "people", "happiness", "trust", "co-prosperity" and "principle".{{cite web|url=http://english.president.go.kr/government/philosophy/philosophy.php |title=THE REPUBLIC OF KOREA CHEONG WA DAE |publisher= |accessdate=16 October 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131208001650/http://english.president.go.kr/government/philosophy/philosophy.php |archivedate= 8 December 2013 |df= }} ==== Government restructuring ==== Right after taking office, Park restructured the Blue House and government organization to carry out her administrative vision. The Office of National Security at the Blue House, Ministry of Science, ICT and Future Planning, and Ministry of Oceans and Fisheries were newly launched, and the seat of Deputy Prime Minister for Economic Affairs was revived. The Chief of the National Security Office would act as a "control tower" for diplomatic, security, and national defense issues, and the Deputy Prime Minister for Economic Affairs for economic, social, and welfare issues.{{cite web|url=http://news.dongascience.com/PHP/NewsView.php?kisaid=20130116100000000656&classcode=0101|title=THE SCIENCE : [박근혜정부 조직개편안]미래部, 성장동력 창출… 부총리는 정책 총괄|publisher=|accessdate=16 October 2015}} ==== Foreign policy ==== ===== United States ===== [[File:Park Geun-Hye meeting with Barack Obama.jpg|thumb|Park Geun-hye at a bilateral meeting with [[President of the United States|U.S. President]] [[Barack Obama]] on 7 May 2013]] After taking office, Park met with John Kerry and U.S. President Barack Obama. Park's trip to the United States in May 2013 was her first foreign trip after taking office.{{cite news |last1=Wilson |first1=Scott |last2=DeYoung |first2=Karen |date=7 May 2013 |title=Obama, South Korea's Park present united front against North Korea at joint appearance |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/obama-south-koreas-park-present-united-front-against-north-korea-at-joint-appearance/2013/05/07/e06767f8-b743-11e2-92f3-f291801936b8_story.html |work=The Washington Post |accessdate=8 April 2018}} Like many of her predecessors, Park has maintained a close relationship with the U.S., which has over [[United States Forces Korea|20,000 soldiers stationed in South Korea]]. During her visit to the U.S., she addressed a joint session of the U.S. Congress, where she called for a united front against any North Korean provocations. Park also called for a strong global relationship between South Korea and the United States.{{cite web|url=http://news.sbs.co.kr/section_news/news_read.jsp?news_id=N1001774050|title=SBS 뉴스 :: 리다이렉트 페이지|publisher=|accessdate=16 October 2015}} Park assesses the security situation on the Korean Peninsula and emphasized that deterrence capabilities were the most important factor for security. Thus, Park considers the American-South Korean alliance as the most successful one in the world. And she hopes the American-South Korean relationship can be upgraded from a comprehensive strategic alliance to a global partnership.{{cite web|url=http://www.korea.net/NewsFocus/Policies/view?articleID=113093|title=Korea.net : The official website of the Republic of Korea|author=Korean Culture and Information Service (KOCIS)|publisher=|accessdate=16 October 2015}} Park visited the United States on her first overseas trip as president. She traveled to Washington, D.C., New York City, and Los Angeles on 5–9 May 2013.{{cite web|url=http://english.president.go.kr/pre_activity/latest/latest_view.php?uno=7800 |title=THE REPUBLIC OF KOREA CHEONG WA DAE |publisher= |accessdate=16 October 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131203194837/http://english.president.go.kr/pre_activity/latest/latest_view.php?uno=7800 |archivedate= 3 December 2013 |df= }} During summit talks in May at the White House, Presidents Park and Obama adopted a joint declaration for the American-South Korean alliance and discussed ways to further develop the bilateral relations in a future-forward manner. Also, two leaders discussed ways to promote cooperation in building peace in the Northeast Asian region and strength the partnership between Seoul and Washington.{{cite web|url=http://www.korea.net/NewsFocus/Policies/view?articleID=107794|title=Korea.net : The official website of the Republic of Korea|author=Korean Culture and Information Service (KOCIS)|publisher=|accessdate=16 October 2015}} The two leaders of South Korea and the United States agreed to adopt a joint statement on comprehensive energy cooperation to build a foundation for a future growth engine and establish a policy cooperation committee on information and communication technology. In addition, President Park urged her U.S. counterpart to expand the annual U.S. visa quota for South Korean professionals in order to promote co-development of both economies. In particular, the "Joint declaration in commemoration of the 60th anniversary of the Alliance between the Republic of Korea and the United States of America" adopted by South Korea and the United States will become a meaningful document looking back at the past six decades of the alliance and spelling out a new direction for the development of bilateral relations over the coming decade.{{cite web|url=http://english.president.go.kr/pre_activity/speeches/speeches_view.php?board_no=E03&uno=7820 |title=THE REPUBLIC OF KOREA CHEONG WA DAE |publisher= |accessdate=16 October 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131204055451/http://english.president.go.kr/pre_activity/speeches/speeches_view.php?board_no=E03&uno=7820 |archivedate= 4 December 2013 |df= }} ===== North Korea ===== North Korea had engaged in provocations such as violating a UN Security Council resolution and firing a long-range missile on 12 December 2012, just before 19 December presidential election. After Park was elected, North Korea conducted its third nuclear test 12 February 2013, nullified the non-aggression agreements between the two countries on 8 March and withdrew North Korean workers from the Kaesong Industrial Complex on 8 April.{{cite news| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-pacific-15278612 | work=BBC News | title=North Korea profile | date=26 March 2014}} Park maintained her stance that South Korea will not succumb to the North's provocations and threats, and will endeavor to elicit policy coordination towards North Korea with major powers such as the United States, China and the UN.{{cite web|url=http://www.heritage.org/research/reports/2013/04/the-us-should-support-new-south-korean-presidents-approach-to-north-korea|title=South Korean President Park Geun-hye's North Korean Strategy|work=The Heritage Foundation|accessdate=16 October 2015}} Her response to North Korean issues gained the support of many South Koreans and also the United States, China, and Russia, and played a significant role in the unanimous adoption by the UN Security Council of Resolution 2094 regarding North Korea on 7 March 2013.{{cite web|url=http://csis.org/publication/un-security-council-passes-new-resolution-2094-north-korea|title=UN Security Council Passes New Resolution 2094 on North Korea|publisher=|accessdate=16 October 2015}} Due to Park's response and the international community's actions, on 6 June North Korea ceased provocations and threats towards the South and suggested holding discussions on reopening the Kaesong Industrial Complex.{{cite web|url=http://www.yonhapnews.co.kr/bulletin/2013/06/06/0200000000AKR20130606082000014.HTML|title=北, 남북 당국간 회담 전격 제의…정부 '수용'|publisher=|accessdate=16 October 2015}} Park said that peace and unification on the Korean peninsula is the wish of all 70 million Koreans and that as president she will do her utmost to meet such a goal. As well, "the ultimate objective of reunification efforts is to improve the quality of life of people in both Koreas, to further expand freedom and human rights, and [from there] build a prosperous Korean Peninsula."{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-34876444|title=North and South Korea to hold talks next week|publisher=BBC|accessdate=16 December 2015}} She later stated, "to open a new era of peace and hope on the peninsula, North Korea needs to accept her administration's trust building policy initiative".{{cite web|url=http://english.yonhapnews.co.kr/national/2013/06/06/25/0301000000AEN20130606002500315F.HTML|title=(LEAD) S. Korean president calls on Pyongyang to accept 'trust building' process|publisher=|accessdate=16 October 2015}}{{cite news| url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/south-korean-president-park-geun-hye-answers-questions/2013/05/07/d7482e5a-b761-11e2-b94c-b684dda07add_story.html|work=[[The Washington Post]] | title=South Korean President Park Geun-hye answers questions|date=7 May 2013}} Park's policy vision and initiative on issues concerning North Korea and unification are reflected in her Korean Peninsula Trust-building Process. The Ministry of Unification has announced a new vision statement "realizing a new unified Korea that ensures everyone's happiness". The administrative tasks for this cause include normalizing inter-Korean relations through a trust-building process, embarking on small-scale unification projects that will lead to a complete integration of the two Koreas, and taking practical measures to prepare for unification by strengthening unification capabilities.{{cite web|url=http://eng.unikorea.go.kr/CmsWeb/viewPage.req?idx=PG0000000694|title=unikorea|first=|last=asadal|publisher=eng.unikorea.go.kr}} According to Park, peaceful unification will be achieved in a three-stage unification initiative: starting from securing peace, going through economic integration, and finally reaching political integration. To achieve sustainable peace by the initiative, the new administration will offer humanitarian assistance for the people in North Korea, inter-Korean exchange and cooperation in economic, social and cultural areas, and will apply 'Vision Korea project' for establishing a single economic community in the Korean Peninsula, conditioned on sufficient mutual trust and progress in denuclearizing North Korea.{{cite web|url=http://csis.org/publication/trust-underlying-philosophy-park-geun-hye-administration|title=Trust - The Underlying Philosophy of the Park Geun-Hye Administration|publisher=|accessdate=16 October 2015}} ===== China ===== [[File:Korea China Press Conference 20130627 03.jpg|thumb|Park Geun-hye and Chinese President [[Xi Jinping]], Beijing, 27 June 2013]] On 27–30 June 2013, Park visited China with a South Korean delegation, where she met with [[Xi Jinping]], the Chinese president. During the meetings, Park explained the government's stance on North Korea and gained his support.{{cite web|url=http://news.sbs.co.kr/section_news/news_read.jsp?news_id=N1001856266|title=SBS 뉴스 :: 리다이렉트 페이지|publisher=|accessdate=16 October 2015}} ===== Russia ===== On 13 November 2013, Park held an extended summit with President Vladimir Putin, whose visit to South Korea was the first among leaders of 4 major powers including the United States, China, and Japan. During the summit, Park and Putin had a comprehensive and productive dialogue with focus on improving economic relations such as logistics cooperation projects (through Russia and North Korea), expanding people-to-people exchanges, and strengthening political ties between South Korea and Russia. Park, especially, emphasized on making preparations to produce an outcome that corresponds to common interests by combining Korea's Eurasian Initiative and Russia's Asia-Pacific Policy. After the summit, both presidents issued a joint communique and held a joint press conference.{{cite web|url=http://english.yonhapnews.co.kr/national/2013/11/12/10/0301000000AEN20131112007053315F.html|title=(3rd LD) S. Korea to participate in Russian-led rail, port development project in N. Korea|publisher=|accessdate=16 October 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www1.president.go.kr/news/newsList.php?srh%5Byear%5D=2013&srh%5Bmonth%5D=11&srh%5Bpage%5D=3&srh%5Bview_mode%5D=detail&srh%5Bseq%5D=325&srh%5Bdetail_no%5D=37 |title=대한민국 청와대 |publisher=president.go.kr |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140102192925/http://www1.president.go.kr/news/newsList.php?srh%5Byear%5D=2013&srh%5Bmonth%5D=11&srh%5Bpage%5D=3&srh%5Bview_mode%5D=detail&srh%5Bseq%5D=325&srh%5Bdetail_no%5D=37 |archivedate=2 January 2014 |df= }} Earlier, Park attended the G-20 Summit at St. Petersburg in September 2013, where she met Putin for a separate dialogue discussing economic cooperation and seeking support on North Korean issues. It marked the first Korea-Russia summit talk since Park's inauguration.{{cite web|url=http://english.yonhapnews.co.kr/news/2013/09/07/13/0200000000AEN20130907000100315F.html|title=Park seeks Russia's support in resolving North Korean nuclear standoff|publisher=|accessdate=16 October 2015}} When Park met with Russian Minister for the Development of Russian Far East Viktor Ishaev, who headed the Russian delegation to Park's inaugural ceremony, she stated that Russia is one of Korea's key strategic partners, and the successful launch of the Naro rocket is the outcome of mutually beneficial relations and demonstrates that relations will grow stronger in the future. She also noted that Russia's active participation in the six-party talks will contribute to alleviating tension on the Korean Peninsula.{{cite web|url=http://www.rg.ru/2013/02/26/reg-dfo/ishaev-anons.html|title=Виктор Ишаев пригласил корейцев к совместному освоению космоса|work=Российская газета|accessdate=16 October 2015}} ==== Economic policy ==== Park announced her plan to build a "Creative Economy" on 5 June 2013, representing her vision for economic revival and job creation.{{cite web|url=http://www.msip.go.kr/UserBbs_bbsDetail.action?bbsId%3D72%26bbsNo%3D810%26bbsType%3Ddefault%26manuId%3D128%26insteadMenuId%3D0 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=21 August 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130819054534/http://www.msip.go.kr/UserBbs_bbsDetail.action?bbsId=72 |archivedate=19 August 2013 |df= }} In April, Park said "Timing is very important for our economic policy, jobs and livelihood mainly ordinary people should organize a supplementary budget in a timely manner."{{cite web|url = http://news.naver.com/main/read.nhn?mode=LSD&mid=sec&sid1=100&oid=034&aid=0002478911|title = 박근혜 대통령, "일자리·서민 위주로 조속히 추경 편성"|date = 3 April 2013|accessdate = 3 April 2013}} On 8 April 2014, Park signed the [[Australia–Korea Free Trade Agreement]] with Australia's Prime Minister [[Tony Abbott]].[http://www.abc.net.au/news/2014-04-08/australia-signs-south-korea-trade-deal/5375600 Australia signs free trade agreement with South Korea in Seoul]; ABC; 8 April 2014 ==== Social policy ==== Park has proposed as one item on the national agenda the eradication of "Four Major Social Evils" (사 대회악: "sa dae hwe ak") – sexual violence, domestic violence, school violence and unsafe food. Statistics show that sexual violence and domestic violence are increasing in these years. Without referring to statistical data, aggravating school violence or food safety is a public concern in South Korea.{{cite web|url=http://koreajoongangdaily.joinsmsn.com/news/article/Article.aspx?aid=2972066|archive-url=https://archive.is/20130609085225/http://koreajoongangdaily.joinsmsn.com/news/article/Article.aspx?aid=2972066|dead-url=yes|archive-date=9 June 2013|title=The zeitgeist: Rooting out social vices|date=24 May 2013|publisher=JoongAng Ilbo}}{{cite web|script-title=ko:4대 사회악 근절 위한 추진본부 발족시킬 것|trans-title=Four Major Social Evils promotion headquarter will be established|url=http://www.hani.co.kr/arti/politics/bluehouse/578152.html|date=14 March 2013|publisher=The Hankyoreh|language=Korean}} She also launched the National Unity Committee on 17 June with the purpose to advise the president in the process of resolving various conflicts in South Korean society and establishing a culture of co-existence and co-prosperity. Former Democratic United Party Advisor Han Kwang -ok was named as the head.{{cite web|url=http://news.donga.com/BestClick/3/all/20130617/55918735/1|title=국민대통합위 오늘 출범…초대 위원장에 한광옥|publisher=|accessdate=16 October 2015}} ==== National ==== On 18 May 2013, President Park Geun-hye attended the 33rd anniversary of the [[Gwangju massacre]], and gave voice to sorrow for the victims' family members.{{cite web|url=http://koreajoongangdaily.joinsmsn.com/news/article/Article.aspx?aid=2971803 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130615204436/http://koreajoongangdaily.joinsmsn.com/news/article/Article.aspx?aid=2971803 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=15 June 2013 |title=Park attends memorial of Gwangju massacre |author=Kang Jin-kyu |publisher=[[Joongang Daily]] |date=20 May 2013 |accessdate=20 May 2013 }} === Second year (February 2014 – February 2015) === [[File:Korea US President Obama Visiting 18 (14045206364).jpg|thumb|190px|Park Geun-hye and U.S. President [[Barack Obama]], 25 April 2014]] ==== Foreign policy ==== ===== North Korea ===== Park proposed three steps to North Korea to help move toward the reunification of the Korean Peninsula, on 28 March in Dresden during her state visit to Germany.{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2014-03-25/park-looks-to-once-divided-germany-to-spur-korean-reunification.html|title=Park Says Once-Divided Germany Is Model for Korea Reunification|date=26 March 2014|work=Bloomberg.com|accessdate=16 October 2015}} And marking the Korean Peninsula's liberation from Japan's colonial rule Friday (8.15), President Park said, as anguish from the two Koreas' separation passes from one generation to the next, abnormalities on the divided peninsula have become the norm. The South Korean president then highlighted the urgent need to increase understanding and to help merge the lives of South and North Koreans for reunification. "Starting with jointly managing rivers and forests running through the two Koreas, we need to expand joint projects that benefit both sides. In that respect, I hope North Korea will attend the UN Convention on Biological Diversity conference to be held in South Korean city of Pyeongchang in October."{{cite web|url=http://www.arirang.co.kr/News/News_View.asp?nSeq=166779|title=News View - The World On Arirang|author=arirang, Arirang International Broadcasting Foundation|publisher=|accessdate=16 October 2015}} President Park Geun-hye has warned that a new nuclear test by North Korea could lead to, "a nuclear domino effect", that might provide its neighbors with a pretext to arm themselves with nuclear weapons, as she sat down with Wall Street Journal Managing Editor Gerard Baker in Seoul on 28 May.[http://www.nti.org/gsn/article/south-korean-president-warns-regional-domino-effect-if-north-detonates-nuke-device S. Korean Leader Warns of 'Nuclear Domino' if North Conducts Test (May 30, 2014), ''NTI''] ==== Government restructuring ==== On 18 May 2014, Park announced South Korea's "plans to break up its coastguard" after failing to respond well during the [[sinking of MV Sewol|MV ''Sewol'' ferry disaster]].{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-27465378#TWEET1132272 |title=BBC News — South Korea to break up coastguard after ferry disaster |publisher=BBC |date=1 January 1970 |accessdate=21 May 2014}} According to Park, "investigation and information roles would be transferred to the South Korea National Police while the rescue and salvage operation and ocean security roles would be transferred to the Department for National Safety, not to be confused with the Korean [[Ministry of Security and Public Administration]], which will be newly established".{{cite web|url=http://www.cnn.com/2014/05/18/world/asia/south-korea-coast-guard/|title=South Korean president dismantles coast guard after ferry disaster|author=K.J. Kwon, Paula Hancocks and Jethro Mullen, CNN|date=19 May 2014|work=CNN|accessdate=16 October 2015}} On 19 November 2014, the [[Korea Coast Guard]] and [[National Emergency Management Agency]] ceased control as the [[Ministry of Public Safety and Security]] was founded at the same day.{{cite news |date=18 November 2014 |title=South Korea launches new safety agency |url=http://www.sandiegouniontribune.com/sdut-south-korea-launches-new-safety-agency-2014nov18-story.html |work=[[San Diego Union-Tribune]] |agency=Associated Press |accessdate=8 April 2018}} === Third year (February 2015 – February 2016) === ==== Foreign policy ==== [[File:Presidente da Coreia do Sul, Park Geun-hye, visita o Brasil.jpg|thumb|Park Geun-hye with then-president of [[Brazil]] [[Dilma Rousseff]] ]] ===== China ===== On 26 May 2015, Park urged the head of the [[Asian Development Bank]] to cooperate with South Korea and the China-led [[Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank]]{{cite news|title=Park calls for cooperation with China-led AIIB|url=http://english.yonhapnews.co.kr/national/2015/05/26/9/0301000000AEN20150526009300315F.html|accessdate=12 June 2015|agency=Yonhap News Agency|date=26 May 2015}} after South Korea had officially applied to join the Chinese-led [[Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank]] in late March 2015.{{cite news|last1=Jun|first1=Kwanwoo|last2=Gale|first2=Alastair|title=South Korea Says It Will Join China-Led Investment Bank|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/south-korea-says-it-will-join-china-led-asia-infrastructure-investment-bank-1427373167|accessdate=12 June 2015|agency=The Wall Street Journal|date=26 March 2015}} === Fourth and Fifth year (February 2016 – March 2017) === ==== Foreign policy ==== ===== Iran ===== [[File:South Korean President Park Geun-hye arrived in Iran, Mehrabad Airport, Tehran 07.jpg|thumb|Park Geun-hye being welcomed by Iran's business minister, [[Mohammad Reza Nematzadeh]] in [[Mehrabad Airport]]]] On 1 May 2016, Park became the first South Korean president to visit [[Iran]].{{cite web|url=http://english.yonhapnews.co.kr/national/2016/05/01/0301000000AEN20160501000200315.html|title=Park leaves for Iran for talks with Rouhani|publisher=|accessdate=29 October 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://en.mehrnews.com/news/116253/Korean-pres-makes-historic-visit-to-Tehran|title=Korean pres. makes historic visit to Tehran|date=1 May 2016|publisher=|accessdate=29 October 2016}} She was at the head of a 236-member delegation of businessmen and entrepreneurs during a three-day visit to [[Tehran]] to discuss bilateral trade and other matters of mutual interest.{{cite web|url=http://www.tehrantimes.com/news/301078/Park-on-landmark-visit-to-Tehran-economy-high-on-agenda|title=Park on landmark visit to Tehran, economy high on agenda|date=1 May 2016|publisher=|accessdate=29 October 2016}} She met Iranian President [[Hassan Rouhani]] and held talks with Supreme Leader [[Ali Khamenei]].{{cite web|url=http://presstv.ir/Detail/2016/04/30/463274/Iran-South-Korea-President-Park-visit-/|title=PressTV-Korean pres., biggest trade team woo Iran|publisher=|accessdate=29 October 2016}} The two countries also signed 19 basic agreements to expand mutual cooperation over a variety of areas.{{cite web|url=http://www.presstv.ir/Detail/2016/05/02/463612/Iran-South-Korea-sign-19-agreements/|title=PressTV-Iran, South Korea sign 19 agreements|publisher=|accessdate=29 October 2016}} Earlier, Iran's President Rouhani emphasized that Iran and South Korea are set to boost their trade volume from the current $6 billion to $18 billion. ==== 2016 general elections ==== Park suffered a serious setback in the [[South Korean legislative election, 2016|2016 general elections]] on 13 April 2016, as the Saenuri Party lost both its majority and its status as first party in the National Assembly.{{cite news|url=http://www.scmp.com/news/asia/east-asia/article/1935845/south-korean-election-setback-deals-severe-blow-president-park|title=South Korean election setback deals severe blow to President Park Geun-hye's economic reform agenda|newspaper=[[South China Morning Post]]|date=14 April 2016|accessdate=14 April 2016}} Park had been criticized for her involvement in the elections and the party's nomination process,{{cite news|url=http://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/nation/2016/03/116_200839.html|title=Park's election meddling may backfire|newspaper=[[The Korea Times]]|date=21 March 2016|accessdate=14 April 2016}}{{cite news|url=http://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/nation/2016/03/116_201181.html|title=Park may stay in power after 2018|newspaper=[[The Korea Times]]|date=25 March 2016|accessdate=14 April 2016}} and other Saenuri members blamed the pro-Park faction in the party for the defeat.{{cite news|url=http://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/nation/2016/04/116_202637.html|title= Saenuri's defeat brewing political upheaval|newspaper=[[The Korea Times]]|date=14 April 2016|accessdate=14 April 2016}} Park loyalists fared badly in constituency elections.{{cite news|url=http://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/nation/2016/04/116_202549.html|title=Park loyalists tumble|newspaper=[[The Korea Times]]|date=13 April 2016|accessdate=14 April 2016}} The result was seen to hinder the chances of Park's passing her proposed economic reforms,{{cite news|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/world/conservative-rout-leaves-south-koreas-park-geunhye-a-lame-duck/news-story/16ca1208ddd42854cf92dae327574176?nk=c07dd96332972d39c73e50067a02b460-1460645891|title=Conservative rout leaves South Korea's Park Geun-hye a lame duck|newspaper=[[The Australian]]|date=14 April 2016|accessdate=14 April 2016}} and in the aftermath of the results the conservative ''[[The Chosun Ilbo]]'' stated that Park's "lame duck period has started earlier than any other administration in the past".{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-southkorea-election-idUSKCN0XA2LC|title=Vote defeat for South Korea's Park raises 'lame duck' prospect|publisher=[[Reuters]]|date=14 April 2016|accessdate=14 April 2016}} === Approval ratings === [[File:Park Geun-hye Presidential Approval Rating.svg|thumbnail|right|Park Geun-hye's Presidential Job Approval Rating]] [[File:Park Geun-hye Approval ratings by age.svg|thumb|right|Approval ratings by age]] In July 2013, public support for Park's method of governing state affairs reached up to 63 percent, much higher than the percentage of the votes she had won in the presidential election, which is 52 percent.{{cite web|url=http://www.gallup.co.kr/gallupdb/reportContent.asp?seqNo=449|title=한국갤럽조사연구소|publisher=|accessdate=16 October 2015}} The Korean media explained that such a high level of support comes from Park's principled North Korea policy, constructive outcome from visits to the United States and China, and distancing away from internal political disputes.{{cite web|url=http://www.mt.co.kr/view/mtview.php?type=1&no=2013070515551873288&outlink=1|title=朴대통령, 지지율 63% 급반등···취임후 최고|author=MoneyToday|publisher=|accessdate=16 October 2015}} By January 2015, Park's approval rating had fallen to 30 percent, partly due to the [[sinking of MV Sewol|sinking of MV ''Sewol'']] and disputes with North Korea.{{cite web|url=https://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/nation/2015/01/116_172335.html|title=Park's popularity hits new low|date=23 January 2015|publisher=|accessdate=29 October 2016}} By September 2015, Park's approval had increased to 54 percent due to her diplomacy that defused a military standoff with North Korea,{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-09-04/south-korea-president-park-s-approval-highest-in-year-and-a-half |title=South Korea President Park's Approval Highest in Year-and-a-Half|date= 3 September 2015 |accessdate= 29 December 2015|publisher=bloomberg.com}} but in the aftermath of her party's 2016 election loss, her ratings fell back to 31.5 percent, plunging 8.1 percentage points compared to the week before the election.{{cite news|url=http://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/nation/2016/04/116_202869.html |title=Park and Saenuri's approval ratings dip to new lows |newspaper=[[The Korea Times]] |date=18 April 2016 |accessdate=19 April 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160504210254/http://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/nation/2016/04/116_202869.html |archivedate=4 May 2016 |df=dmy }} On 4 November 2016, Park's ratings fell to 4–5% as details of her relationship with [[Choi Soon-sil]] were investigated and exposed in what became the [[2016 South Korean political scandal]].{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/asia_pacific/south-koreas-presidency-on-the-brink-of-collapse-as-scandal-grows/2016/10/28/7639a2cc-1700-4ef7-a3a4-661b3ff989c4_story.html|title=South Korea's presidency 'on the brink of collapse' as scandal grows|date=29 October 2016|website=Washington Post}}{{cite web|url=http://sports.khan.co.kr/culture/sk_index.html?art_id=201612021024003&sec_id=560901|title=한국갤럽 여론조사, 박근혜 대통령 지지율 4%|date=2 December 2016|publisher=}} ==Arrest and detention== Park was arrested on 31 March 2017, and held in pre-trial detention at the Seoul Detention Center in [[Uiwang]], [[Gyeonggi Province]].{{cite news |quote=Park, who was awaiting the ruling at a room of the Seoul Central Prosecutors' Office, was taken to the Seoul Detention Center in Uiwang, Gyeonggi Province, soon after the decision was announced. Park -- in prison garb -- is expected to travel back and forth to the prosecutors' office for additional questioning before being formally indicted. |first=Si-soo |last=Park |date=31 March 2017 |access-date=1 April 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170401040413/https://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/nation/2017/03/251_226702.html |archive-date=1 April 2017 |url=https://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/nation/2017/03/251_226702.html |publisher=''[[The Korea Times]]'' |title=PARK GEUN-HYE ARRESTED}}{{cite news |url=https://www.thestar.com/news/world/2017/03/31/ousted-south-korean-leader-goes-from-presidential-palace-to-solitary-cell.html |first=Tong-Hyung |last=Kim |publisher=[[The Associated Press]] via ''[[The Toronto Star]]'' |title=Ousted South Korean leader goes from presidential palace to solitary cell |date=31 March 2017 |access-date=1 April 2017 |quote=Park Geun-hye entered the Seoul Detention Center in a black sedan before dawn Friday after a court approved her arrest on corruption allegations.}} On 17 April 2017, Park was formally charged with abuse of power, [[bribery]], coercion, and leaking government secrets.{{cite news |date=17 April 2017 |access-date=17 April 2017 |url=http://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/nation/2017/04/251_227690.html |title=Former President Park, Lotte chairman indicted on corruption charges |publisher=''[[Korea Times]]'' |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170417164527/http://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/nation/2017/04/251_227690.html |archive-date=17 April 2017}} Park denied the charges during five rounds of interrogation while in jail.{{cite news |date=17 April 2017 |access-date=17 April 2017 |url=http://abcnews.go.com/International/wireStory/korean-leader-park-indicted-now-faces-trial-46838400 |first=Hyung-jin |last=Kim |publisher=Associated Press (via ABC News) |title=Ex-South Korean leader Park indicted, faces trial}}{{Cite news|url=http://graphics.straitstimes.com/STI/STIMEDIA/Interactives/2017/03/south-korea-scandal-animated/index.html|title=All the Queen’s men and women|work=The Straits Times|access-date=12 May 2017|language=en}} ===Trial=== Prosecutors sought a 30-year jail term for Park, along with a fine of {{currency|118500000000|KRW}} ({{US$|110579397|link=yes}}). On 6 April 2018, a three-judge panel of the Central District Court in Seoul sentenced Park to 24 years in prison and a fine of {{currency|18000000000|KRW}} ({{US$|16,798,683|link=yes}}), finding her guilty of 16 out of 18 charges brought before her.{{cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-southkorea-politics-park/south-korean-prosecutors-seek-30-years-jail-for-ousted-park-as-supporters-demand-her-release-idUSKCN1GB0FJ |publisher=[[Reuters]] |title=South Korean prosecutors seek 30 years' jail for ousted Park as supporters demand her release |date=February 27, 2018 |first=Hyonhee |last=Shin |first2=Heekyong |last2=Yang |first3=Christine |last3=Kim |editor-first=Nick |editor-last=Macfie}}{{cite news| url=http://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/nation/2018/04/356_246875.html| title=Court orders 24 years in jail for former President Park| first=Kim| last=Se-jeong| publisher=[[Korea Times]]| date=April 6, 2018}}{{cite news |author=Choe Sang-hun |date=6 April 2018 |title=Park Geun-hye, South Korea’s Ousted President, Gets 24 Years in Prison |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/04/06/world/asia/park-geun-hye-south-korea.html |work=The New York Times |accessdate=6 April 2018}}{{cite web|url=https://edition.cnn.com/2018/04/06/asia/south-korea-park-geun-hye-corruption-intl/index.html?sr=fbCNN040618south-korea-park-geun-hye-corruption-intl0810AMStory|title=Former South Korean President Park Geun-hye sentenced to 24 years in prison|first=Paula Hancocks, Yoonjung Seo and James Griffiths,|last=CNN|publisher=}} In June 2018 three former [[National Intelligence Service (South Korea)|NIS]] directors (Lee Byung-kee, Lee Byung-ho, and Nam Jae-joon) who served in the Park administration were found guilty of bribing, related to the [[2016 South Korean political scandal|2016 Park Geun-hye scandals]]. They illegally transferred money from the NIS budget to Park's presidential office. This illegally obtained money was used by Park and her associates for private use and to pay bribes.https://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2018/06/15/asia-pacific/south-korea-jails-ex-spy-chiefs-bribing-former-president-park-geun-hye/ . Retrieved 22 June 2018 == Controversies == === Parentage controversy === Park had been often criticized for being the "daughter of a dictator ([[Park Chung-hee]])"{{cite news|url=http://news.naver.com/main/read.nhn?mode=LSD&mid=sec&sid1=100&oid=003&aid=0003762812|script-title=ko:이해찬 "野 총선승리 시 박근혜 별명은 '독재자의 딸'"|trans-title= Lee Hae-chan, "If the oppositions win the legislative election, Park Geun-hye's nickname will change (from Queen of election) to daughter of a dictator"|date=24 March 2011|accessdate=16 May 2012|language=Korean|work=NewsIs|author=Chang Jin-bok(장진복)}}{{cite news|url=http://www.newshankuk.com/news/content.asp?news_idx=2011011017184489054|script-title=ko:손학규 "누가 뭐래도 박근혜는 박정희의 딸"|trans-title=Sohn Hak-kyu, "No one can deny Park Geun-hye is the daughter of dictator Park Jeonghui"|date=10 January 2011|accessdate=16 May 2012|work=News Hankook|author=Ko Dong-seok(고동석)|language=Korean}} and for not actively supporting the Lee administration by supporters of Lee Myung-bak. A national-level poll conducted in July 2012 by a conservative newspaper reported that 59% of participants responded they did not believe Park was a "daughter of a dictator" while 36% agreed with the characterization.{{ko icon}} [http://news.donga.com/3/all/20120716/47788962/1 2012 Donga Ilbo article] Park Chung-Hee's status as a dictator became a contested topic after the 1997 Asian Financial Crisis. GNP party elites saw this as their chance to revitalize Park Chung-Hee's image, focusing on South Korea's economic growth during his administration, thus steadily changing his public perception.{{Cite journal|last=Lee|first=Young-Im|date=2016-07-21|title=From first daughter to first lady to first woman president: Park Geun-Hye’s path to the South Korean presidency|url=https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/14680777.2016.1213307|journal=Feminist Media Studies|language=en|volume=17|issue=3|pages=377–391|doi=10.1080/14680777.2016.1213307|issn=1468-0777}} During a recent interview with the [[Cheongju]] broadcast station ''[[Cheongju Broadcasting|CJB]]'', Park commented regarding her stance that her father's [[May 16 coup]] was a "revolution to save the country" by stating, "I don't think it's the place of politicians to be fighting over whether [the events of 1961] were a 'coup d'etat' or a 'revolution'."{{cite news|url=http://english.hani.co.kr/arti/english_edition/e_national/546402.html|title=Was it a 'coup' or a 'revolution'?|date=9 August 2012|accessdate=9 August 2012|work=[[The Hankyoreh]]}} In a July 2012 survey, 50% of respondents answered that they disagreed with Park's assessment that her father's 1961 coup was "unavoidable, the best possible choice, and an advisable decision", as opposed to 37% that agreed.{{cite news|url=http://english.hani.co.kr/arti/english_edition/e_national/544829.html|title=An leading Park in latest polls|date=30 July 2012|accessdate=9 August 2012|work=[[The Hankyoreh]]}} From another survey conducted in July 2012, 42% of respondents agreed with her opinion that her father's 1961 coup was "unavoidable", while 46% disagreed.{{cite web|url=http://www.gallup.co.kr/gallupdb/reportContent.asp?seqNo=312&pagepos=1&search=&searchKeyword=&selectYear=|title=한국갤럽조사연구소|publisher=|accessdate=29 October 2016}} Because Park inherited strong regional and generational support from her father, as well as the legacy of his economic success, Park's opponents used her father as criticism against her.{{Cite journal|last=Lee|first=Young-Im|date=2016-07-21|title=From first daughter to first lady to first woman president: Park Geun-Hye’s path to the South Korean presidency|url=https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/14680777.2016.1213307|journal=Feminist Media Studies|language=en|volume=17|issue=3|pages=377–391|doi=10.1080/14680777.2016.1213307|issn=1468-0777}} === Bu-il foundation accusations === Park has faced much scrutiny over an educational foundation, Jeongsoo Scholarship Foundation, formerly known as Buil (in reference to the stock it controls in the newspaper "[[Busan Ilbo]]"), which her father, and later she, headed. Its original owners claimed in court they were forced to turn it over to her father.{{cite news| url=http://english.hani.co.kr/arti/english_edition/e_national/556901.html | work=The Hankyoreh | title= Park Geun-hye denies involvement in scandal-ridden foundation | date=22 October 2012 | accessdate=13 November 2012}} === Party criticism === A [[Liberty Korea Party|Saenuri Party]] assemblyman [[Nam Kyung-pil]] criticized the Park-centered nature of the party, regarding its preparation for the [[South Korean presidential election, 2012|2012 presidential election]], and stated, "If we keep seeing the same situation where Park Geun-hye gives a press conference before a general meeting of lawmakers is held, and what she says then gets decided on as the party's position, then the public is going to think democracy has disappeared from the party."{{cite news |author=Seong Yeon-cheol |date=16 July 2012 |title=Park Geun-hye's flip flopping and double-talking |url=http://english.hani.co.kr/arti/english_edition/e_national/542691.html |work=[[The Hankyoreh]] |accessdate=8 April 2018}} Furthermore, some have said Park's behavior in the lead-up to [[South Korean presidential election, 2012|2012 presidential election]] was a mixture of trend-following and corner-cutting—a stark contrast with the vehement insistence on principle that she showed when she opposed a revision of the plan for a multifunctional administrative city in [[Sejong City]]. For instance, [[Yim Tae-hee]], another presidential candidate of the party, pointed to Park's voting down of a motion to arrest [[Chung Doo-un]], a lawmaker implicated with bribery related to saving banks. Another candidate, [[Ahn Sang-soo (born May 1946)|Ahn Sang-soo]], accused Park of "saying one thing yesterday and another today". === Spokesman scandal === {{further|Yoon Chang-jung}} Park fired [[Yoon Chang-jung]], a [[Blue House]] spokesman who was alleged by [[Metropolitan Police Department of the District of Columbia|Washington police]] to have committed sexual assault against a young woman hired as an intern at the [[Embassy of South Korea, Washington, D.C.|South Korean Embassy in Washington]] during President Park's first visit to the United States.{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/05/11/world/asia/spokesman-for-south-korean-leader-quits.html | publisher=[[New York Times]] | title= South Korean President Fires Spokesman for 'Unsavory Act' During Visit to U.S. |first=SANG-HUN|last=CHOE| date=10 May 2013 | accessdate=10 May 2013}} Park has been criticized for picking the wrong people for senior government posts.{{cite news| url=http://english.yonhapnews.co.kr/national/2013/05/10/30/0301000000AEN20130510001000315F.HTML | publisher=[[Yonhap News Agency]] | title= (4th LD) Park sacks spokesman Yoon amid sexual assault allegations |first=Chi-dong|last=Lee| date=10 May 2013 | accessdate=10 May 2013}} === Election-meddling scandal === {{Main|2012 NIS public opinion manipulation scandal}} {{Update|section|date=November 2016}} Just a week before the presidential election date, the opposing party alleged that the public servants from National Intelligence Service (NIS) have organized to promote Park's election campaign by way of posting online articles favorable to Park and slanderous to the opposing candidates.{{citation needed|date=August 2015}} This political behavior by public servants is strictly prohibited by Korean Constitution.{{cite news|url=http://korea.assembly.go.kr/res/low_01_read.jsp?boardid=1000000035 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120710041912/http://korea.assembly.go.kr/res/low_01_read.jsp?boardid=1000000035 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=10 July 2012 |title=Constitution of the Republic of Korea }} To prove their allegation, the opposing Democratic Party, along with the police and Central Election Assistance Commission, swooped in the house where the alleged agent of NIS has resided.{{citation needed|date=August 2015}} From there, the 29-year-old female agent, later known as Ha-Young Kim, who was running an illegal online election campaign operation such as spreading slanderous postings about the opposing candidate had locked herself in.{{citation needed|date=August 2015}} The police could not force to enter the house and the standoff lasted for three days, provoking a tense political standoff.{{citation needed|date=August 2015}} The opposition accused the intelligence service of blocking an investigation.{{citation needed|date=August 2015}} Park and her party accused the opposition of harassing the woman.{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/04/19/world/asia/south-korean-intelligence-officers-are-accused-of-political-meddling.html?_r=0 | title= South Korean Intelligence Officers Are Accused of Political Meddling | work=The New York Times | first=Choe | last=Sang-Hun | date=18 April 2013}} Park even said the standoff of the self-lock-in was a violation of a female right in the presidential candidate debate that took place three days before the election.{{citation needed|date=August 2015}} Later that night of the presidential debate, Kim Yong-pan, then the chief of Seoul Metropolitan Police Agency, publicly announced there was no evidence of illegal online postings from the collected laptop of the female agent.{{citation needed|date=August 2015}} This announcement, which took place three days before the election, was believed to have significantly affected the outcome of the presidential election according to the opposing party.{{citation needed|date=August 2015}} After months of probes into the alleged election meddling, the prosecution concluded in mid-June 2013 that Won Sei-hoon, then NIS chief who headed the intelligence agency for around four years under former President Lee Myung-bak, ordered agents to conduct online smear campaign against opposition presidential candidates.{{citation needed|date=August 2015}} The special investigation drew a conclusion that the agents systemically intervened in domestic politics by writing thousands of postings on politics in cyberspace through hundreds of different user IDs.{{citation needed|date=August 2015}} Kim Yong-pan, then chief of the Seoul Metropolitan Police Agency (SMPA), was prosecuted without physical detention on charges of abusing his authority to hamper police investigation into the case.{{cite news| url=http://www.philstar.com/world/2013/08/11/1078601/news-analysis-skorea-rattled-spy-agencys-political-interference | title= News Analysis: SKorea rattled by spy agency's political interference}} CCTV conversation between the computer analysts who were analyzing the laptop at police revealed that the police already knew there were illegal online postings against the opposing party's candidates, but the chief of SMPA publicly announced otherwise, an announcement that indicates intentional meddling into the presidential election.{{citation needed|date=August 2015}} The investigation and the trial at court are on-going, and Park faces a political blow.{{citation needed|date=August 2015}} However, the leading Saenuri party along with government leaders has attempted to dodge its political fall-out.{{citation needed|date=August 2015}} Their effort has involved tipping a rumor to a major conservative media, Chosun Ilbo, about an extramarital child of the Chae Dong-wook, former Prosecutor General, who has approved the prosecution of Won Se-hoon and Kim Yong-pan, which eventually led to his resignation.{{cite news| url=https://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/nation/2013/09/116_142783.html | title= Prosecutor general calls it quits}} Yoon Suk-ryul, the director of the special investigation team, which was leading the probe into the election meddling, was fired and returned to his original position, head of Yeoju branch Supreme Prosecutors Office. The investigation of his team has further revealed that the NIS is suspected of having posted 55,689 messages on Twitter for three months until the presidential election.{{cite news| url=http://english.donga.com/srv/service.php3?biid=2013102264948 | title= Prosecutors are swayed by internal conflict and external pressure}} Whether or not the election meddling of the NIS by way of online posts has actually affected the outcome of the presidential election is controversial.{{citation needed|date=August 2015}} However, the false announcement by Kim Yong-pan, then chief of the SMPA, has appeared to do so.{{citation needed|date=August 2015}} Had the police announced honestly, 14% of the electorate who voted for Park said they would have voted for Moon Jae-In, the first runner-up of the election.{{cite news| url=http://www.polinews.co.kr/news/article.html?no=183788 | title= 국정원 경찰수사발표가 대선 결과 영향 52.8%}} === Lack of communication === Park has been criticized for holding press conferences with questions and answers submitted in advance. As of 11 January 2015, she held press conferences four times since she took office in February 2013. Among the four press conferences, three of them were public speeches without questions and answers. Even in the remaining press conference, the questions were submitted in advance and she read prepared answers. Her opponents labeled her as "No communication" (불통, ''Bultong'').{{cite web |script-title=ko:대통령 기자회견 |trans-title=Presidential Press Conference |publisher=Jeonbuk Daily |date=11 February 2015 |url=http://www.jjan.kr/news/articleView.html?idxno=536421 |language=Korean}}{{cite web |title=News Analysis: Park Geun-hye's first year: principle vs. non-communication |date=25 February 2014 |publisher=Xinhua |url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/indepth/2014-02/25/c_133141149.htm |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151019050939/http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/indepth/2014-02/25/c_133141149.htm |archivedate=19 October 2015 |df=dmy-all }} === November 2015 protests === On 15 November 2015, around 80,000 anti-government protesters clashed with government forces on the streets of Seoul, demanding that Park step down, with many of the protesters chanting "Park Geun-hye, step down". The rally was triggered by Park's adopting business-friendly labour policies and a decision to require middle and high schools to use only state-issued history textbooks in classes starting in 2017,{{Cite web|title = Anti-government protesters rally in South Korea|url = http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2015/11/anti-government-protesters-clash-police-korea-151114085804263.html|website = www.aljazeera.com|accessdate = 14 November 2015}} combined with plans to make labour markets more flexible by giving employers more leeway in dismissing workers. Security forces fired tear gas and sprayed water cannons into the crowd when protesters attempted to break through police barricades.{{Cite web|title = S Korea protesters clash with police in Seoul - BBC News|url = https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-34820596|website = BBC News|accessdate = 14 November 2015|language = en-GB}} === Censorship === In the wake of the April 2014 capsize of the [[Sinking of MV Sewol|Sewol]] ferry, public outcry arose over the government's handling of the situation. In response, the Park administration established a commission to monitor and prosecute social media critics of Park.{{Cite web | url = https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-world/2015/south-korea | title = South Korea {{!}} Country report {{!}} Freedom in the World {{!}} 2015 | website = freedomhouse.org | access-date = 28 February 2016 }} [[Tatsuya Kato (journalist)|Tatsuya Kato]], Japanese journalist who was a [[Seoul]] Bureau chief of [[South Korea]] at ''[[Sankei Shimbun]]'' was indicted on charges of defamation for reporting the relationship of President Park Geun-hye and [[Choi Soon-sil]]'s husband, [[Chung Yoon-hoi]], by the [[Supreme Prosecutors' Office of the Republic of Korea]] after the [[sinking of MV Sewol|MV ''Sewol'' sank]].{{cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/korean-prosecutors-indict-japanese-journalist-on-defamation-charge-1412826990|publisher=wsj.com|title=Korean Prosecutors Indict Japanese Journalist on Defamation Charge - WSJ|accessdate=1 November 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://m.koreatimes.co.kr/phone/news/view.jsp?req_newsidx=209657|publisher=m.koreatimes.co.kr|title=US journal criticizes Park's regression into dictatorship|accessdate=1 November 2016}} === Controversy about violating Public Official Election Act === On 25 June 2015 Park said that "Betrayal which breaks the trust shouldn't be accepted in politics and this should be punished by election with people's own hands". This mention was aimed to Yu Seungmin who was a member of Saenuri Party. Her mention was criticized by professor [[Jo Guk]] and politician [[Moon Jae-in]] because it had a purpose of losing Yu Seungmin's election which is protected by Public Official Election Act. But the National Election Commission decided not to treat Park's mention as a violation of Public Official Election Act.Park's mention can be treated as a violation of public official election act http://finance.daum.net/news/news_content.daum?docid=MD20150628171008128 Ruling party floor leader resigns amid party's internal feud / YTN https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dvxXJr4PeIE === Choi Soon-sil scandal and impeachment === {{Main|2016 South Korean political scandal}} {{see also|Impeachment of Park Geun-hye}} In late October 2016, investigations into Park's relationship with [[Choi Soon-sil]], daughter of the late Church of Eternal Life cult leader and President Park's mentor [[Choi Tae-min]] began.{{cite web|url=https://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/nation/2016/10/116_216623.html|date=23 October 2016|title=Investigations into 'Choi Soon-sil gate' widening|website=The Korea Times}}{{cite web|title=All the Queen's men and women|url=http://graphics.straitstimes.com/STI/STIMEDIA/Interactives/2017/03/south-korea-scandal-animated/index.html|website=The Straits Times|accessdate=21 March 2017}} Several news media including [[JTBC]] and [[the Hankyoreh]] reported that Choi, who has no official government position, had access to confidential documents and information for the president, and acted as a close confidant for the president. Choi and President Park's senior staff including both Ahn Jong-bum and Jeong Ho-sung used their influence to extort ₩77.4 billion (approximately $75 million) from Korean [[chaebol]]s—family-owned large business conglomerates—and set up two culture and sports-related foundations, Mir and K-sports foundations.{{cite web|url=http://www.hani.co.kr/arti/society/society_general/768777.html|title=박 대통령 독대한 대기업들 미르·K 출연금 유독 많았다|date=3 November 2016|publisher=hani.co.kr}}{{cite web|url=http://www.hani.co.kr/arti/opinion/column/768706.html|title=[안선희의 밑줄 긋기] 재벌들이 피해자라고?|date=3 November 2016|publisher=hani.co.kr}}{{cite web|url=http://news.donga.com/3/00/20161101/81099663/1|title=[단독]"미르-K스포츠재단 모금, 안종범 수석이 지시했다"|publisher=news.donga.com}} Choi is also accused of having influenced [[Ewha Womans University]] to change their admission criteria in order for her daughter [[Chung Yoo-ra]] to be given a place there.{{cite news|last1=McCurry|first1=Justin|title='Rasputin-like' friend of South Korean president returns amid protests|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/oct/30/south-korea-rasputin-like-friend-president-park-geun-hye-returns|work=The Guardian|date=30 October 2016}} Ahn Jong-bum and Jeong Ho-sung, top presidential aides, were arrested for abuse of power and helping Choi; they denied wrongdoing and claimed that they were simply following President Park's orders.{{cite web|url=http://news.donga.com/rss/feed/3/all/20161102/81140663/1?gid=81140910&srev=1®date=20161103 |title=검찰, 안종범 전 정책조정수석 긴급체포…서울남부구치소로 이송 |publisher=news.donga.com |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161104142326/http://news.donga.com/rss/feed/3/all/20161102/81140663/1?gid=81140910&srev=1®date=20161103 |archivedate=4 November 2016 |df= }} On 25 October 2016, Park publicly acknowledged her close ties with Choi. On 28 October, Park dismissed key members of her top office staff while her [[#Approval ratings|approval ratings]] fell to 4%. Her approval rating ranged from 1 to 3% for Korean citizens under 60 years of age, while it remained higher, at 13%, for the over 60 age group.{{cite web|url=http://m.ohmynews.com/NWS_Web/Mobile/at_pg.aspx?CNTN_CD=A0002257639#cb|title=President Park breaks YS's record, approval rating at 5 percent|date=6 November 2016|website=Oh My News}} It was the worst ever approval rate in Korean history and is worse than the 6% approval rating of former President [[Kim Young-sam]], who was widely blamed for forcing the Korean economy into the [[1997 Asian financial crisis]].{{cite web |title=데일리 오피니언 제234호(2016년 11월 1주) |trans-title=Daily Opinion No. 234 (1 November 2016) |publisher=Gallup Korea |url=http://www.gallup.co.kr/gallupdb/reportContent.asp?seqNo=787&pagePos=1&selectYear=&search=&searchKeyword=}}{{cite web|url=https://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/nation/2016/10/116_217058.html|title=Park orders secretaries to resign over 'Choi Soon-sil scandal'|date=28 October 2016|website=The Korea Times}} The controversy led to [[2016 South Korean protests|mass protests and rallies]] in October and November 2016 calling for her resignation.{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-southkorea-politics-idUSKCN12T08V|title=Thousands protest in South Korea, demand president quit over scandal|website=Reuters}} On 12 November, more than 1 million citizens participated in the protests at Gwanghwamun Square close to presidential residence demanding President Park's resignation or impeachment.{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.kr/2016/11/13/story_n_12936242.html|title='100만명'이 지하철 통계로 증명됐다|publisher=huffingtonpost.kr}} On 19 November, another 1 million people participated in the national protest after Park refused to help in the investigation.{{cite web|url=http://news.nate.com/view/20161120n00937|title=들불로 번진 2주연속 '100만 촛불혁명'…26일 300만 예고|publisher=news.nate.com}}{{cite web|url=http://english.hani.co.kr/arti/english_edition/e_national/771080.html|title=Dreaming of a new world, one million candles again burn nationwide|publisher=english.hani.co.kr}} [[File:민중총궐기 1112 175616.jpg|thumb|Protest held in November 2016]] Park then fired a number of her cabinet members and the prime minister. In particular, the sacking of the prime minister [[Hwang Kyo-ahn]] resulted in a controversy, due to the claim that his firing was carried out via a text message.{{cite web|url=http://m.khan.co.kr/view.html?artid=201611032237025&code=910100|title=Left wings outrage regarding text firing of Hwang Kyo-ahn|website=KyungHyang}}{{cite web|url=http://m.insight.co.kr/newsRead.php?ArtNo=81335|title=Prime minister Hwang Kyo-ahn 'fired' by president Park via a text message|website=Insight}} The Supreme Prosecutors' Office of Korea (SPO), in laying charges against Choi and two former presidential aides, have alleged that President Park colluded with the three in certain criminal activities. The president would be questioned by prosecutors, the first time this has occurred with a serving South Korean president.{{cite news|author1=Agence France-Presse|title=Choi-gate prosecutors accuse South Korean president of collusion|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/nov/20/choi-gate-prosecutors-accuse-south-korean-president-of-collusion|work=The Guardian|date=20 November 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://news.chosun.com/site/data/html_dir/2016/11/20/2016112000593.html|title=최순실, 딸 친구 부모 민원 들어주고 1000만원 샤넬백 등 5000만원 챙겨|publisher=news.chosun.com}}{{cite web|url=http://news.nate.com/view/20161120n10972|title=檢, 헌정사상 첫 현직 대통령 피의자 입건…"3명과 공모범행"(종합)|publisher=news.nate.com}} Following the scandal, there were a series of massive demonstrations that started in the first week of November 2016.{{Cite web|url=http://www.atimes.com/article/south-koreas-president-park-beast-public-sentiment/|title=South Korea's President Park and the beast of public sentiment|last=Breen|first=Michael|date=29 November 2016|website=www.atimes.com|publisher=|access-date=2 December 2016}} On 29 November 2016, Park offered to resign as President, and invited the National Assembly to arrange a transfer of power. The opposition parties rejected the offer, accusing Park of attempting to avoid the process of impeachment.{{cite web|last1=McCurry|first1=Justin|title=South Korea's president calls on parliament to arrange her exit|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/nov/29/south-koreas-president-calls-on-parliament-to-arrange-her-exit|website=[[The Guardian]]|accessdate=29 November 2016|date=29 November 2016}} The National Assembly instead filed a motion for impeachment, which was put to a vote on 9 December 2016{{cite web|author1=[[Agence France-Presse]]|title=South Korean president Park Geun-Hye to face impeachment vote|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/dec/03/south-korean-president-park-geun-hye-to-face-impeachment-vote|website=''[[The Guardian]]''|accessdate=3 December 2016|date=3 December 2016}} and passed with 234 supports.{{cite news|last1=Sang-hun|first1=Choe|title=South Korea Parliament Votes to Impeach President Park Geun-hye|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/12/09/world/asia/south-korea-president-park-geun-hye-impeached.html|accessdate=9 December 2016|work=The New York Times|date=9 December 2016}}{{cite news|last1=Joo|first1=Youngjae|title=[속보]박근혜 대통령 탄핵소추안 가결···찬성 234·반대 56·무효 7·기권 2|url=http://news.khan.co.kr/kh_news/khan_art_view.html?artid=201612091610001&code=940100|accessdate=9 December 2016|work=Kyunghyang|date=9 December 2016|language=Korean}}{{cite web|url=http://in.reuters.com/article/southkorea-politics-idINKBN13X2JQ|title=South Korean parliament votes overwhelmingly to impeach President Park|first1=Ju-min|last1=Park|first2=Jack|last2=Kim|publisher=}} Due to the ratification of her [[Impeachment of Park Geun-hye|impeachment proposal]], her presidential powers and duties were suspended, and Prime Minister [[Hwang Kyo-ahn]] assumed those powers and duties as Acting President. Park was finally ousted from office by the Constitutional Court on 10 March 2017. The decision was unanimous, 8–0 in favour of impeachment, as announced shortly thereafter.{{cite news|title=South Korea president Park Geun-hye ousted by court|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-39202936|accessdate=10 March 2017|agency=BBC|date=10 March 2017}} On 26 March 2017, South Korean prosecutors announced they were seeking an arrest warrant against Park.{{Cite web|url=http://www.cnn.com/2017/03/27/asia/south-korea-park-geun-hye/index.html|title=Arrest warrant sought for ousted South Korean president|last=CNN|first=Taehoon Lee|website=CNN|access-date=27 March 2017}} This warrant was granted by the [[Seoul Central District Court]] on 30 March 2017 and Park was arrested later that day.{{cite news|title=Ex-South Korean president Park Geun-hye arrested|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-39449681|accessdate=30 March 2017|work=BBC|date=30 March 2017}} == Electoral history == === National Assembly races (1998 to present) === ==== 1998 ==== {{Election box begin no change | title=15th National Assembly of the Republic of Korea elections, 1998 by-election, Dalseong, Daegu{{cite news|url=http://newslibrary.naver.com/viewer/index.nhn?articleId=1998040300289101004&edtNo=5&printCount=1&publishDate=1998-04-03&officeId=00028&pageNo=1&printNo=3157&publishType=00010|script-title=ko:한나라 재보선 4곳 석권|trans-title=GNP won all four seats of by-election|date=3 April 1998|accessdate=16 May 2012|work=[[The Hankyoreh]]|author1=An Jaeseung(안재승)|author2=Choe Ikrim(최익림)|author3=Hong Dae-sun(홍대선)|author4=Sin Seung-geun(신승근)|language=Korean|quote=대구 달성에선 이날 자정 현재 82%개표 상황에서 박근혜 후보가 2만8937표(51.5%)를 얻어 1만 6355표(29.1%)를 얻은 엄삼탁 국민회의 후보를 크게 앞지르며 당선됐다. [In Dalseong Daegu, 82% votes were counted by 12 am. And Park Geun-hye got 28,937 (52%) votes, compared to 16,355 (29%) votes for Eom Samtak of Democratic Party. Park has been elected by wide margin.]}}}} {{Election box winning candidate with party link no change| |party = Grand National Party |candidate = Park Geun-hye |votes = 28,937 |percentage = 64 }} {{Election box candidate with party link no change| |party = National Congress for New Politics |candidate = Eom Sam-tak |votes = 16,355 |percentage = 36 }} {{Election box total no change| |votes = National Assembly of the Republic of Korea elections, 2000, Dalseong, Daegu{{cite web|url=http://www.nec.go.kr/sinfo/|archive-url=https://archive.is/20130218232337/http://www.nec.go.kr/sinfo/|dead-url=yes|archive-date=18 February 2013|title=중앙선거관리위원회, 역대 선거정보 시스템|trans-title=NEC, past election result|accessdate=16 May 2012}}}} {{Election box winning candidate with party link no change| |party = Grand National Party |candidate = Park Geun-hye |votes = 37,805 |percentage = 61 }} |percentage = 100 }} {{Election box hold with party link without swing| |winner = Grand National Party }} {{Election box end}} ==== 2004 ==== {{Election box begin no change | title=17th National Assembly of the Republic of Korea elections, 2004, Dalseong, Daegu}} {{Election box winning candidate with party link no change| |party = Grand National Party |candidate = Park Geun-hye |votes = 45,298 |percentage = 70 }} {{Election box candidate with party link no change| |party = Uri Party |candidate = Yun Yong-hui |votes = 15,014 |percentage = 23 }} {{Election box candidate with party link {{Refimprove|date=April 2010}} {{Infobox album | name = Pump Up the Jam | type = Album | artist = [[Technotronic]] | cover = Technotronic Pump Up The Jam First Cover.jpeg | alt = | released = 28 November 1989 | recorded = | venue = | studio = | genre = [[Techno]] | length = | label = {{hlist|ARS|[[SBK Records|SBK]]/[[EMI|EMI Records]] (US)|Swanyard <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.discogs.com/label/9466-Swanyard-Records-Ltd|title=Swanyard Records Ltd|accessdate=10 July 2017}}</ref>|}} | producer = [[Jo Bogaert|Thomas de Quincey]] | prev_title = | prev_year = | next_title = [[Trip on This: The Remixes]] | next_year = 1990 | misc = {{Extra album cover | header = Alternative cover | type = Album | cover = Technotronic Pump Up The Jam.jpg | border = | alt = | caption = North American cover }} {{Extra album cover | header = Alternative cover | type = Album | cover = Technotronic featuring Ya Kid K.jpg | border = | alt = | caption = Replacement cover }} {{Singles | name = Pump Up the Jam | type = studio | single1 = [[Pump Up the Jam]] | single1date = 27 September 1989 | single2 = [[Get Up! (Before the Night Is Over)]] | single2date = 8 January 1990 | single3 = [[This Beat Is Technotronic]] | single3date = 15 February 1990 | single4 = [[Rockin' Over the Beat]] | single4date = 20 April 1990 | single5 = [[Move This]] | single5date = 25 February 1992 }} }} {{Album ratings | rev1 = [[AllMusic]] | rev1Score = {{Rating|4.5|5}}<ref>{{Allmusic|class=album|id=r19761}}</ref> | rev2 = [[Robert Christgau]] | rev2Score = (A-)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.robertchristgau.com/get_artist.php?name=technotronic|title=Robert Christgau: CG: technotronic|website=www.robertchristgau.com|accessdate=18 May 2017}}</ref> }} '''''Pump Up the Jam''''' (also known as '''''Pump Up the Jam: The Album''''' in North America) is the debut [[studio album]] by Belgian dance act [[Technotronic]]. It was released on 28 November 1989. When it was discovered that model Felly [[Lip sync|lip-synched]] to vocals that were actually performed by Belgian [[Rapper|emcee]] [[Ya Kid K]], the album's artwork, which had featured a picture of Felly, was changed to feature Ya Kid K instead. The album reached number 2 on the [[UK Albums Chart]].<ref name="OCC">{{cite web|url=http://www.officialcharts.com/artist/_/technotronic/|title=TECHNOTRONIC | Artist | Official Charts|work=[[Official Charts Company]]|publisher=[[British Phonographic Industry]]|accessdate=10 July 2013}}</ref>
== Track listing == {{tracklist |collapsed = |headline = |extra_column = |total_length =
|title1 = [[Pump Up the Jam|Pump up the Jam]] |writer1 = [[Ya Kid K|Manuela Kamosi]], [[Jo Bogaert]] |length1 = 5:20
|title2 = [[Get Up! (Before the Night Is Over)]] |writer2 = Kamosi, Jo Bogaert |length2 = 5:37
|title3 = Tough |writer3 = [[Me One|Eric Martin]], Bogaert |length3 = 4:25
|title4 = Take It Slow |writer4 = Kamosi, Bogaert |length4 = 5:05
|title5 = Come On |writer5 = Bogaert |length5 = 3:09
|title6 = [[This Beat Is Technotronic]] |writer6 = Martin, Bogaert |length6 = 5:26
|title7 = [[Move This]] |writer7 = Kamosi, Bogaert |length7 = 5:19
|title8 = Come Back |writer8 = Bogaert |length8 = 4:52
|title9 = [[Rockin' Over the Beat]] |writer9 = Kamosi, Bogaert |length9 = 5:46
|title10 = Raw |writer10 = Bogaert |length10 = 4:37
|title11 = Wave |writer11 = Bogaert |length11 = 4:17
|title12 = String |writer12 = Bogaert |length12 = 2:54 }} ;Notes *Track 11 and 12 are CD bonus tracks. Track 12 is titled "Bluestring" on U.S. and Canadian CD release. Tracks 1, 2, 3, 4, 7, 8, 9, and 10 are in longer versions on CD.
==Personnel== *[[Ya Kid K|Manuela "Ya Kid K" Kamosi]] – vocals *[[Me One|Eric "MC Eric" Martin]] – vocals *Patrick de Meyer, Yannic Fonderie – keyboards *DJ Seik – turntable scratching on "Get Up!" "Tough," "Take it Slow," and "Raw" *[[Jo Bogaert|Jo “Thomas de Quincey” Bogaert]] – all other instruments and programming
;Production *Produced by Jo Bogaert for ARS Entertainment Belgium *Engineered by Spencer Henderson at Swanyard Studios, London, UK
==Charts== {| class="wikitable" !Chart !Position |- | [[UK Albums Chart]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.officialcharts.com/artist/26486/technotronic/|title=Official Charts Company|website=www.officialcharts.com|accessdate=18 May 2017}}</ref> | style="text-align:center;"|2 |- | US [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/artist/371857/technotronic/chart?f=305|title=Technotronic - Chart history - Billboard|website=www.billboard.com|accessdate=18 May 2017}}</ref> | style="text-align:center;"|10 |}

revision.comment: /* Private groups */
revision.text:
'''Relief 2.0''' or '''disaster relief 2.0''' is the deployment of [[digital information]] techniques in the management of [[disaster relief]].
== History == The first large-scale use of modern digital information techniques was by technology experts and volunteers responding to the [[Hurricane Katrina|Katrina disaster]] in 2005 in the USA.
Further notable developments came in the disasters that followed, in particular the 7.0MW [[2010 Haiti earthquake|earthquake in Haiti]] on January 12, 2010 and the 9.0MW [[2011 Tōhoku earthquake and tsunami|earthquake and tsunami in Japan]] on March 11, 2011. In Japan, a disaster relief organization was created under the name "Relief 2.0".<ref name="Low2016">{{cite book|author=Robin Low|title=Good Intentions Are Not Enough: Why We Fail at Helping Others|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gmltDQAAQBAJ&pg=PA127|date=18 October 2016|publisher=World Scientific|isbn=978-981-320-059-3|page=111}}</ref>
=== Academia involvement === Following the aftermath of the 2010 Haiti earthquake, a group of fellows, academics, technology experts and emergency response volunteers organized a Relief 2.0 workshop at [[Stanford University]] in February 2010 to collect and organize the lessons learned in the field in Haiti. These lessons were further researched and worked on at the [[National University of Singapore]] Entrepreneurship Centre in collaboration with the Stanford University Peace Innovation Laboratory and later tested in the field in the [[Tōhoku Region]] of Japan after the Tōhoku earthquake and tsunami of 2011. The findings were presented at [[Kyushu University]] in Fukuoka, Japan in April 2010 during the TEDxEarthquake9.0 conference.
=== International organization reports === In April 2011, the report "Disaster Relief 2.0: The Future of Humanitarian Information Sharing" report was presented at the US Mission to the UN in New York.<ref>[http://www.unocha.org/top-stories/all-stories/disaster-relief-20-future-information-sharing-humanitarian-emergencies "Disaster Relief 2.0: The Future of Humanitarian Information Sharing"], UN OCHA</ref> It was prepared by the [[Harvard Humanitarian Initiative]], in cooperation with the [[United Nations Foundation]], [[Vodafone Foundation]] and the [[UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs]] (UN OCHA). This report highlighted the role of mass participation using [[mobile communication]]s, [[social media]] and [[crisis mapping]] to pinpoint the most urgent needs following a disaster.<ref name="Ali2016">{{cite book|author=Shahla F. Ali|title=Governing Disasters: Engaging Local Populations in Humanitarian Relief|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dQnPDAAAQBAJ&pg=PA232|date=13 June 2016|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-1-316-59845-0|page=232}}</ref>
== Tools == There are a number of tools, toolkits and specific platforms available and used in the practice of Relief 2.0, including [[Ushahidi]] Crowdmap, [[Frontline SMS]], [[OpenStreetMap]]s, [[Sahana FOSS Disaster Management System]] and [[Crisis Maps]].
== Private groups == Several private, government funded and non-profit groups have emerged in recent years to advance the practice of Relief 2.0, increase preparedness and the effectiveness of disaster response at a local and a global level. These include: [http://crisismappers.net/ Crisis Mappers], [http://www.standbytaskforce.org/ Standby Task Force], [https://sempo.ai Sempo], [[Digital Humanitarian Network]] and Relief 2.0 Inc.
== See also == * [[Digital humanitarianism]] * [[Crowdmapping]]
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Disaster management]]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2018}} {{Use Indian English|date=March 2018}} {{BLP sources|date=January 2016}} '''Sadanand Date''' is an officer of 1990 batch of [[Indian Police Service]] (IPS). He has held several important posts at both state and national levels of the IPS, including serving as deputy inspector general of police in the [[Central Bureau of Investigation]] (CBI). He gained a doctorate from [[Pune University]] (in his home town), having previously done postgraduate work in commerce. Date is also a qualified cost and management accountant. He attended the [[University of Minnesota]] under the Humphrey fellowship program, where he studied the theoretical and practical aspects of controlling white-collar and organized crime in the United States. On his return to India he was posted as additional commissioner of police (economic offences wing).<ref>"[http://www.tehelka.com/story_main30.asp?filename=Bu120507Scandal_in.asp Scandal in the Warehouse]", ''[[Tehelka]]'', 12 May 2007.</ref> He was awarded the President's medal in 2007.
== Mumbai attacks ==
Date attracted international attention during the [[November 2008 Mumbai attacks]] because of his actions resisting terrorists at the [[Cama Hospital|Cama and Albless Hospital]] for women and children, where he was seriously wounded. Responding to Date's call to Police Headquarters for backup, [[Ashok Kamte]], [[Hemant Karkare]], [[Vijay Salaskar]] and four constables were ambushed ''[[wikt:en route|en route]]'' by two terrorists. The three officers and three constables were killed quickly; the surviving constable reported the events to representatives of the press. The wounded Date was eventually successfully evacuated for medical attention.
== See also ==
* [[Gajendra Singh (NSG commando)]] * [[Sandeep Unnikrishnan]]
== References ==
{{Reflist}}
== External links == * [http://www1.umn.edu/humanrts/center/humphrey/2005hfellows.html Humphrey Fellows] — bios of fellows, including Sadanand Date, from the official University of Minnesota website * [https://web.archive.org/web/20081209103246/http://www.indsearch.org/pdf/ResearchNewsletter1.pdf Research Newsletter] — abstract of Sadanand Date's PhD research (page 2 of 2)
{{DEFAULTSORT:Date, Sadanand}} [[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Indian police officers killed in the line of duty]] [[Category:University of Minnesota alumni]] [[Category:People associated with the 2008 Mumbai attacks]] [[Category:Victims of the 2008 Mumbai attacks]] [[Category:Police officers from Mumbai]]
